A person named Apollodorus, who was present, a great admirer of Socrates, but, otherwise, of weak understanding, said, “ I grieve most on this account, Socrates, that I see you going to die undeservedly;
tgt_text.2701: " when it is said that Socrates, stroking the head of Apollodorus, asked, "And would you, my dearest Apollodorus, rather see me die deservedly than undeservedly ? " Socrates, as he said this, smiled upon him.
tgt_text.2703: It is related, also, that on seeing Anytus pass by, he remarked, " This man is elated, as if he had done something great and honourable in causing my death, because, when I saw him thought worthy of the highest offices by the state,1 I said that he ought not to bring up his son among ox-hides.
tgt_text.2705: How foolish is he," added Socrates, " who does not seem to know that whichsoever of us has done that which is more beneficial and more honourable for all time, is the superior!
tgt_text.2706: 30. But," he continued, " Homer has attributed to some of his personages3 the faculty of foreseeing the future at the end of their lives;
tgt_text.2707: and I am desirous also of uttering something in the manner of a prophecy.
tgt_text.2708: I had the company, for a short time, of Anytus's son;
tgt_text.2709: and he appeared to me to be not with­ out vigour of mind;
tgt_text.2710: and I therefore predict that he will not continue at the servile occupation which his father has destined for him, but that, as he has no efficient guardian, he will plunge himself into some licentious gratification and advance far into vice."
tgt_text.2711: In making this prediction, Socrates was not deceived;
tgt_text.2712: for the young man, conceiving a passion for wine, ceased neither night nor day from drinking, and at last became worthless alike to his country, his friends, and himself.
tgt_text.2713: Anytus, on account of his bad education of his son, and his own folly, is loaded with infamy, even now that he is dead.
tgt_text.2714: 31. But Socrates, incurring odium through magnifying himself before the tribunal, afforded the more inducement to his judges to pronounce sentence against him.
tgt_text.2715: To me, how­ ever, he appears to have met with a fate appointed by the kindness of the gods ;
tgt_text.2716: for he was freed from the most trouble­ some part of life, and suffered the easiest of deaths.
tgt_text.2717: 32. He gave a proof of the firmness of his mind ;
tgt_text.2718: for as he felt that to die was better for him than to live, he, as he had never been averse to anything else that was good, did not show want of spirit to meet death, but welcomed it and submitted to it with cheerfulness.
tgt_text.2719: For myself, observing his wisdom and noble­ ness of mind, I cannot forbear to think of him, or, while I think of him, to praise him.
tgt_text.2720: But if any one, among those who are studious of virtue, has met with a more beneficial instructor than Socrates, I consider him to be of all mankind the most deserving of congratulation.
tgt_text.2721: THE minute attention which I have necessarily given to the style of these Treatises in translating them induces me to form a much more unfavourable opinion with regard to their genuineness than I conceived when I read them for the first time some years ago.
tgt_text.2722: In the Life of Xenophon prefixed to the previous volume, I said, relying on my own early impressions and the judgment of Weiske, that there was nothing in the style or manner of the treatises to prove that Xenophon was not their author.
tgt_text.2723: Nor is there so much discrepancy in the style of them from that of Xenophon's acknow­ ledged works as to make it clear to all readers that Xenophon did not write them;
tgt_text.2724: for, as Weiske observes, mere dissimilitude of dic­ tion will not suffice to demonstrate that they are spurious, since a writer may, for various reasons, adopt different forms of style in different compositions.
tgt_text.2725: But the numerous repetitions of the same phrases in the treatise on the Lacedæmonian Government, and the curtness and aridity of the phraseology, seem to convict the writer of a poverty of words never chargeable upon Xenophon ;
tgt_text.2726: and I am now, therefore, inclined to think with Heyne, Heindorf, and F. A. Wolf, that they are the work of some other writer than the Attic bee.
tgt_text.2727: As to the style of the Treatise on the Athenian Government, it certainly approaches nearer to that of Xenophon, in structure and flow, than the style of the other, but is still far beneath the excel­ lence of the master's own compositions.
tgt_text.2728: With regard to the matter, in both treatises, especially in that on the Laeedæmonian Government, much of it is so extremely poor and trifling, that it cannot be thought to have proceeded from Xenophon.
tgt_text.2729: That Xenophon wrote Treatises on the Lacedæmonian and Athenian Governments is mentioned by Diogenes Laertius and other writers;
tgt_text.2730: but the genuineness of the books on those subjects which were in circulation under his name in early times was denied by Demetrius of Magnesia, a contemporary of Cicero.
tgt_text.2731: Longinus cites a few words from the treatise on the Government of the Lace­ dæmonians as Xenophon's, but with some variation from the pre­ sent text.
tgt_text.2732: Whether therefore the original treatises have been lost, and others substituted by an inferior hand, or whether they have been mutilated, and the deficiencies supplied by some unskilful essayist at reparation, must remain doubtful.
tgt_text.2733: The question is fully discussed by Sauppe in the preface to his edition of Schneider.
tgt_text.2734: Sauppe tries to prove both pieces genuine.
tgt_text.2735: That the fourteenth chapter of the Treatise on the Lacedæmonian Government is, if not spurious, certainly out of place, is admitted by Weiske, Schneider, and Dindorf.1.
tgt_text.2736: BUT1 reflecting once how Sparta, one of the least popu­ lous of states,2 had proved the most powerful and celebrated city3 in Greece, I wondered by what means this result had been produced.
tgt_text.2737: When I proceeded, however, to contemplate the institutions of the Spartans, I wondered no longer.
tgt_text.2739: Lycurgus, who made laws for them, by obedience to which they have flourished, I not only admire, but consider to have been in the fullest sense a wise man ;
tgt_text.2740: for he rendered his country preëminent in prosperity, not by imitating other states, but by making ordinances contrary to those of most governments.
tgt_text.2742: With regard, for example, to the procreation of children, that I may begin from the beginning, other people feed their young women, who are about to produce offspring, and who are of the class regarded as well brought up, on the most moderate quantity of vegetable food possible, and on the least possible quantity of meat, while they either keep them from wine altogether, or allow them to use it only when mixed with water ;
tgt_text.2743: and as the greater number of the men engaged in trades are sedentary, so the rest of the Greeks think it proper that their young women should sit quiet and spin wool.
tgt_text.2744: But how can we expect that women thus treated should produce a vigorous progeny ?
tgt_text.2745: 4. Lycurgus, on the contrary, thought that female slaves were competent to furnish clothes ;
tgt_text.2746: and, considering that the production of chil­ dren was the noblest duty of the free, he enacted, in the first place, that the female should practise bodily exercises no less than the male sex ;
tgt_text.2747: and he then appointed for the women con­ tests with one another, just as for the men, expecting that when both parents were rendered strong, a stronger offspring would be born from them.
tgt_text.2749: Observing, too, that the men of other nations, when women were united to husbands, associated with their wives, during the early part of their intercourse, without restraint, he made enactments quite at variance with this practice;
tgt_text.2750: for he ordained that a man should think it shame to be seen going in to his wife, or coming out from her.
tgt_text.2751: When married people meet in this way, they must feel stronger desire for the company of one another, and whatever offspring is produced must thus be rendered far more robust than if the parents were satiated with each other's society.
tgt_text.2753: In addition to these regulations, he also took from the men the liberty of marrying when each of them pleased, and appointed that they should contract marriages only when they were in full bodily vigour, deeming this injunction also con­ ducive to the production of an excellent offspring.
tgt_text.2754: 7. Seeing also that if old men chanced to have young wives, they watch- ed their wives with the utmost strictness, he made a law quite opposed to this feeling;
tgt_text.2755: for he appointed that an old man should introduce to his wife whatever man in the prime of life he admired for his corporeal and mental qualities, in order that she might have children by him.
tgt_text.2756: 8. If, again, a man was unwilling to associate with his wife, and yet was desirous of having proper children, he made a provision also with re­ spect to him, that whatever woman he saw likely to have off­ spring, and of good disposition, he might, on obtaining the consent of her husband, have children by her.
tgt_text.2757: 9. Many simi­ lar permissions he gave;
tgt_text.2758: for the women are willing to have two families,1 and the men to receive brothers to their children, who are equal to them in birth and standing, but have no claim to share in their property,10.
tgt_text.2759: Let him who wishes, then, consider whether Lycurgus, in thus making enactments different from those of other legis­ lators, in regard to the procreation of children, secured for Sparta a race of men eminent for size and strength.
tgt_text.2761: HAVING given this account of the procreation of children, I wish also to detail the education of those of both sexes.
tgt_text.2763: Of the other Greeks, those who say that they bring up their sons best set slaves over them to take charge of them,1 as soon as the children can understand what is said to them, and send them, at the same time, to schoolmasters, to learn letters, and music, and the exercises of the palæstra.
tgt_text.2764: They also render their children's feet delicate by the use of sandals, and weaken their bodies by changes of clothes;
tgt_text.2765: and as to food, they regard their appetite as the measure of what they are to take.
tgt_text.2766: 2. But Lycurgus, instead of allowing each citizen to set slaves as guardians over his children, appointed a man to have the care of them all, one of those from whom the chief magistrates are chosen;
tgt_text.2767: and he is called the Pædonomus.
tgt_text.2768: He invested this man with full authority to assemble the boys, and, if he found that any one was negligent of his duties, to punish him severely.
tgt_text.2769: He assigned him also some of the grown-up boys as scourge-bearers, that they might inflict whatever chastisement was necessary;
tgt_text.2770: so that great dread of disgrace, and great willingness to obey, prevailed among them.
tgt_text.2772: Instead, also, of making their feet soft with sandals, he enacted that they should harden them by going without san­ dals ;
tgt_text.2773: thinking that, if they exercised themselves in this state, they would go up steep places with far greater ease, and de­ scend declivities with greater safety;
tgt_text.2774: and that they would also leap, and skip, and run faster unshod, if they had their feet inured to doing so, than shod.
tgt_text.2775: 4. Instead of being ren­ dered effeminate, too, by a variety of dresses, he made it a practice that they should accustom themselves to one dress throughout the year;
tgt_text.2776: thinking that they would thus be better prepared to endure cold and heat.
tgt_text.2778: As to food, he ordained that they should exhort the boys2 to take only such a quantity as never to be oppressed with repletion, and not to be strangers to living somewhat frugally;
tgt_text.2779: supposing that, being thus brought up, they would be the better able, if they should be required, to support toil under a scarcity of supplies, would be the more likely to persevere in exertion, should it be imposed on them, on the same quantity of provisions, and would be less desirous of sauces, more easily satisfied with any kind of food, and pass their lives in greater health.
tgt_text.2780: He also considered that the fare which rendered the body slender would be more conducive to increasing its stature than that which expanded it with nutriment.
tgt_text.2781: 6. Yet that the boys might not suffer too much from hunger, Lycurgus, though he did not allow them to take what they wanted with­ out trouble, gave them liberty to steal certain things to relieve the cravings of nature;
tgt_text.2782: and he made it honourable to steal as many cheeses as possible.
tgt_text.2784: 7. That he did not give them leave to form schemes for getting food because he was at a loss what to allot them, I suppose no one is ignorant;
tgt_text.2785: as it is evident that he who designs to steal must be wakeful during the night, and use deceit, and lay plots;
tgt_text.2786: and, if he would gain anything of consequence, must employ spies.
tgt_text.2787: All these things, therefore, it is plain that he taught the children from a desire to render them more dexterous in securing provisions, and better qualified for warfare.
tgt_text.2789: Some one may say, “ Why, then, if he thought it hon­ ourable to steal, did he inflict a great number of stripes on him who was caught in the fact ?"
tgt_text.2790: I answer, that in other things which men teach, they punish him who does not follow his instructions properly;
tgt_text.2791: and that the Lacedæmonians ac­ cordingly punished those who were detected as having at­ tempted to steal in an improper manner.
tgt_text.2792: These boys he gave in charge to others to scourge them at the altar of Diana Orthia ;
tgt_text.2793: 2 designing to show by this enactment that it is pos­ sible for a person, after enduring pain for a short time, to enjoy pleasure with credit for a long time.
tgt_text.2795: It is also shown by this punishment that, where there is need of activity, the inert person benefits himself the least, and occasions himself most trouble.
tgt_text.2797: In order, too, that the boys, in case of the pædonomus being absent, may never be in want of a president, he ap­ pointed that whoever of the citizens may happen at any time to be present is to assume the direction of them, and to enjoin whatever he may think advantageous for them, and punish them if they do anything wrong.
tgt_text.2798: By doing this, Lycurgus has also succeeded in rendering the boys much more modest;
tgt_text.2799: for neither boys nor men respect any one so much as their rulers.
tgt_text.2800: 11. And that if, on any occasion, no full-grown man happen to be present, the boys may not even in that case be without a leader, he ordained that the most active of the grown-up youths take the command of each band;
tgt_text.2801: so that the boys there are never without a superintendent.
tgt_text.2803: It appears to me that I must say something also of the boys as objects of affection;
tgt_text.2804: for this has likewise some refer­ ence to education.
tgt_text.2805: Among the other Greeks, a man and boy either form a union, as among the Bœotians, and associate together, or, as among the Eleians, the men gain the favour of the youths by means of attentions bestowed upon them;
tgt_text.2806: but there are some of the Greeks who prohibit the suitors for the boys' favours from having the least conversation with them.
tgt_text.2808: But Lycurgus, acting contrary to all these people also, thought proper, if any man, being himself such as he ought to be, admired the disposition of a youth, and made it his object to render him a faultless friend, and to enjoy his society, to bestow praise upon him, and regarded this as the most excellent kind of education;
tgt_text.2809: but if any man showed that his affections were fixed only on the bodily attractions of a youth, Lycurgus, considering this as most unbecoming, ap­ pointed that at Lacedæmon suitors for the favours of boys should abstain from intimate connexion with them, not less strictly than parents abstain from such intercourse with their children, or children of the same family from that with one another.
tgt_text.2810: 14. That such a state of things is disbelieved by some, I am not surprised;
tgt_text.2811: for in most states the laws are not at all adverse to the love of youths;
tgt_text.2812: but Lycurgus, for his part, took such precautions with reference to it.
tgt_text.2814: WHEN boys pass from the condition of children to that of young men, the rest of the Greeks withdraw them from the charge of the slaves who have had the care of them, and with­ draw them at the same time from the schools, when no one any longer directs them, but the authorities allow them to live according to their own pleasure.
tgt_text.2815: 2. Lycurgus, however, made enactments at variance with this custom;
tgt_text.2816: for observing that in youths of such an age there is naturally the greatest spirit, the greatest presumption apparent in their conduct, and the keenest desire of pleasure prevailing in their minds, he im­ posed upon them, at that period of life, the most constant toil, and contrived as much occupation for them as possible.
tgt_text.2817: 3. Enacting in addition, too, that if any one should shrink from these exercises, he should afterwards be eligible to no kind of honours, he occasioned that not only the public magistrates,1 but those who had the charge also of individuals, took care that they might not, by indolent neglect of their duty, become utterly disreputable in the state.
tgt_text.2819: Besides, as he wished to engender in them the deepest feelings of modesty, he enjoined them, when they were on the public roads, to keep both their hands under their dress, to walk along in silence, not to look round in any direction, but to keep their eyes on what was before their feet.
tgt_text.2820: 5. Hence it was made manifest that the male sex is more susceptible of acquiring modesty than even the female;
tgt_text.2821: for you would hear no more sound of a voice from them than from stone statues;
tgt_text.2822: you would have as much difficulty in turning their eyes as if they were made of brass;
tgt_text.2823: you would esteem them more bash­ ful than even virgins in the bridal chamber;
tgt_text.2824: and when they came into the philition,2 you must be content to hear only what was asked of them.
tgt_text.2826: The education among the Lacedæmonians, and that among the other Greeks, has now been detailed;
tgt_text.2827: and by which of the two men are formed to be more obedient and unassuming, and more temperate in things in which they ought to be temperate, let him who pleases consider.
tgt_text.2829: ON the full-grown men, however, he bestowed the most anxious attention ;
tgt_text.2830: as he thought that they, if they proved such as they ought to be, would have the greatest influence in promoting the welfare of the state.
tgt_text.2831: 2. Observing, there­ fore, that among whatever people emulation was excited, their bands of singers were most deserving of being heard, and their gymnastic contests most worthy of being seen, he con­ sidered that if he could match the youth with one another in a contest for meritorious distinction, they would thus un­ doubtedly arrive at the greatest eminence in manly excellence.
tgt_text.2832: How he stimulated them, accordingly, to contend with one another, I will relate.
tgt_text.2834: From the men in the full vigour of life the ephori choose three, who are called Hippagretæ.
tgt_text.2835: Each of these makes choice of a hundred others, explaining for what reasons he prefers some and rejects others.
tgt_text.2836: 4. Those who do not obtain this honour are at strife as well with those who have rejected them, as with those who have been preferred to them ;
tgt_text.2837: and they also keep strict watch over one another, lest they should act at all laxly, contrary to what is considered honourable.
tgt_text.2839: Such strife is both highly acceptable to the gods, and extremely beneficial to the community;
tgt_text.2840: for in it is shown what a good citizen ought to do;
tgt_text.2841: and the people exercise themselves individually that they may always be in good condition, and may severally support the state, if it be at all necessary, with all their might.
tgt_text.2842: 6. They must also attend to their health, for in consequence of this emulation, they engage in boxing with one another, whenever they chance to meet;
tgt_text.2843: but any person who comes up on the occasion has full power to sepa­ rate the combatants ;
tgt_text.2844: and if either disobeys him that would separate them, the pædonomus takes him before the ephori, who inflict a heavy penalty upon him, as they wish to prevent anger from ever prevailing so far as to be the cause of dis­ obedience to the laws.
tgt_text.2846: As to those who have passed the age of puberty, and from whom the chief officers of state are chosen, the rest of the Greeks, though they exempt them from the cultivation of their strength, nevertheless require them to serve in the field;
tgt_text.2847: but Lycurgus made it a custom that it should be honourable for persons of that age to engage in hunting, unless any pub­ lic business hindered them, that they might be able, no less than the younger men, to endure the hardships of war.1.
tgt_text.2848: THE employments which Lycurgus appointed for each period of life have now been almost all specified.
tgt_text.2849: What mode of living he instituted for all the citizens, I will next endeavour to explain.
tgt_text.2851: Lycurgus, then, having found the Spartans, like the other Greeks, taking their meals1 at home, and knowing that most were guilty of excess at them, caused their meals to be taken in public, thinking that his regulations would thus be less likely to be transgressed.
tgt_text.2852: 3. He appointed them such a quan­ tity of food, that they should neither be overfed nor feel stinted.
tgt_text.2853: Many extraordinary supplies2 are also furnished from what is caught in hunting, and for these the rich some­ times contribute bread;
tgt_text.2854: 1 so that the table is never without provisions, as long as they design the meal to last, and yet is never expensive.
tgt_text.2856: Having put a stop likewise to all unnecessary drinking, which weakens alike the body and the mind, he gave permis.
tgt_text.2857: sion that every one should drink when he was thirsty, think­ ing that the drink would thus be most innoxious and most pleasant.
tgt_text.2858: When they take their meals together in this man­ ner, how can any one ruin either himself or his family by gluttony or drunkenness ?
tgt_text.2859: 5. In other states, equals in age generally associate together, and with them modesty has but very little influence ;
tgt_text.2860: but Lycurgus, at Sparta, mixed citizens of different ages, so that the younger are for the most part instructed by the experience of the older.
tgt_text.2861: 6. It is a custom at these public meals, that whatever any one has done to his honour in the community is related;
tgt_text.2862: so that insolence, or disorder from intoxication, or any indecency in conduct or language, has there no opportunity of showing itself.
tgt_text.2864: The practice of taking meals away from home is also attended with these advantages, that the people are obliged to walk in taking their departure homewards, and to be careful that they may not stagger from the effects of wine, knowing that they will not remain where they dined, and that they must conduct themselves in the night just as in the day;
tgt_text.2865: for it is not allowable for any one who is still liable to military duty2 to walk with a torch.a.
tgt_text.2866: As Lycurgus observed, too, that those who, after taking food, exercise themselves, become well-complexioned, plump, and robust, while those who are inactive are puffy, unhealthy­ looking, and feeble, he did not neglect to give attention to that point;
tgt_text.2867: and as he perceived that when any one engages in labour from his own inclination, he proves himself to have his body in efficient condition, he ordered that the oldest in each place of exercise should take care that those be­ longing to it should never be overcome by taking too much food.
tgt_text.2868: 1 9. With regard to this matter, he appears to me to have been by no means mistaken;
tgt_text.2869: for no one would easily find men more healthy, or more able-bodied, than the Spar­ tans ;
tgt_text.2870: for they exercise themselves alike in their legs, in their hands, and in their shoulders.
tgt_text.2872: IN the following particulars, also, he made enactments contrary to the usage of most states;
tgt_text.2873: for in other communi­ ties each individual has the control over his own children, and servants, and property;
tgt_text.2874: but Lycurgus, wishing to order things so that the citizens might enjoy some advantage from one another, unattended with any reciprocal injury, ordained that each should have authority not only over.
tgt_text.2875: his own chil­ dren, but over those of others.
tgt_text.2876: 2. But when a person is con­ scious that his fellow-citizens are fathers of the children over whom he.
tgt_text.2877: exercises authority, he must exercise it in such a way as he would wish it to be exercised over his own.
tgt_text.2878: If a boy, on any occasion, receive blows from another boy, and complain of that boy to his father, it is considered dishonour able in the father not to inflict additional blows on his son.
tgt_text.2879: Thus they, trust to one another to impose nothing disgraceful on the children.
tgt_text.2881: He enacted also that a person might use his neighbour's servants, if he had need of them.
tgt_text.2882: He introduced, too, a com­ munity of property in hunting-dogs ;
tgt_text.2883: so that those who re­ quire them call on their owner to hunt, who, if he is not at leisure to hunt himself, cheerfully sends them out.
tgt_text.2884: They use horses also in like manner ;
tgt_text.2885: for whoever is sick, or wants a vehicle, or desires to go to some place speedily, takes posses-.
tgt_text.2886: sion of a horse, if he sees one anywhere, and, after making proper use of it, restores it.
tgt_text.2888: Nor, in regard to the following point, did he allow that that which is customary among other people should be prac­ tised among his countrymen.
tgt_text.2889: For when men, from being overtaken by night in hunting, are in want of provisions, unless they have previously furnished themselves with them, be directed that, in such a case, those who have partaken of what they need, leave the rest ready for use, and that those who require a supply, having opened the seals,1 and taken as much as they want, seal the remainder up again and leave it.
tgt_text.2890: As they share thus, then, with one another, those who possess but little participate, whenever they are in need, in all the produce of the country.i.
tgt_text.2891: THE following practices, too, Lycurgus established in Sparta, at variance with those of the rest of Greece.
tgt_text.2892: In other communities all gain as much by traffic as they can;
tgt_text.2893: one cultivates land, another trades by sea, another engages in general commerce, another maintains himself by art.
tgt_text.2894: 2. But at Sparta, Lycurgus prohibited free men from having any connexion with traffic, and enjoined them to consider as their only occupation whatever secures freedom to states.
tgt_text.2895: 2 3. How, indeed, could wealth be eagerly sought in a community where he had appointed that the citizens should contribute equally to their necessary maintenance, and should take their meals in common, and had thus provided that they should not desire wealth with a view to sensual gratifications ?
tgt_text.2896: Nor had they, moreover, to get money for the sake of clothing;
tgt_text.2897: for they think themselves adorned, not by expensive raiment, but by a healthy personal appearance.
tgt_text.2898: 4. Nor have they to gather money for the purpose of spending it on those who eat with them, since he has made it more honourable for a person to serve his neighbours by bodily exertion, than by putting him­ self to pecuniary expense ;
tgt_text.2899: making it apparent that the one proceeds from the mind, and the other from fortune.
tgt_text.2901: From acquiring money by unjust means, he prohibited them by such methods as the following.
tgt_text.2902: He instituted, in the first place, such a kind of money, that, even if but ten minæ came into a house, it could never escape the notice either of masters or of servants ;
tgt_text.2903: for it would require much room, and a carriage to convey it.
tgt_text.2904: 6. In the next place, gold and silver are searched after, and, if they are discovered anywhere, the possessor of them is punished.
tgt_text.2905: How, then, could gain by traffic be an object of pursuit, in a state where the possession of money occasions more pain than the use of it affords pleasure ?I. THAT at Sparta the citizens pay the strictest obedience to the magistrates and laws, we all know.
tgt_text.2906: I suppose, how­ ever, that Lycurgus did not attempt to establish such an ex­ cellent order of things, until he had brought the most power­ ful men in the state to be of the same mind with regard to it.
tgt_text.2907: 2. I form my opinion on this consideration, that, in other states, the more influential men are not willing even to appear to fear the magistrates, but think that such fear is unbecoming free men ;
tgt_text.2908: but in Sparta, the most powerful men not only put themselves under the magistrates, but even count it an honour , to humble themselves before them, and to obey, when they are called upon, not walking, but running;
tgt_text.2909: supposing that if they themselves are the first to pay exact obedience, others will follow their example;
tgt_text.2910: and such has been the case.
tgt_text.2912: It is probable, also, that the chief men established the magistracy of the Ephori, in conjunction with Lycurgus, as they must have been certain that obedience is of the greatest benefit, alike in a state, and in an army, and in a family;
tgt_text.2913: and they doubtless considered that the greater power magistrates have, the great­ er effect will they produce on the citizens in enforcing obedi­ ence.
tgt_text.2914: 1 4. The Ephori, accordingly, have full power to im­ pose a fine on whomsoever they please, and to exact the fine without delay;
tgt_text.2915: they have power also to degrade magistrates even while they are in office, and to put them in prison, and to bring them to trial for their life.
tgt_text.2916: Being possessed of such authority, they do not, like the magistrates in other states, always permit those who are elected to offices to rule during the whole year as they choose, but, like despots and presid­ ents in gymnastic contests, punish on the instant whomsoever they find acting at all contrary to the laws.
tgt_text.2918: Though there were many other excellent contrivances adopted by Lycurgus, to induce the citizens to obey the laws, the most excellent of all appears to me to be, that he did not deliver his laws to the people until he had gone, in company with the most eminent of his fellow-citizens, to Delphi, and consulted the god whether it would be more beneficial and advantageous for Sparta to obey the laws which he had made.
tgt_text.2919: As the god replied that it would be more beneficial in every way, he at once delivered them, deciding that it would be not only illegal, but impious, to disobey laws sane­ ioned by the oracle.i.
tgt_text.2920: IT is deserving of admiration, too, in Lycurgus, that he made it a settled principle in the community, that an honour­ able death is preferable to a dishonourable life;
tgt_text.2921: for whoever pays attention to the subject will find that fewer of those who hold this opinion die, than of those who attempt to escape danger by flight.
tgt_text.2922: 2. Hence we may say with truth, thai safety attends for a much longer period on valour than on cowardice;
tgt_text.2923: for valour is not only attended with less anxiety and greater pleasure, but is also more capable of assisting and sup­ porting us.
tgt_text.2924: It is evident, too, that good report accompanies valour ;
tgt_text.2925: for almost everybody is willing to be in alliance with the brave.
tgt_text.2927: How he contrived that such sentiments should be enter­ tained, it is proper not to omit to mention.
tgt_text.2928: He evidently, then, intended a happy life for the brave, and a miserable one for the cowardly.
tgt_text.2929: 4. In other communities, when a man acts as a coward, he merely brings on himself the name of coward, but the coward goes to the same market, and sits or takes exercise, if he pleases, in the same place with the brave man;
tgt_text.2930: at Lacedæmon, however, every one would be ashamed to ad­ mit a coward into the same tent with him, or to allow him to be his opponent in a match at wrestling.
tgt_text.2931: Frequently, too, a person of such a character, when they choose opposite parties to play at.
tgt_text.2932: ball, is left without any place;
tgt_text.2933: and in forming a chorus he is thrust into the least honourable position.
tgt_text.2934: On the road he must yield the way to others, and at public meet­ ings he must rise up, even before his juniors.
tgt_text.2935: His female relatives1 he must maintain at hornet and they must pay the penalty of his want of spirit ;
tgt_text.2936: 3 he is also not allowed to have his hearth without a wife, and must at, the same time pay a Sne for being in that condition.
tgt_text.2938: He must not walk abroad anointed,2 or imitate the manners of persons of blameless character ;
tgt_text.2939: else he will have to receive stripes from his betters.
tgt_text.2940: Since, then, such disgrace is inflicted on cowards, I do not at all wonder that death is preferred at Sparta to a life so dis­ honourable and infamous.
tgt_text.2942: LYCURGUS seems to me to have provided also, with great judgment, how virtue might be practised even to old age;
tgt_text.2943: for by adding to his other enactments the choice of senators3 at an advanced stage of life, he caused honour and virtue not to be disregarded even in old age.2.
tgt_text.2944: It is worthy of admiration in him, too, that he attached consideration to the old age of the well-deserving;
tgt_text.2945: for by making the old men arbiters in the contest for superiority in mental qualifications, he rendered their old age more honour­ able than the vigour of those in the meridian of life.
tgt_text.2946: 3. This contest is deservedly held in the greatest esteem among the people, for gymnastic contests are attended with honour, but they concern only bodily accomplishments;
tgt_text.2947: the contest for dis­ tinction in old age involves a decision respecting merits of the mind.
tgt_text.2948: In proportion, therefore, as the mind is superior to the body, so much are contests for mental eminence more worthy of regard than those concerning bodily superiority.
tgt_text.2950: Is it not highly worthy of admiration, also, in Lycurgus, that when he saw that those who are disinclined1 to practise virtue are not qualified to increase the power of their country, he obliged all the citizens of Sparta to cultivate every kind of virtue publicly.
tgt_text.2951: As private individuals, accordingly, who practise virtue, are superior in it to those who neglect it, so Sparta is naturally superior in virtue to all other states, as it is the only one that engages in a public cultivation of honour and virtue.
tgt_text.2952: 5. Is it not also deserving of commendation, that, when other states punish any person that injures another, Lycurgus inflicted no less punishment on any one that openly showed himself regardless of becoming as good a man as pos­ sible?
tgt_text.2953: 6. He thought, as it appears, that by those who make others slaves, or rob them, or steal anything, the individual sufferers only are injured, but that by the unprincipled and cowardly whole communities are betrayed;
tgt_text.2954: so that he appears to me to have justly imposed the heaviest penalties on such characters.
tgt_text.2956: He also imposed on his countrymen an obligation, from which there is no exception, of practising every kind of poli­ tical virtue;
tgt_text.2957: for he made the privileges of citizenship equally available to all those who observed what was enjoined by the laws, without taking any account either of weakness of body or scantiness of means;
tgt_text.2958: but if any one was too indolent to perform what the laws prescribed, Lycurgus appointed that he should be no longer counted in the number of equally pri­ vileged citizens.
tgt_text.2960: That these laws are extremely ancient is certain;
tgt_text.2961: for Lycurgus is said to have lived in the time of the Heracleidæ;
tgt_text.2962: 2 but, ancient as they are, they are still very new to other corn- munities;
tgt_text.2963: for, what is the most wonderful of all things, all men extol such institutions, but no state thinks proper to imi­ tate them.
tgt_text.2965: THE regulations which I have mentioned are beneficial alike in peace and in war;
tgt_text.2966: but if any one wishes to learn what he contrived better than other legislators with reference to military proceedings, he may attend to the following par­ ticulars.
tgt_text.2968: In the first place, then, the Ephori give the cavalry and infantry public notice of the years during which they must join the army, as well as the artisans;
tgt_text.2969: for the Lacedæmonians provide themselves in the field with an abundance of all those things which people use in a city;
tgt_text.2970: and of whatever instru­ ments1 an army may require in common, orders are given to bring some on waggons, and others on beasts of burden, as by this arrangement anything left behind is least likely to escape notice.
tgt_text.2972: For engagements in the field he made the following ar­ rangements.
tgt_text.2973: He ordered that each soldier should have a purple robe and a brazen shield;
tgt_text.2974: for he thought that such a dress had least resemblance to that of women, and was excel­ lently adapted for the field of battle, as it is soonest made splendid, and is longest in growing soiled.
tgt_text.2975: He permitted also those above the age of puberty to let their hair grow, as he thought that they thus appeared taller, more manly, and more terrible in the eyes of the enemy.
tgt_text.2977: When they were thus equipped, he divided them into six moræ2 of cavalry and heavy-armed infantry.
tgt_text.2978: Each of these morae of the citizens1 has one polemarch, four centurions, eight captains of fifty, and sixteen enomotarchs.
tgt_text.2980: The men of these moræ are sometimes, according to the command issued, formed in enomotiæ, sometimes by threes, sometimes by sixes.
tgt_text.2982: 5. As to what most people imagine, that the arrangement of the Lacedæmonians under arms is extremely complex, they conceive the exact contrary to what is the fact;
tgt_text.2983: for in the Lacedæmonian order the officers are placed in the front ranks, and each rank is in a condition to perform everything which it is necessary for it to perform.
tgt_text.2985: 6. So easy is it to under­ stand this arrangement, that no one, who can distinguish one man from another, would fail of learning it;
tgt_text.2986: for it is assigned to some to lead, and enjoined on others to follow.
tgt_text.2987: Shiftings of place, by which the companies are extended or deepened, are ordered by the word of the enomotarch, as by a herald;
tgt_text.2988: and in these there is nothing in the least difficult to learn.
tgt_text.2989: 7. But how it is possible for men in this arrangement, even if they are thrown, into confusion, to fight with an enemy pre­ senting themselves on any quarter alike, it is not so easy to understand, except for those who have been brought up under the institution of Lycurgus.
tgt_text.2990: 8. The Lacedæmonians do with the greatest ease what appears extremely difficult to other men that are even accustomed to arms.
tgt_text.2991: For when they march in column, one enomotia follows in the rear of another and if, when they are in this order, a body of the enemy shows itself in front, orders are given to each enomotarch to bring up his enomotia to the front on the left;
tgt_text.2992: and this movement is made throughout the whole army, until it presents itself in full array against the enemy.
tgt_text.2993: But if again, while they are in this order, the enemy should show themselves in the rear, each rank performs an evolution,2 that the strongest3 may always be presented to the enemy.
tgt_text.2995: But when the commander is on the left, they do not in that case consider themselves in a worse condition, but sometimes even in a better;
tgt_text.2996: for if an enemy should attempt to encompass them, he would come round, not on the defence­ less, but on the armed side.
tgt_text.2997: If on any occasion, again, it should appear advantageous, for any particular object, that the commander should occupy the right wing, they wheel the troop towards the wing, and manœuvre4 the main body, until the commander is on the right, and the rear becomes the left.
tgt_text.2998: 10. But if, again, a body of the enemy appear on the right, marching in column, they do nothing else but turn each cen­ tury round, like a ship, so as to front the enemy ;
tgt_text.2999: and thus the century which was in the rear comes to the right.
tgt_text.3000: But if the enemy approach on the left, they do not allow them to come near, but repulse them, or turn their centuries round to face the enemy;
tgt_text.3001: and thus again the century that was in the rear takes its place on the left.
tgt_text.3003: I WILL also explain how Lycurgus directed that a camp should be pitched.
tgt_text.3004: As the angles of a quadrilateral figure are useless, he formed the encampment in a circle, unless there happened to be a mountain to protect it, or unless the troops kept a wall or a river behind them.
tgt_text.3005: 2. He appointed guards during the day, some close by the camp, looking into it;
tgt_text.3006: 1 for these are stationed with reference, not to the ene­ my, but to their own friends ;
tgt_text.3007: 2 as for the enemy, cavalry watch their approach from posts from which they command the farthest view.
tgt_text.3008: 3. If any went out of the camp3 at night, he directed that they should be watched by the Sciritæ ;
tgt_text.3009: 4 a duty which is now performed by the mercenary troops, [ifj any of them [happen]5 to be with the army.
tgt_text.3010: As to their custom of always going about with spears,6 we may know for certain that it is observed for the same reason for which they always prohibit slaves from entering the army.
tgt_text.3011: That those who retire on necessary occasions do not withdraw farther from one another or from the camp than just to such a distance as will not cause each other uneasiness, must not excite sur­ prise in us;
tgt_text.3012: for they observe such caution for self-preserva­ tion.
tgt_text.3014: They change the position of their camp frequently, with the view both of doing damage to their enemies and of serving their friends.
tgt_text.3015: It is prescribed by law that all the Lacedæ­ monians are to practise gymnastic exercises whenever they are in the field;
tgt_text.3016: 1 and they thus acquire a finer appearance than they had before, and a more manly air than other men.
tgt_text.3017: But the space for walking or running must be made not less, [and not much greater,]2 than the space over which a mora would extend,3 in order that no one may go far away from his arms.
tgt_text.3018: 6. When the exercises are concluded, the first polemarch gives orders for them to sit down;
tgt_text.3019: this serves the purpose of a review ;
tgt_text.3020: he then orders them to take their break­ fast, and soon after to relieve the advanced sentinel.
tgt_text.3022: The men then amuse themselves and take rest previously to the evening exercises.
tgt_text.3023: 8. After these, orders are issued that they may take supper, and that, when they have sung a hymn to the gods, from whom they have had favourable omens when sacrificing, they may repose themselves on their arms.
tgt_text.3024: That I specify many particulars, no one ought to be sur­ prised ;
tgt_text.3025: for an observer will find very few things that require care omitted by the Lacedæmonians in their military regula­ tions.
tgt_text.3027: I WILL also relate what power and honour Lycurgus has assigned to the king when he is with the army.
tgt_text.3028: In the first place, the state supports the king on an expedition, and those who attend on him;
tgt_text.3029: and the polemarchs pitch their tents close by him, that, being always at hand, they may be the bet.
tgt_text.3030: ter able to take counsel with him, if they require to do so.
tgt_text.3031: Three others, also, of the equally privileged citizens pitch their tents with him;
tgt_text.3032: and these attend to all the provisions for the rest,1 that no business of that kind may prevent them from attending to military affairs.a.
tgt_text.3033: But I will go back to describe how the king sets forth with the army.
tgt_text.3034: He first sacrifices, while still at home, to Jupiter and the gods with him,2 and if the omens there be favourable, the fire-bearer,3 taking fire from the altar, leads the way to the confines of the country, when the king again sacrifices.
tgt_text.3036: 3. When favourable omens have been obtained from both these deities, he then crosses the boundaries of the country;
tgt_text.3037: and the fire from these sacrifices is carried before him, never being extinguished, and all kinds of victims5 are taken with him.
tgt_text.3038: But whenever sacrifice is offered, he always commences that duty before daybreak, wishing to be the earliest to gain the good­ will6 of the god.
tgt_text.3040: 4. There are present at the sacrifice, the polemarchs, the centurions, the captains of fifties, the. officers of the mercenaries, the captains of the baggage-troop, and any one of the military commanders from the towns1 that chooses.
tgt_text.3041: 5. There are present, also, two of the ephori, who, however, take no active part in the proceedings, unless the king calls upon them;
tgt_text.3042: but, as they observe what every one does, they render the whole company, as is to be expected, more solemn in their deportment.
tgt_text.3043: When the sacrifice is concluded, the king, calling all the officers around him, gives directions as to what is to be done ;
tgt_text.3044: 2 so that, if you watched all these proceed­ ings attentively, you would think that other nations engaged in military operations without premeditation, and that the Lacedæmonians were the only people really skilled in the con­ duct of war.6.
tgt_text.3045: If, when the king commences his march, no enemy ap­ pears, no one goes before him except the Sciritæ and the cavalry ordered to reconnoitre;
tgt_text.3046: but if they expect that a battle will ensue, the king, taking the foremost troop3 of the first mora, and wheeling it round, leads it off to the right, until he reaches the space between two morse and two polemarchs.
tgt_text.3048: 7. Those who are to be stationed next to these, the eldest of the attendants on the royal tent5 draws up;
tgt_text.3049: and these are such of the equally privileged citizens as pitch their tents to­ gether, as well as the augurs, the physicians, the officers of the army,6 and the volunteers, if there be any.
tgt_text.3050: Thus no part of what is necessary to be done is attended with any difficulty;
tgt_text.3051: for everything has been previously considered.
tgt_text.3053: The following particulars, too, as it appears to me, Lycurgus ordered with great advantage in regard to contests in arms.
tgt_text.3054: When a goat is sacrificed,7 the enemy being in sight, it is the custom that all the flute-players who are in attendance play on their flutes, and that every one of the Lacedæmonians wear a chaplet;
tgt_text.3055: and notice is given that the arms be made bright.
tgt_text.3056: It is expected of the youth to engage in battle with their hair combed,l and with a cheerful look and fair appearance.
tgt_text.3057: 9. They also call out the orders to the enomotarch ;
tgt_text.3058: for the voice cannot reach along the whole of each enomotia from each enomotarch at the extremity;
tgt_text.3059: but to see that all is properly done is the business of the polemarch.
tgt_text.3061: As to the time when it may seem proper to pitch the camp, the king has the direction, as well as the power of pointing out the place where it must be pitched.
tgt_text.3062: To the king it also belongs to send embassies, either to friends or enemies.
tgt_text.3063: Every one, indeed, when he wishes to do anything of consequence, begins by consulting the king.
tgt_text.3064: 11. If any one comes seeking justice, the king refers him to the Hellanodicae ;
tgt_text.3066: if he brings in spoil, to the sellers of the spoil.
tgt_text.3067: Things being thus ordered, no other duty is left for the king in the field, than to act as priest in what regards the gods, and as general in what con­ cerns men.1.
tgt_text.3068: 3[IF any one should ask me, whether the laws of Lycur­ gus appear to me to continue even at the present time intact I could certainly no longer reply with confidence in the af­ firmative.
tgt_text.3070: For I know that the Lacedæmonians formerly preferred to associate together at home, though with moderate means, rather than to grow corrupt by governing foreign cities, and listening to flatterers.
tgt_text.3071: 3. I know that they were formerly afraid to let it be known that they were possessed of gold;
tgt_text.3072: but some a< present, I am aware, are ostentatious of possessing it.
tgt_text.3073: 4. I know that for this reason strangers were formerly.
tgt_text.3074: banished from Sparta, and that citizens were not allowed to reside abroad, lest they should be initiated in licen­ tiousness by foreigners;
tgt_text.3075: but now I know, that those who are thought the chief men among them have shown the utmost eagerness to be constantly engaged in governing some foreign city.
tgt_text.3076: 5. There was a time, too, when they made it their study to render themselves worthy to be governors;
tgt_text.3077: but now they use far more exertion to obtain rule, than to prove them­ selves deserving of it.
tgt_text.3078: 6. Hence the Greeks formerly used to resort to Lacedæmon, and request them to be their leaders against those who were convicted of doing wrong;
tgt_text.3079: but now many of the Greeks exhort one another to prevent them.
tgt_text.3080: from ever again taking the lead.
tgt_text.3081: 7. Yet we must not feel surprised that such reproach is thrown upon them, since they evidently show themselves neither obedient to the deity,1 nor to the laws of Lycurgus.]1. I WISH, also, to state what compact Lycurgus instituted between the king and the state;
tgt_text.3082: for this is the only govern­ ment that continues just as it was established at the very be­ ginning;
tgt_text.3083: other constitutions we may find either changed, or at present undergoing change.a.
tgt_text.3084: Lycurgus, then, appointed that the king should offer all the public sacrifices on behalf of the state, as being descended from Jupiter, and that he should command the army wherever the state should think proper to send it.
tgt_text.3085: 3. He allowed the king also to receive an honorary portion of the sacrifices offer­ ed, and appointed him choice portions of land in the territory of many of the neighbouring towns, of such an extent that he might neither be in want of moderate means, nor be possessed of extravagant wealth.
tgt_text.3086: 4. That the kings might take their meals1 in a tent away from home, too, he assigned them a public tent, and honoured them with a double portion at din­ ner, not that they might eat twice as much as others, but that they might have it in their power to honour whomsoever they pleased with a part of it.
tgt_text.3087: 5. He permitted also each of the kings to choose for himself two tent-companions, whom they call Pythii.
tgt_text.3088: He allowed the king, too, to take a pig from the brood of every sow, that he might never be in want of victims, if it should be necessary for him to consult the gods.
tgt_text.3089: 6. Near the palace, a lake affords abundance of water;
tgt_text.3090: and that such a supply is useful for many purposes, those who are without it know extremely well.
tgt_text.3091: All rise up from their seats before the king, except the ephori from their seats of office.
tgt_text.3092: 7. They take an oath to each other every month, the ephori for the state, and the king for himself.
tgt_text.3093: The oath on the part of the king is, that he will govern according to the existing laws of the state ;
tgt_text.3094: the oath on the part of the state is, that if the king adheres to his word, they will preserve his kingdom unshaken.
tgt_text.3096: Such are the honours that are granted to the king in his native land, while living, honours not far exceeding those that are paid to private individuals;
tgt_text.3097: for Lycurgus did not wish to excite a tyrannical spirit in the kings, or to inspire the citi­ zens with envy of their power.
tgt_text.3098: 9. As to the honours which are paid to a king when dead, the laws of Lycurgus wish to show by them that they have honoured the kings of the La­ cedæmonians, not as men, but as heroes.
tgt_text.3100: As to the government of the Athenians,l I do not com­ mend them for having chosen that form of government, for this reason, that, by making such a choice, they chose that the lower class should be in a better condition than the upper ;
tgt_text.3101: for this reason, then, I say, I do not commend them;
tgt_text.3102: but I will show that, since this state of things has been adopted by them, they support their constitution well, and successfully transact other things in which they appear to the rest of the Greeks to be in error.2.
tgt_text.3103: I shall observe, then, in the first place, that in such a con­ stitution the poor and the plebeian have deservedly greater in­ fluence than the well-born and the rich;
tgt_text.3104: because it is the plebeians that manage the shipping, and that in consequence increase the power of the state ;
tgt_text.3105: for the pilots and celeustae,2 and captains of fifty rowers, and forecastle-men,1 and ship­ builders, are those who add strength to the community far more than the noble and better class of citizens.
tgt_text.3106: Since such is the case, therefore, it seems to be but just that all of them should have a voice concerning the offices of state, whether the election to them be by lot or by show of hands, and that every one of the citizens who wishes should have liberty to speak.
tgt_text.3108: In those offices, however, which, from being efficiently or inefficiently held, cause safety or peril to the whole common­ wealth, the people have no desire to participate ;
tgt_text.3109: they do not expect to be admitted to the office of commander-in-chief or of general of the cavalry;
tgt_text.3110: for they are sensible that they are more benefited by not taking upon themselves such offices, but allowing the most influential2 of the citizens to hold them ;
tgt_text.3111: but whatever posts are held for pay,3 or attended with benefit to their families, these the people try to gain.
tgt_text.3113: In the very fact, too, at which some wonder, that they everywhere give more weight to the less respectable, the poor, and the plebeians, than to those of a higher class, they will but prove that they uphold their democratic form of govern­ ment ;
tgt_text.3114: for if the humble, the men of the people, and the lower orders prosper and increase in number, they add to the po­ pular power ;
tgt_text.3115: but if the wealthier and higher classes are ad­ vanced in prosperity, the plebeians establish in authority a party opposed to themselves.
tgt_text.3116: 5. In every country, indeed, the better class of the people is adverse to a democracy ;
tgt_text.3117: for in the most respectable portion of a community there is the least licentiousness and injustice, and the strictest regard to honesty ;
tgt_text.3118: but among the plebeians the greatest ignorance, in­ subordination, and vice ;
tgt_text.3119: for poverty leads them much more to dishonourable practices, and to some men want of instruc­ tion and knowledge, in consequence of the want of money... 46.
tgt_text.3120: Some person may perhaps remark, that they should not have allowed all men without distinction to speak in public, and offer advice, but only those of the greatest ability and of the highest character ;
tgt_text.3121: but even in this respect they act with excellent judgment, by permitting even the mean to speak ;
tgt_text.3122: for if the highest class only made speeches and offered their opinions, what they say might be of advantage to.
tgt_text.3123: men like themselves, but of no advantage to the plebeians ;
tgt_text.3124: but now, even the lowest individual of the people, standing up to speak if he pleases, can bring to light something that may be bene­ ficial both to himself and to his equals.
tgt_text.3125: 7. Some one might ask, " What measure can such a man devise that is likely to be beneficial either to himself or to the people ?
tgt_text.3126: " but the Atheni­ ans know that his imperfect knowledge and humble views, if attended with benevolence, are more likely to profit the com­ munity than the talents and wisdom of the higher character, if accompanied with dishonest intentions.
tgt_text.3128: Under such modes of proceeding the constitution may not be the very best, but the democratic form of government will thus be excellently preserved ;
tgt_text.3129: for the peopleare by no means desirous, while the state is well regulated, to be them­ selves slaves, but to be free and to govern.
tgt_text.3130: If the govern­ ment is bad, they care but little ;
tgt_text.3131: for, from that which you think a bad condition of government, the people gain both strength and freedom.
tgt_text.3132: 9. But if you want a really good government, you must first see the wisest men make laws for the people ;
tgt_text.3133: and then the good must punish the bad, and con.
tgt_text.3134: suIt for the interests of the commonwealth, and not allow fellows like madmen1 to offer counsel, and harangue and address the public assemblies.
tgt_text.3135: In such an excellent state of things, how­ ever, the plebeians would soon fall into servitude.
tgt_text.3137: The licence allowed to slaves and sojourners at Athens is very great;
tgt_text.3138: it is not allowable to strike them, nor will the slave yield you the way.
tgt_text.3139: For what reason this custom is suffered to prevail in the country, I will tell you.
tgt_text.3140: Le it were usual for the slave, or the sojourner, or the freed man to be beaten by the free citizen, he would often strike an Athenian born, imagining him to be a slave ;
tgt_text.3141: for the people of the city wear no better dress than slaves or so.
tgt_text.3142: journers, nor are they at all superior in personal appear ance.
tgt_text.3143: 11. Yet if any one feels surprised that they permit their slaves to fare luxuriously, and some of them to live even magnificently, they may be shown to act even in this respect with judgment;
tgt_text.3144: for where a naval power exists, it is neces­ sary, from pecuniary considerations, to humour the slaves,1 Ithat we may receive the profit from the work which they per­ form,2 and to indulge them in a liberal way of living;
tgt_text.3145: a but where the slaves are rich, it is no longer expedient that my slave should fear you;
tgt_text.3146: (at Lacedæmon, indeed, my slave fears you ;
tgt_text.3147: ) since, if your slave fears me, he will be likely to sacrifice what is in his possession,4 in order to escape danger to his person.
tgt_text.3148: 12. On this account, accordingly, we have granted to slaves a certain equality 5 with the free, as well as to sojourners with the citizens ;
tgt_text.3149: for the state has need of so­ journers, through the great number of trades, and for the ser­ vice of the fleet.
tgt_text.3151: The people have ceased to tolerate those who practise gymnastic exercises 6 and cultivate music, thinking that such pursuits do not become them, and knowing that the lower class are not competent to study such arts.
tgt_text.3152: In the furnishing of choruses, as well as in the government of the gymnasia, and the equipment of triremes, they are aware not only that the rich furnish the expense for the choruses, while the lower class of people enjoy the pleasure of them, but that the rich also supply triremes, and preside over the gymnasia, while the poor have the benefit of both ;
tgt_text.3153: the plebeians are accordingly ready to take money for singing, and running, and dancing, and serving in the galleys, that they themselves may have some advantage, and that the rich may become poorer.
tgt_text.3155: As to proceedings in courts of law, they have less re­ gard to what is just, than to what is profitable to themselves.:
tgt_text.3156: As to their allies, those who are sent from Athens over the sea to them calumniate the more respectable class, as it appears, and manifest dislike for them, knowing that the governors must necessarily be hated by the governed ;
tgt_text.3157: and if ever, in­ deed, the rich and influential secure power in the states, the government of the people of Athens will be but of very short duration.
tgt_text.3158: On these accounts, accordingly, they degrade the better sort of people, take away their property, banish them, and put them to death, but increase the influence of the lower orders.
tgt_text.3159: The more honourable of the Athenians, how­ ever, protect the respectable inhabitants in the allied states, being aware that it is for their advantage always to support the aristocracy in those communities.is.
tgt_text.3160: Some person might say, that it is a great support to the Athenians that their allies should be in a condition to con­ tribute money to them.
tgt_text.3161: To the plebeians, however, it seems to be of much greater advantage that every individual of the Athenians should get some of the property of the allies, and that the allies themselves should have only so much as to en-I able them to live and to till the ground,2 so that they may not be in a condition to form conspiracies.
tgt_text.3163: The people of Athens seem also to have acted injudi­ ciously in this respect, that they oblige their allies to make voyages to Athens for the decision of their lawsuits.
tgt_text.3164: But the Athenians consider only, on the other hand, what benefits to the state of Athens are attendant on this practice;
tgt_text.3165: in the first place, they receive their dues throughout the year from the prytaneia ;
tgt_text.3166: 1 in the next place, they manage the govern­ ment of the allied states while sitting at home, and without sending out ships ;
tgt_text.3167: they also support suitors of the lower or­ ders, and ruin those of an opposite character, in their courts of law;
tgt_text.3168: but if each state had its own courts, they would, as being hostile to the Athenians, be the ruin of those who were most favourable to the people of Athens.
tgt_text.3169: 17. In addition to these advantages, the Athenian people have the following pro­ fits from the courts of justice for the allies being at Athens ;
tgt_text.3170: first of all, the duty of the hundredth2 on what is landed at the Peiræeus affords a greater revenue to the city;
tgt_text.3171: next, who­ ever has a lodging-house makes more money by it, as well 'as whoever has cattle or slaves for hire;
tgt_text.3172: and the heralds, too, are benefited by the visits of the allies to the city.
tgt_text.3173: 18. Be­ sides, if the allies did not come to Athens for Jaw, they would honour only such of the Athenians as were sent over the sea to them, as generals, and captains of vessels, and ambassa­ dors ;
tgt_text.3174: but now every individual of the allies is obliged to flat­ ter the people of Athens, knowing that on going to Athens he must gain or lose his cause according to the decision, not of other judges, but of the people,3 as is the law of Athens;
tgt_text.3175: and he is compelled, too, to use supplication before the court, and, as any one of the people enters, to take him by the hand.
tgt_text.3176: By these means the allies are in consequence rendered much more the slaves of the Athenian people.
tgt_text.3178: Moreover, from the possessions which they hold, and the governments which they administer, beyond the borders of their country, the Athenians themselves and their followers learn almost imperceptibly to row;
tgt_text.3179: for a man who is often at sea must himself, as well as his attendants, take the oar in hand ;
tgt_text.3180: and he will necessarily learn also the names of every­ thing used in the management of vessels.
tgt_text.3181: 20. They become good pilots, likewise, as well through the experience gained in their voyages, as through exercise;
tgt_text.3182: for some practise them- selves in steering a small vessel, others a transport ship, and others pass from these to the galleys.
tgt_text.3183: The bulk of the people, indeed, are able to row as soon as they go on board, from having given their attention to rowing all their lives.
tgt_text.3185: THEIR land forces,l which appear to be by no means in good condition at Athens, may be thus characterized.
tgt_text.3186: They consider themselves to be weaker in this department, and to have fewer troops, than their enemies ;
tgt_text.3187: but they are superior by land to their allies, who pay them tribute ;
tgt_text.3188: and they think that their land force, if they maintain by its aid a superiority over their allies, is sufficient.
tgt_text.3190: From fortune, too, they have some such advantage as the following.
tgt_text.3191: It would be possible for their subjects, if they dwelt on the mainland, to collect themselves together from small towns, and take the field in a large body;
tgt_text.3192: but as to those who are ruled by sea, such as islanders, it is impossible for their towns to unite their strength;
tgt_text.3193: for the sea lies be­ tween them, and their rulers are masters of the sea;
tgt_text.3194: and if it were practicable for the islanders to come together secretly into one island, they would perish of famine.
tgt_text.3195: 3. Whatever cities, moreover, are subject to the Athenians on the continent, the larger of them are kept in subordination through fear, and the smaller through necessity ;
tgt_text.3196: for there is no city that does not require to import or export commodities;
tgt_text.3197: and this will be out of its power, unless it be obedient to those who have the mastery at sea.
tgt_text.3198: 4. It is possible, also, for the mas- ters of the sea to do what is impracticable to those who are masters of the land only ;
tgt_text.3199: for instance, to ravage at times the lands even of the more powerful;
tgt_text.3200: since they can make a de­ scent on the coast, where there are either no enemies or but few, and, if a force come against them, can reëmbark and sail away;
tgt_text.3201: and those who do this find fewer difficulties than those who make attacks with a land army.
tgt_text.3203: Those who have the ascendency at sea, moreover, can , sail as far from their own country as they please ;
tgt_text.3204: while those who rule on land can march but a very few days' journey from home;
tgt_text.3205: for marches are slow, and it is impossible for those who go by land to carry provisions sufficient for any considerable length of time.
tgt_text.3206: He that goes by land, too, must either go through a friendly country, or make his way by fighting;
tgt_text.3207: but he who goes by sea may disembark wherever he is stronger, and, when he is weaker, may sail along the coast of the country until he reaches the territories either of a friendly or of an inferior nation.
tgt_text.3208: 6. Those again who are power­ ful by land cannot easily bear blights of the crops, which proceed from Jupiter ;
tgt_text.3209: but the rulers of the sea can endure them with ease;
tgt_text.3210: for the whole of a country does not suffer at the same time;
tgt_text.3211: so that provisions come to the rulers of the sea from that ground which is in good condition.
tgt_text.3213: If we may allude, in addition, to some smaller advan­ tages, the Athenians, through their intercourse with other na­ tions, in consequence of their maritime ascendency, have dis­ covered various sorts of luxuries;
tgt_text.3214: since whatever is attractive in Sicily, or Italy, or Cyprus, or Egypt, or Lydia, or Pontus, or the Peloponnesus, or anywhere else, may be collected into one spot through enjoying the command of the sea.
tgt_text.3215: 8. Hear­ ing all kinds of languages spoken, too, they have selected different words from each.
tgt_text.3216: The rest of the Greeks have each a peculiar language and mode of living and dress, but the Athenians have adopted a mixture of fashions from Greeks and barbarians.
tgt_text.3218: As to sacrifices, and temples, and festivals, and conse­ crated groves, the people, knowing that it is impossible for every poor man to make offerings and feasts, and have temples, and to live in a beautiful and extensive city,1 have discovered by what means these privileges may be secured to them.
tgt_text.3219: The state accordingly sacrifices many victims at the public expense, while it is the people that feast on them, and distri­ bute them among themselves by lot.
tgt_text.3220: 10. Some of the rich, indeed, have private places of exercise, and baths, and un dressing-rooms;
tgt_text.3221: but the people construct for their own especial use many wrestling-grounds, and dressing-places, and baths;
tgt_text.3222: and the vulgar have more enjoyment from them than the few and the wealthy.
tgt_text.3224: The Athenians are the only nation among Greeks and barbarians that can secure wealth ;
tgt_text.3225: for if any state is rich in timber for ship-building, where shall they dispose of it, unless they gain the favour of the rulers of the sea ?
tgt_text.3226: Or if any state abounds in iron, or brass, or flax, where shall they dis­ pose of it, unless they obtain the consent of the lords of the aea ?
tgt_text.3227: It is, however, from these very materials that our ships are constructed ;
tgt_text.3228: for from one nation comes timber, from an­ other iron, from another brass, from another hemp, from an­ other wax.
tgt_text.3229: 12. Besides, such as are our rivals will not allow people to carry these things to any other parts than where they themselves command the sea.
tgt_text.3231: I, without labour, have all these benefits from the land by means of the sea ;
tgt_text.3232: and no other state has any two of these materials;
tgt_text.3233: for the same state has not timber and flax, since, where there is abundance of flax, the ground is level and woodless ;
tgt_text.3234: nor do brass and iron come from the same state;
tgt_text.3235: nor are any two or three other commodities found in the same state, but one state abounds in one, and another in another.
tgt_text.3237: Besides, there is near every part of the mainland either a projecting shore, or an island lying on the coast, or an isthmus, so that those who have the command of the sea may make a descent there, and do injury to the inhabitants of the, continent. *14. But there is one particular in which they lie under a disadvantage;
tgt_text.3238: for if the Athenians inhabited an island and were lords of the sea, they would have it in their power to do mischief to others if they pleased, and would suffer no injury from others, as long as they maintained their superiority at sea;
tgt_text.3239: nor would their land be ravaged, nor would they fear the approach of an enemy.
tgt_text.3240: But at present the husband­ men, and the richer citizens in Athens, are greatly in fear of enemies;
tgt_text.3241: though the lower order, being well aware that an enemy will burn or devastate nothing belonging to them, live in security, and without any apprehension of an enemy, is.
tgt_text.3242: In addition to this, theywould have been free from another cause of fear, if they had inhabited an island;
tgt_text.3243: for they would never have dreaded that their city might be betrayed, or their gates set open, or an enemy let in upon them by a small faction;
tgt_text.3244: (for how could such things have happened when they dwelt in an island ?) nor, had they been islanders, would they have had seditions among the people ;
tgt_text.3245: for if the people were to raise a sedition at present, they would raise it from trust­ ing in an enemy, with the expectation of bringing them into the city by land;
tgt_text.3246: but if they were all islanders, they would be free from apprehension on that point.
tgt_text.3247: 16. Since, however, they have not dwelt in an island from the beginning, their practice now is to deposit their property in the islands, trust­ ing to their power by sea, and allow the lands of Attica to be ravaged,1 knowing that, if they concerned themselves for their territory, they would lose other things of greater im­ portance.
tgt_text.3249: It is necessary for states governed by an oligarchy to pay strict adherence to alliances and treaties ;
tgt_text.3250: and if they do not keep their engagements, by whom else can it be sup­ posed that faith is broken, but by those who made those en­ gagements ?
tgt_text.3252: But in regard to engagements which the people make, it is possible for any one 3 laying the blame on the indi- vidual who proposed the measure, and put it to the vote, to declare to every one else that he was not present, and that what was settled by no means pleased him ;
tgt_text.3253: they examine into the matter in a full assembly of the people, and if it does not please them that the measure in question should be car­ ried into effect, they find innumerable pretexts for not doing what they do not wish.
tgt_text.3254: And if any harm results from what the people have decreed, they complain that a few individuals, adverse to the popular interests, have mismanaged the mat­ ter ;
tgt_text.3255: if any good is the consequence, they claim the credit to themselves.
tgt_text.3257: The authorities do not allow jesting on the people in comedies, or defaming them, lest they themselves be slan­ dered ;
tgt_text.3258: but privately, if a writer wishes to satirize any one, they stimulate him to the attempt, as they are sure that lie who is brought on the stage will in general not be one of the multitude, but some rich, or noble, or influential person
tgt_text.3259: It is but a few of the poorer and plebeian class that are ever exposed on the stage, and these would not be molested unless for officiousness, and seeking to set themselves above the rest of the people;
tgt_text.3260: so that at the ridicule thrown on these they are not at all concerned.
tgt_text.3261: 19. I say then, that the people at Athens know very well which of the citizens are good and which are bad;
tgt_text.3262: but, while they know this, they love those who are of use and advantage to themselves, even though they be bad, and rather entertain a. dislike for the better sort, for they do not think that the merit which is in them is for the good of the people in general, but for their harm.
tgt_text.3263: On the other hand, some, who belong to the people by birth, are by no means of a democratic disposition.20.
tgt_text.3264: I forgive the people themselves their attachment to a, democracy, for it is pardonable in every one to study his own benefit;
tgt_text.3265: but whoever is not one of the people, and prefers to live under a democratic rather than an oligarchic form cf government, is but meditating dishonesty, and knows that it is much easier for a knave to escape notice under a de­ mocracy than under an oligarchy.
tgt_text.3267: THE form of the Athenian government, then, I do not commend;
tgt_text.3268: but since they have themselves given the prefer­ ence to a democracy, they appear to me to preserve the de­ mocratic constitution with ability, adhering to the modes of proceeding which I have described.
tgt_text.3269: I see also that some blame the Athenians for this reason, that it is sometimes impossible for an individual, after wait­ ing even a whole year, to settle business with either the senate or the people.
tgt_text.3270: This delay at Athens, however, arises from no other cause than that, from the multiplicity of their affairs, they are unable to decide matters with all parties, and send them away;
tgt_text.3271: 2. for how could they do so, when they have to celebrate, in the first place, more festivals than any other city of Greece,1 (and during these it is impossible for any one to settle any part of the business of the state,) and have besides to take cognizance of so many lawsuits, and accusations, and examinations of public accounts, that not even all the men in the world could attend to them;

tgt_text.3468: 38. Besides,- if everything were to be done at once, it would be necessary for us to procure means for everything at the same time;
tgt_text.3469: but if part be done now, and part deferred, the incom­ ing revenue may assist in obtaining what is necessary for future proceedings.
tgt_text.3471: But as to that which appears to everybody most to be apprehended, I mean that, if the state purchase an extraordi nary number of slaves, the works may be overstocked, we may feel quite free from that apprehension, if we do not send into the mines every year a greater number than the opera tions require.
tgt_text.3472: 40. Thus it appears to me that the way in which it is easiest to pursue these plans is also that in which it is best.
tgt_text.3473: But if, again, you think that, on account of the contributions made during the present war, you are unable to contribute anything further, you must, whatever sum of money the taxes brought in before the peace, conduct the ad­ ministration with that exact sum during the next year, and whatever additional sum they may bring, through peace having taken place, through attention being paid to the sojourners and merchants, through more commodities being imported and exported in consequence of a greater number of people resorting to us, and through the sale of goods being increased at the harbour, you must take that sum and appropriate it in such a way that the revenues may be advanced to the utmost.
tgt_text.3474: 41. If, however, any feel apprehensive that this course, if war occur, will prove ineffectual, let them consider that, even if war should break out, it will be far more formidable to those who attack us than to our state.
tgt_text.3475: 42.
