For what acquisi­ tion would be more useful for war than a great number of people, since they would be able to man many of the public vessels, while many of them also, serving for the public on land, would offer a powerful resistance to the enemy, provided that we do but treat them well ?43.
tgt_text.3476: I consider, too, that even if war takes place, it is possi­ ble to prevent our mines from being abandoned;
tgt_text.3477: for there is, we know, a fortress near the mines at Anaphlystus, on the sea towards the south, and another at Thoricus, on the sea towards the north ;
tgt_text.3478: 1 and these two are distant from each other about sixty furlongs.
tgt_text.3479: 44. If, then, a third fort should be built be­ tween these on the summit of Besa, the workmen might then retire into some one of all these fortresses, and, if they should see an enemy approaching, it would be but a short distance for each to retreat to a place of safety.
tgt_text.3480: 45. Should even an overpowering number of enemies come, they would, doubtless, if they found corn, or wine, or cattle, without the works, carry them off;
tgt_text.3481: but if they even occupied the mining ground, of what more would they possess themselves than a heap of stones ?
tgt_text.3482: 46. But how, indeed, could our enemies ever make an inroad on our mines ?
tgt_text.3483: for the city of Megara, which is nearest to them, is distant much more than five hundred stadia;
tgt_text.3484: and Thebes, which is the nearest city after Megara, is distant much more than six hundred.
tgt_text.3485: 47. If they should advance upon the mines, then, from any part in that direction, they will be under the necessity of passing by the city of Athens;
tgt_text.3486: and if they come in small numbers, it is probable that they will be cut off by the cavalry and the guards of the frontier ;
tgt_text.3487: 2 while it is difficult to imagine that they will march out with a large force, leaving their own country unguarded;
tgt_text.3488: for the city of Athens would be much nearer to their cities, than they themselves would be when they are at the mines.
tgt_text.3489: 48. But, even if they should come in great force, how could they stay, when they would have no provisions?
tgt_text.3490: since, should they go out to get provisions in small parties, there would be danger both to those who went out for provisions, and to those who remained behind to fight;
tgt_text.3491: 1 and, if their whole force went out foraging on every occasion, they would be besieged rather than besiegers.
tgt_text.3493: Not only the profit from the slaves, then, would increase the resources of the city, but, as a vast number of people would collect about the mines, there would also arise a great income from the market held there,3 from the rent of the public buildings around the mines, from the furnaces, and from all other sources of that kind.
tgt_text.3495: Our city, too, if it be thus supported, will become extremely populous, and land about the mines will grow as valuable to those who possess it there as to those who have it around Athens.
tgt_text.3496: 51. Should all in­ deed be done that I have proposed, I maintain that the state will not only be better supplied with money, but will be more quiet and orderly, and better prepared for war.
tgt_text.3497: 52. For those who are appointed to exercise the youth would discharge their duties in the gymnasia with greater care, as they would then receive more pay than those now receive who act as gymnasiarchs for the torch-race ;
tgt_text.3498: 4 and those who are sent to be stationed in garrisons, as well as those who are to serve as peltasts, and to keep guard round the country,' would per­ form all their occupations more efficiently, if pay were given them for each of their duties.
tgt_text.3500: BUT if it appears evident, that, if the full revenues from the state are to be collected, there must be peace, is it not proper for us also to appoint guardians of peace ?
tgt_text.3501: 2 for such an office, if established, would render the city more agreeable for all men to visit, and more frequented.
tgt_text.3502: 2. Should any persons imagine, however, that if our state continues to maintain peace, it will be less powerful, and esteemed, and celebrated through Greece, such persons, in my opinion, entertain an unreasonable apprehension;
tgt_text.3503: for those states, assuredly, are most prosperous, which have remained at peace for the long­ est period ;
tgt_text.3504: and of all states Athens is the best adapted by nature for flourishing during peace.
tgt_text.3505: 3. Who, indeed, if the city were in the enjoyment of peace, would not be eager to resort to it, and shipowners and merchants most of all?
tgt_text.3506: Would not those who have plenty of corn, and ordinary wine,.
tgt_text.3507: and wine of the sweetest kind, and olive oil, and cattle, flock to us, as well as those who can make profit by their ingenuity and by money-lending ?
tgt_text.3509: and sophists, and philosophers, and poets, and such as study their works, and such as desire to witness sacrifices, or re­ ligious ceremonies worthy of being seen and heard, and such as desire to make a quick sale or purchase of many com­ modities, obtain their objects better than at Athens ?
tgt_text.3510: 5. If no one can answer in the negative to these questions, and yet some, who desire to recover the supreme dominion for our state, think that that end would be effected better by war than by peace, let them contemplate, first of all, the Persian invasion, and consider whether it was by force of arms or by good offices to the Greeks that we attained the head of the naval confederacy, and the management of the treasury of Greece.
tgt_text.3512: 6. Besides, when our state, from being thought to exercise its power too tyrannically, was deprived of its supre­ macy, were we not then also, after we abstained from en­ croachment, again made rulers of the fleet by the unanimous consent of the islanders ? 2 7. Did not the Thebans, in con­ sideration of the benefits which they had received, allow the Athenians to lead them ?3
tgt_text.3513: Even the Lacedæmonians, not from being forced, but from having been assisted by us, allowed the Athenians to settle matters as they pleased respecting the supreme command.
tgt_text.3515: 8. And at the present time, through the disturbances prevailing in Greece,5 it seems to me that an opportunity has offered itself to our city to attach the Greeks to it again without difficulty, without danger, and without expense ;
tgt_text.3516: for we may endeavour to reconcile the states that are at war with one another, and we may try also to unite such as are divided into factions.
tgt_text.3517: 9. If you should make it evident, too, not by forming warlike confederacies, but by send­ ing embassies throughout Greece, that you are anxious for the temple at Delphi to be free as it was formerly, I think it would not be at all surprising if you should find all the Greeks ready to agree, and to form confederacies and alliances with you, against those6 who sought to gain the mastery over the Delphic temple when the Phocians relinquished it.
tgt_text.3518: 10. If you indicate, moreover, that you are desirous that peace should prevail over the whole land and sea, I consider that all the Greeks, next to the security of their own countries, would pray for the pre­ servation of Athens.it.
tgt_text.3519: But if any one still thinks that war is more conducive to the wealth of our city than peace, I know not by what means this point can be better decided, than by considering what effect events that occurred in former times produced on our city.
tgt_text.3520: 12. For he will find that in days of old vast sums of money were brought into the city during peace, and that the whole of it was expended during war;
tgt_text.3521: and he will learn, if he gives his attention to the subject, that, in the present day, many branches of the revenue are deficient in conse­ quence of the war, and that the money from those which have been productive has been spent on many urgent requi­ sitions of every kind ;
tgt_text.3522: but that now, when peace is established at sea, the revenues are increasing, and that the citizens are at liberty to make whatever use of them they please.
tgt_text.3523: 13. If any one should ask me this question, " Do you mean that, even if any power should unjustly attack our state, we must maintain peace with that power?"
tgt_text.3524: I should not say that I had any such intention ;
tgt_text.3525: but I may safely assert, that we shall retaliate on any aggressors with far greater facility, if we can show that none of our people does wrong to any one;
tgt_text.3526: 1 for then our enemies will not have a single supporterI.
tgt_text.3527: IF, then, of all that has been said, nothing appears im­ possible or even difficult, and if, in case that what I propose be effected, we shall secure increased attachment from the Greeks in general, dwell in greater security, and be distin­ guished with greater honour,-if the common people will have plenty of provisions, and the rich be eased of the expenses for war,—if, as abundance increases, we shall celebrate our festivals with greater magnificence than at present, shall re­ pair our temples, rebuild our walls and docks, and restore their civil rights1 to the priests, the senate, the magistrates, and the cavalry, is it not proper that we should proceed to ex­ ecute these plans as soon as possible, that, even in our days, we may see our country flourishing in security ?
tgt_text.3528: 2. Should we resolve on pursuing these measures, I should recommend that we should send to Dodona and Delphi to inquire of the gods whether it will be better and more advantageous for the state, for the present time and for posterity, thus to regulate itself.
tgt_text.3529: 3. If the gods should give their assent to the pro­ ceedings, I should say that we ought then to ask which of the gods we should propitiate in order to execute our designs in the best and most efficient manner;
tgt_text.3530: and whichever of the deities they name in their reply, it will be proper to seek favourable omens from them by sacrifices, and then to com­ mence our operations;
tgt_text.3531: for if our undertakings are begun with the support of the gods, it is likely that the results from them will lead continually to that which is still better and more advantageous for the state.
tgt_text.3532: Tms treatise, as Weiske observes, is the production of a mail who had had much experience in horsemanship, and who had nicely observed the habits and character of the horse.
tgt_text.3533: He speaks with commendation, at the commencement, of a writer named Simo, who had published a work on horses.
tgt_text.3534: Of Simo little more is known than what Xenophon tells;
tgt_text.3535: he is called an Athenian by Suidas (v. Τρίλλη), and is several times cited by Pollux.
tgt_text.3536: Accord­ ing to Pliny, H. N. xxxiv. 8, he was the first that wrote on horse­ manship.
tgt_text.3537: In delivering his observations and precepts, Xenophon some­ times uses the first person plural, and sometimes the first person singular, but the reason for the difference does not appear.
tgt_text.3538: The treatise seems from the conclusion to have been written after the Hipparchicus, but as it is printed in all editions before it, it is here suffered to retain its precedence.
tgt_text.3540: SINCE, as it has been our fortune to be long engaged about horses, we consider that we have acquired some know­ ledge of horsemanship;
tgt_text.3541: we desire also to intimate to the younger part of our friends how we think that they may bestow their attention on horses to the best advantage.
tgt_text.3542: Simo has indeed written, too, on the management of horses, who also made an of­ fering of the brazen horse on the temple of the Eleusinian Ceres at Athens, and engraved his own works2 on the pedestal;
tgt_text.3543: and in whatever particulars, assuredly, we happen to be of the same opinion with him, we shall not expunge 3 them from our pages, but shall lay them before our friends with far greater pleasure, expecting to acquire additional credit, since he who was skilled in horses had the same notions with us ;
tgt_text.3544: and on such points as he has left unnoticed we shall endeavour to throw light.
tgt_text.3545: We shall show, first if all, how a man may be least deceived in purchasing a horse.
tgt_text.3546: In regard to a colt not yet broken, it is plain that we must examine his body ;
tgt_text.3547: for of his temper a horse that has never been mounted can give no certain indi­ cations.
tgt_text.3549: In respect to his body, then, we assert that we must first examine thefeet;
tgt_text.3550: for as there would be no use in a house, though the upper parts were extremely beautiful, if the found­ ations were not laid as they ought to be, so there would be no profit in a war-horse, even if he had all his other parts excel­ lent, but was unsound in the feet;
tgt_text.3551: for he would be unable to render any of his other good qualities effective.
tgt_text.3553: A person may form his opinion of the feet by first ex­ amining the hoofs;
tgt_text.3554: for thick hoofs are much more conducive to firmness of tread than thin ones ;
tgt_text.3555: and it must also not escape his notice whether the hoofs are high or low, as well before as behind;
tgt_text.3556: for high hoofs raise what is called the frog 1 far above the ground;
tgt_text.3557: and low ones tread equally on the strongest and softest part of the foot, like in-kneed men.
tgt_text.3558: Simo says that horses which have good feet may be known by the sound;
tgt_text.3559: and he says this with great justice, for a hollow hoof rings against the ground like a cymbal.
tgt_text.3561: Since we have commenced with this part, we shall as­ cend from it to the rest of the body.
tgt_text.3562: The bones 3 immediately above the hoofs, then, and below the fetlocks, must be neither too upright, like those of a goat (for then, being too unyield­ ing,l they shake the rider, and such legs are more subject to inflammation), nor ought those bones to be too sloping;
tgt_text.3563: for the fetlocks will in that case be denuded of hair and galled, if the horse be ridden either among clods or over stones.
tgt_text.3565: Of the legs the bones ought to be thick ;
tgt_text.3566: for they are the supports of the body;
tgt_text.3567: but it is not in veins or flesh that their thickness should consist,2 since, should this be the case, they must, when the horse is ridden over hard ground, be filled with blood, when hard tumours3 will arise, and while the whole leg is swollen, the skin will widen ;
tgt_text.3568: and when the skin is loose, the small bone of the leg4 often gives way, and renders the horse lame.
tgt_text.3570: If the colt, as he walks, bends his knees freely,5 you may conjecture that he will have supple legs when he is ridden;
tgt_text.3571: for all colts in the course of time acquire greater freedom of motion in their knees ;
tgt_text.3572: and supple joints are justly commended, for they render a horse less likely to stumble and grow tired than stiff joints.
tgt_text.3574: The thighs 6 under the shoulders, if they are stout, appear stronger and more graceful, as is the case with those of men.
tgt_text.3575: The chest, if somewhat broad, is better adapted both for beauty and strength, as well as for keeping the legs, not so as to touchy but wide apart.
tgt_text.3577: The neck, as it proceeds from the chest, should not fall forwards, like that of a boar, but should grow upwards like that of a cock, and should have an easy motion8 at the parts about the arch.
tgt_text.3578: The head should be bony,1 and have a small cheek.
tgt_text.3579: Thus the neck will be directly in front of the rider,2 and the eye of the animal will see what is before his feet.
tgt_text.3581: A horse of such a shape would be less able to do mischief, even though he be extremely vicious;
tgt_text.3582: for it is not by bending, but by stretching out the neck and head, that horses attempt to.
tgt_text.3584: It is necessary to observe, however, whether both the jaws 4 be soft or hard, or only one of them, for horses which have not both the jaws alike are generally obstinate.
tgt_text.3586: To have the eye prominent gives an air of greater vigilance to a horse than to have it sunk, and a horse with such an eye can see much further than another.
tgt_text.3588: Wide nostrils are not only better adapted for breathing than those which are contracted, but make a horse appear more terrible;
tgt_text.3589: for when one horse is angry at another, or is excited in being ridden, he dilates his nostrils.
tgt_text.3591: When the top of the head is somewhat large, and the ears rather small, they render a horse's head more like what it.
tgt_text.3593: The point of the shoulder being high renders the seat of the rider more secure, and makes the shoulder ap­ pear more firmly attached to the body.
tgt_text.3594: A double spine6 is both much softer to sit upon, and more pleasing to the eye, than a single one.
tgt_text.3595: 12. The sides being somewhat deep, and swelling towards the belly, render a horse in general more easy to ride, and stronger, and make him appear better profited by his food.
tgt_text.3597: The broader and shorter the loins are, the more easily the horse raises his fore parts, and brings forward his hinder ones;
tgt_text.3598: and in so doing, his belly will appear smaller, which, if large, partly disfigures a horse, and renders him also weaker and less able to carry weight.
tgt_text.3600: The haunches should be broad and well covered with flesh, that they may correspond to the sides and the chest;
tgt_text.3601: and if these parts are compact, they will be lighter for run­ ning, and render the horse much swifter.
tgt_text.3603: If a horse has the thighs under the tail broad and not distorted,2 he will then set his hind legs well apart, and will by that means have a quicker 3 and firmer step,.
tgt_text.3604: a better seat for a rider, and will be better in every respect.
tgt_text.3606: We may see a proof of this in men;
tgt_text.3607: for when they wish to take up anything from the ground, they try to raise it by setting their legs apart rather than by bringing them together.
tgt_text.3609: A horse should not have large testicles;
tgt_text.3610: but it is im­ possible to tell what will be the size of them in a colt.
tgt_text.3611: With regard to the pasterns of the hind legs, or shins, as well as the fetlocks and hoofs, we may make the same remarks as we made concerning the fore-legs.16.
tgt_text.3612: I wish also to show by what means a person will be least likely to be deceived in regard to the probable size;
tgt_text.3613: for any colt that has very long legs when it is foaled will become a very large horse, since in all quadrupeds the shank-bones do not grow much as time advances, but the rest of the body, that it may be symmetrical, grows in proportion to them.
tgt_text.3615: Those who judge in this way of the shape of a colt seem to us most likely to get a horse that has good feet, and is strong, fleshy, and of a good figure and size.
tgt_text.3616: Even though some horses change as they grow up, yet we may still have sufficient confidence in these observations to form a judgment;
tgt_text.3617: for far more horses, from being ill-shaped, become well proportioned, than grow deformed after having once been well-shaped.i.
tgt_text.3618: How we must break colts, it does not appear to me that I need give any account;
tgt_text.3619: 1 for though it is people that are well provided with means in communities, and that have no small share in the commonwealth, who are required2 to serve in the cavalry, yet it is much better for a young man to study to im­ prove his bodily strength, and to attain a knowledge of horse­ manship, or, if he is already a proficient in it, to exercise him­ self in riding, than to be a breaker of colts;
tgt_text.3620: and for a man in years it is better that he should attend to his family and friends, or to civil and military occupations, than employ him­ self in training horses.
tgt_text.3622: He assuredly who knows as much as myself respecting the management of colts will give his colt out to be broken.
tgt_text.3624: But he ought to write down, when he gives him out, as he does when he puts out a youth to learn any art, in what points the trainer is to send him back instructed ;
tgt_text.3625: for this will be an intimation to the trainer to what particulars he must at­ tend, if he wishes to receive his pay.
tgt_text.3627: We should however take care that the colt be delivered to the breaker gentle, tractable, and submissive to man ;
tgt_text.3628: for such a disposition may generally be produced in him by the groom at home, if he knows how to manage so that hunger, and thirst, and uneasiness may be felt by the colt when alone, and that food, and drink, and relief from uneasiness may come to him from man ;
tgt_text.3629: for, if things are thus ordered, men must not only be liked, but longed for, by the colts.
tgt_text.3631: We ought also to handle such parts as a horse most likes to be stroked ;
tgt_text.3632: and these are the parts which are most hairy, and in which the horse, if anything makes him uneasy, is least able to afford himself relief.
tgt_text.3634: Let orders be given to the groom, too, to lead him through crowds of people, and to make him approach all kinds of objects and sounds;
tgt_text.3635: and of whichever of these the colt is afraid, we must teach him, not with harshness, but with gen­ tleness, that they are by no means objects of fear.
tgt_text.3636: Such are the points, in respect to the breaking of colts, to which it ap­ pears to me sufficient to admonish a private individual1 to attend.
tgt_text.3638: WHEN a person would buy a horse that has been already ridden, we shall subjoin some admonitions which he ought tc bear in mind, if he would not be cheated in his purchase.
tgt_text.3639: In the first place, then, let it not escape his notice what the age is;
tgt_text.3640: for a horse that has no longer the marks in his teeth neither delights the buyer with hope, nor is so easy to be ex­ changed.
tgt_text.3642: When his youth is ascertained, it must also be noticed how he takes the bit into his mouth, and the head-piece over his ears;
tgt_text.3643: and this cannot fail to be observed, if the bridle is put on in sight of the purchaser, and taken off in his sight.
tgt_text.3645: It is also necessary to see how he takes the rider on his back ;
tgt_text.3646: for many horses reluctantly receive on them anything which it is plain to them that they cannot receive without being compelled to work.
tgt_text.3647: 4. It must likewise be observed whether, when he is mounted, he wishes to separate himself from other horses, or whether, if he is ridden near horses standing by, he carries off his rider towards them.
tgt_text.3648: There are some horses too, that, from bad training, run off from the places of exercise to their stalls1 at home.
tgt_text.3650: As for horses whose jaws are not alike,2 that sort of riding which is called the pede3 exposes them, and, still more, a change in the direction in which they are ridden;
tgt_text.3651: 4 for many horses will not attempt to run away with their riders, unless a hard jaw, and their course directed homewards, con­ cur to stimulate them.
tgt_text.3652: We ought to ascertain, also, whether the horse, being put to his speed, is readily pulled up, and whether he submits to be turned about.
tgt_text.3654: It is good for a purchaser not to be ignorant, moreover, whether a horse is equally willing to obey when he is roused with a blow;
tgt_text.3655: for a servant and an army, if disobedient, are useless, but a disobedient horse is not only useless, but often plays the traitor.
tgt_text.3657: But when we take upon ourselves to purchase a war- horse, we must make trial of him in all things in which war will make trial of him;
tgt_text.3658: and these are, leaping across ditches, springing over walls, jumping on to mounds, and jumping down from them;
tgt_text.3659: and we must try him in riding up and down steep places, and along them;
tgt_text.3660: for all such efforts show his spirit, whether it is bold, and whether his body is sound.
tgt_text.3661: 8. Yet we must not at once reject a horse that does not accomplish all these feats perfectly;
tgt_text.3662: for many fail, not from being un­ able, but from want of training;
tgt_text.3663: and if they are taught, and used, and exercised in such performances, they will execute them all well, provided they are sound in other respects, and not wanting in spirit.
tgt_text.3665: We must however be cautious of having anything to do with horses that are naturally shy;
tgt_text.3666: for horses that are exces­ sively timorous will not only not allow the rider on their back to harm the enemy, but will often take him by surprise,1 and expose him to great danger.
tgt_text.3667: 10. We must also learn whether the horse has anything of vice either towards other horses, or towards men, and whether he is averse to being handled ;
tgt_text.3668: for all such defects are troublesome to his owner.
tgt_text.3669: 11. As to any reluctance to being bridled and mounted, and other tricks,2 a person will much sooner discover them, if, when the horse has been thoroughly exercised, he attempt to do to him3 what he did before he began to ride him;
tgt_text.3670: since horses that, after having been exercised, are ready to submit to exercise again, give sufficient proofs of a mettlesome spirit.
tgt_text.3672: To sum up all in a few words, whatever horse has good feet, is mild-tempered, sufficiently swift, is willing and able tt endure fatigue, and is in the highest degree obedient, will probably give least trouble to his rider, and contribute most to his safety in military occupations.
tgt_text.3673: But horses that from sluggishness require a great deal of driving, or, from excess of mettle, much coaxing and care, afford plenty of employ­ ment to the rider, as well as much apprehension in time of danger.l
tgt_text.3674: WHEN a man has purchased a horse that he admires, and taken him home, it is proper that his stable should be in some part of the premises where the master may see him most fre­ quently ;
tgt_text.3675: and it will be right for him to construct the stall in such a way that it may no more be possible for the horse's food to be stolen from the manger than the master's from his cellar.
tgt_text.3676: He that is neglectful of such precaution appears to me to be neglectful of himself;
tgt_text.3677: for it is evident that in danger the master trusts his personal safety to his horse.
tgt_text.3679: A secure manger is not only serviceable to prevent the food from being stolen, but to let it be seen when the horse scatters his food out of the manger ;
tgt_text.3680: 1 and if a person perceives that such is the case, he may be sure, either that the horse, having too much blood in his body, requires veterinary atten­ tion, or that, from fatigue having affected him, he needs rest, or that indigestion2 or some other malady is coming upon him;
tgt_text.3681: and it is with horses as with men, that all diseases are more easily cured at the commencement than after they have acquired strength, and mistakes have been made in the treat­ ment of them.
tgt_text.3683: As attention must be paid to a horse's food and exercise, that his body may be vigorous, so must care be likewise taken of his feet.
tgt_text.3684: Damp and smooth stable floors injure even na­ turally good hoofs;
tgt_text.3685: and to prevent them from being damp, they ought to be sloping;
tgt_text.3686: to prevent them from being smooth, they should have stones inserted in the ground close to one another, similar to a horse's hoofs in size;
tgt_text.3687: for such stable floors give firmness to the feet of horses that stand on them.
tgt_text.3689: The groom must also lead the horse out of the stable to the place where he is to comb him ;
tgt_text.3690: and he should be tied away from the manger after his morning's feed, that he may come to his evening meal with the greater appetite.
tgt_text.3691: The ground outside the stable may be put into excellent condition, and serve to strengthen the horse's feet,2 if a person throws down in it here and there four or five loads of round stones, large enough to fill the two hands, and about a pound in weight, surrounding them with an iron rim, so that they may not be scattered;
tgt_text.3692: for, as the horse stands on these, he will be in much the same condition as if he were to travel part of every day on a stony road.
tgt_text.3694: A horse must also move his hoofs when he is rubbed down, or when he is annoyed with flies,4 as much as when he is walking;
tgt_text.3695: and the stones which are thus spread about strengthen the frogs of the feet.
tgt_text.3696: And as we must take care of the hoofs, that they may be hard, so we must take care of the mouth, that it may be soft;
tgt_text.3697: and the same treatment softens the flesh of a man and the mouth of a horsed1.
tgt_text.3698: IT seems to us to be the duty of a man who keeps horses to see that his groom be instructed1 as to what he ought to do about a horse.
tgt_text.3699: In the first place, he should know that the knot of the halter which ties the horse to the manger should never be made in the same place where the head-piece2 is put round;
tgt_text.3700: for as the horse often rubs his head against the man­ ger, the halter, if it be not easy around his ears, will frequently cause sore places;
tgt_text.3701: and, in consequence of such sores, the horse must necessarily prove less tractable under the operations of bridling and rubbing.
tgt_text.3703: It is right, also, that the groom should be ordered to carry out the dung and straw from the horse every day, to some one particular place ;
tgt_text.3704: 3 for, by so doing, he will get rid of it with the greatest ease, and at the same time do a service to the horse.
tgt_text.3706: The groom must likewise know that be should put the muzzle4 on the horse when he takes him out, whether to be rubbed down or for exercise ;
tgt_text.3707: and 5 at all times, indeed, when­ ever he takes him out without a bit, he should muzzle him ;
tgt_text.3708: for the muzzle does not hinder him from breathing, though it pre­ vents him from biting ;
tgt_text.3709: and, when it is on, it makes them feel less inclined to play vicious tricks.
tgt_text.3710: 64. It is proper to tie up a horse with the halter above his bead;
tgt_text.3711: for whatever annoys a horse about the face, he na­ turally tries to get rid of by throwing up his head;
tgt_text.3712: and when he is thus tied, he rather, as he throws up his head, loosens his halter than tightens it.
tgt_text.3714: When the groom rubs down the horse, he should begin with the head and the mane;
tgt_text.3715: for if the upper parts are not clean, it is useless to clean those, below ;
tgt_text.3716: and then, with all sorts of cleansing instruments, he should raise the hair over the rest of the body, and brush away the dust in the contrary direction to that in which the hair grows;
tgt_text.3717: but the hair on the back he ought to touch with no instrument at all, but to rub and smooth it down gently with the hand the way that it na­ turally lies, for thus he will do less injury to the seat of the horse.
tgt_text.3719: The head he should wash with water ;
tgt_text.3720: for, being bony, if it were cleaned with anything made of iron or wood,2 it would pain the horse.
tgt_text.3721: The forelock he should also moisten;
tgt_text.3722: 3 for while these hairs, though of a good length, do not prevent the horse from seeing, they brush away from his eyes what­ ever annoys them;
tgt_text.3723: and we may suppose that the gods gave these hairs to the horse instead of the long ears which they have given to asses and mules, to be a protection to the eyes.
tgt_text.3724: 7. The tail and the mane it is also proper to wash, since we should encourage the growth of this hair;
tgt_text.3725: that of the tail, in order that the horse, stretching it out as far as possible, may brush off whatever molests him;
tgt_text.3726: 4 and that of the neck, that, being abundant, it may afford an ample grasp to the person mounting.
tgt_text.3728: The mane, fore-lock, and tail have been given by the gods as additions to the beauty of a horse ;
tgt_text.3729: and a proof of this is, that mares kept for breeding do not so readily admit asses to cover them, as long as their hair is of its natural length;
tgt_text.3730: and in consequence, all those who breed mules cut off the hair of the mares to prepare them for being covered.
tgt_text.3732: Washing of the legs we omit;
tgt_text.3733: for it is of no use, and the daily wetting does harm to the hoofs.
tgt_text.3734: It is proper, also, to moderate the excessive cleaning under the belly ;
tgt_text.3735: for it is the most troublesome of all cleaning to the horse ;
tgt_text.3736: and the cleaner those parts are made, the more annoyances2 they at­ tract under the belly.
tgt_text.3738: Besides, if a groom takes ever so much pains with those parts, the horse is no sooner taken out, than he is exactly in the same condition as horses that have not been cleaned.
tgt_text.3739: These things it is therefore well to let alone ;
tgt_text.3740: and in regard to the legs, too, such rubbing of them as can be performed with the hands is sufficient..
tgt_text.3741: WE shall now show how a man may groom a horse with least danger to himself, and most benefit to the animal.
tgt_text.3743: when he cleans him, he looks the same way as the horse,1 there is danger that he may be struck in the face with his knee or his hoof.
tgt_text.3744: 2. But if he looks in the opposite direction to the horse when he cleans him, keeping himself2 out of the reach of his leg, and rubs gradually down by the shoulder, he will thus receive no injury, and may clean the frog of the horse's foot by turning up the hoof.
tgt_text.3745: In like manner let him clean the hind legs.
tgt_text.3747: But whoever is employed about a horse, ought to know that to do these things, and everything else that he has to do, he must come as little as possible near the face and the tail;
tgt_text.3748: for if a horse is inclined to be vicious, he has in both these parts the advantage of the man.
tgt_text.3749: But a person who approaches him at the side may manage the horse with least danger to him­ self, and with most power over the beast.
tgt_text.3750: 34. When we have to lead a horse, we do not approve of the practice of leading from behind, for these reasons, that the person leading the horse is thus least able to keep on his guard against him, and the horse has most liberty to do what he pleases.
tgt_text.3751: 5. To the mode, again, of conducting him with a long rein, to teach him to go forward and take the lead, we object for the following reasons, that the horse can do mis­ chief on whichever side he pleases, and that, by turning him­ self round, he can set himself opposite his leader.
tgt_text.3752: 6. When there are a number of horses together, too, how, if they are thus led, can they be prevented from annoying one another ?
tgt_text.3753: But a horse that is accustomed to be led at the side, will be least in a condition to molest either other horses or men, and will be readiest at hand for his rider whenever he may require to mount in haste.
tgt_text.3755: That the groom may put on the bridle properly let him first approach the horse on the left side, and then throw­ ing the reins over the horse's head, let him suffer them to rest on the point of the shoulder ;
tgt_text.3756: and next let him take the head-piece in his right hand, and apply the bit with his left.
tgt_text.3758: If the horse take the bit into his mouth, the man has nothing to do but put on the head-piece;
tgt_text.3759: but if the horse will not open his mouth, the man must hold the bit to his teeth, and insert the middle finger of his left hand between the horse's bars ;
tgt_text.3760: for most horses, when this is done, open their mouths;
tgt_text.3761: should the horse, however, not even then receive the bit, let him press the lip against the dog-tooth or tusk, and there are very few horses that, on feeling this, will not admit it.9.
tgt_text.3762: Let the groom also be instructed in the following points.
tgt_text.3763: First, never to lead the horse by the bridle, for this practice makes horses harder on one side of the mouth than on the other ;
tgt_text.3764: and, next, to keep the bit from pressing on his jaws as much as possible ;
tgt_text.3765: for if the bit rubs on them too much, it renders the mouth callous, so that it loses all feeling ;
tgt_text.3766: though, on the other hand, if it is allowed to fall down too much to­ wards the front of the mouth, it gives the horse an oppor­ tunity of seizing the bit between his teeth, and refusing to obey it.
tgt_text.3768: It is proper, however, that a horse should not be irritated by these matters when he has work to do ;
tgt_text.3769: for so important is it that a horse should take the bit readily, that one who does not take it is altogether useless.
tgt_text.3770: 11. But if he is accustomed to be bitted, not only when he is going to work, but when he is taken to his food, and when he is brought home to his stable after being ridden, it will not be at all surprising if he seize the bit of his own accord when it is held towards him.
tgt_text.3771: 12. It is well, too, that the groom should know how to as­ sist a rider to mount after the Persian manner,1 that the master himself, if he should be sick or advanced in years, may have some one that can mount him easily, or may lend his servant to a friend to mount him, if he wish to afford such assistance to any one.
tgt_text.3773: But never to approach a horse in afit of anger is the one great precept and maxim of conduct in regard to the treatment of a horse ;
tgt_text.3774: for anger is destitute of forethought, and consequently often does that of which the agent must necessarily repent.
tgt_text.3776: When a horse is shy of any object, and reluctant to approach it, the rider must try to make him feel1 that there is nothing terrible in it, especially to a horse of spirit;
tgt_text.3777: but if he cannot succeed, the rider must himself touch that which ap­ pears so alarming, and lead the horse up gently to it.
tgt_text.3778: 15. As to those who force horses forward with blows in such a case, they only inspire them with greater terror ;
tgt_text.3779: for they imagine, when they suffer any pain at such a time, that what they look upon with alarm is in some way the cause of it.
tgt_text.3781: When the groom brings the horse to the rider, we have no objection that he should know how to make the horse stoop,2 so that it may be easy to mount him;
tgt_text.3782: yet we think every rider ought to take care to be able to mount, even if the horse does not bend to him ;
tgt_text.3783: for sometimes a different horse will present himself, and the same horse will not always be equally obedient.1.
tgt_text.3784: WE shall now show how a rider must act, when he has received his horse for the purpose of mounting him, so as to be of most service alike to himself and to his horse in riding.
tgt_text.3785: In the first place, then, he must take the rein,' which is fastened to the lower part of the bit,2 or to the chain that goes under the chin,3 in his left hand, in a convenient manner, and so loosely, that he may not, either as he raises himself by grasping the mane near the ears, or jumps on the horse's back with the assistance of his spear,4 pull the animal back.
tgt_text.3786: Then, with his right hand, let him take hold of the bridle 5 at the point of the shoulder, and of the mane at the same time, that he may not in any way, as he mounts, twist the horse's mouth with the bit.
tgt_text.3787: 2. When he has set himself at ease for mount­ ing, let him draw up his body with his left hand, and, stretch­ ing forth his right, let him lift himself with that also (for, mounting in this way, he will not present an ungraceful ap­ pearance behind), and let him do this with his leg bent, and not rest his knees on the back of the horse, but throw his leg across at once to the right side;
tgt_text.3788: and when he has passed his foot clean over, let him then seat himself on the horse's back.
tgt_text.3790: It seems to us also very proper, in case a rider should happen to be leading his horse with his left hand, and to be holding his lance in his right, to practise mounting on the right side ;
tgt_text.3791: 1 but for this he has nothing more to learn, than to perform those movements with his left hand and foot which he had previously performed with his right.
tgt_text.3792: 4. We com­ mend such readiness in mounting for this reason, that the rider, as soon as he is seated on the horse, is in every way prepared for action, if it should be necessary to encounter an enemy on a sudden.
tgt_text.3794: When he has taken his seat, whether on the horse's bare back or on the clothe we do not like that lie should sit as if he were on a carriage seat, but as if he were standing upright with his legs somewhat apart ;
tgt_text.3795: 3 for thus he will cling more firmly to the horse with his thighs, and, keeping himself erect, he will be able to throw a javelin or to strike a blow on horseback, if it be necessary, with greater force.
tgt_text.3797: But it is necessary to allow the leg, as well as the foot, to hang loose from the knee ;
tgt_text.3798: for if a rider keep his leg stiff, and strike it against anything, it may be broken ;
tgt_text.3799: but if the leg hangs easy, and anything strikes against it, it will yield, and yet not move the thigh from its position.
tgt_text.3801: A rider should also accustom himself to keep the parts of his body above the hips as flexible as possible ;
tgt_text.3802: for be will by this means be better able to exert himself, and if any person should drag or push him, he will be less likely to be thrown off.
tgt_text.3804: Let it be observed, too, that when he is seated on the horse's back, he must first teach the horse to stand quiet, until he has drawn up his mantle,4 if necessary, and adjusted the reins, and taken hold of his lance in such a way as it may most conveniently be carried.
tgt_text.3805: Then let him keep his left arm close to his side;
tgt_text.3806: for in such an attitude a rider appears most graceful,1 and his hand has the greatest power.
tgt_text.3808: As to reins, we approve of such as are equally balanced, and not weak, or slippery, or too thick, so that the hand which holds them may be able also to hold the spear when it is necessary.
tgt_text.3810: When the rider gives the signal to the horse to start, let him begin to advance at a walking pace, as this pace is least likely to disturb the horse.
tgt_text.3811: Let him hold the reins, if the horse is inclined to hold down his head, rather high ;
tgt_text.3812: but if he is more disposed to carry it erect, let him keep them lower, for thus he will best set off the horse's figure.
tgt_text.3813: 11. After a little, if he trots at his natural pace,2 he will find his limbs become pliant without inconvenience, and will come with the greatest readiness to obey the whip.
tgt_text.3815: Since, too, it is the most approved practice to set off towards the left side, the horse will most readily start on that side, 1 if, when he lifts, as he is trotting, his right foot,2 the rider then give him the signal to gallop.
tgt_text.3816: 12. For, being then about to raise the left foot, he will thus start with that foot;
tgt_text.3817: and just at the mo­ ment that the rider turns him to the left, he will make the first spring 3 in his gallop;
tgt_text.3818: for a horse, when he is turned to the right, naturally leads off with the right foot, and when turned to the left, with the left foot.
tgt_text.3820: As to the mode of exercising a horse, we approve of that which is called the pede,4 for it accustoms a horse to be turned by both sides of his mouth ;
tgt_text.3821: and it is good to change the direction of his course, that both sides may receive equal stress in the different directions.
tgt_text.3822: 14. We approve, too, of a place of exercise of an oblong form,5 in preference to the round;
tgt_text.3823: for in the oblong the horse may be turned with the greater ease, when tired of going straight forward, and he will be exercised at once in running in a direct course and in turning.is.
tgt_text.3824: It is proper also to pull in the rein 6 as the horse turns;
tgt_text.3825: for it is not easy for a horse, nor safe, when going fast, to turn in a small spacer especially if the ground be rough 2 or slip­ pery.
tgt_text.3826: 16. But at the time that the rider pulls him in, he ought to sway the horse as little as possible with the bit, and to sway himself also as little as possible;
tgt_text.3827: for if he sways himself much, he may be well assured that a very small im­ pulse will be sufficient to stretch both him and his horse on the ground.
tgt_text.3829: When the horse, after having turned, looks straight be­ fore him, the rider should then excite him to greater speed;
tgt_text.3830: 3 for it is plain that turnings are made in war either for pur­ suing or retreating, and hence it is good to accustom a horse, after he has turned, to increase his speed.
tgt_text.3832: Also, when the horse appears to have been sufficiently exercised, it is useful, after having let him rest a while, to excite him on a sudden to his utmost speed, as well away from the other horses as towards them;
tgt_text.3833: and, after he has been put to his speed, to let him rest somewhere as near as possible," and, when he has stood still awhile, to wheel him about and urge him again to a gallop;
tgt_text.3834: for it is certain that occasions will offer when he will have need to practise both.
tgt_text.3836: But when it is time to dismount, the rider should never alight either among other horses, or amidst a concourse of people, or beyond the exercise ground;
tgt_text.3837: but in the place where the horse is obliged to exert himself, there let turn also begin to rest.
tgt_text.3839: SINCE there will be occasions when the horse will have to run up and down sloping and hilly grounds, and along the sides of hills, when he will have to leap over obstacles, and to spring up and down, the rider must train and exercise both himself and his horse completely in all these manoeuvres;
tgt_text.3840: for thus they will be likely to contribute more to the safety and advantage of each other.
tgt_text.3841: 2. If any one thinks that e are merely repeating ourselves, because we now make men­ tion of the same things that we mentioned before, 1 let him understand that this is not a repetition;
tgt_text.3842: for we then exhorted a horseman, when he purchased a horse, to try whether the animal could perform such exercises;
tgt_text.3843: but now we say that he must teach his own horse, and are going to prescribe how lie must teach him.
tgt_text.3845: He that has got a horse utterly inexperienced in leaping over ditches must, after slackening the leading-rein, go over the ditch first, and must then pull him on with the rein, that he may take the leap.
tgt_text.3846: 4. If he will not leap, another person must take a whip or a switch, and apply it on him smartly, when he will not only leap over the required space, but much further than is necessary;
tgt_text.3847: and afterwards there will be no need to strike him, for if he only sees some one coming be­ hind him, he will leap.
tgt_text.3849: When he has thus been trained to leap, let the rider mount him, and take him first to small, and then to larger ditches.
tgt_text.3850: Just as he is going to leap, let the rider touch him with the spur.
tgt_text.3851: Let him spur him, too, when he is teaching him to leap up and down from any height;
tgt_text.3852: for if the horse does all these things with an impulse2 of his whole body, he will do them with more safety to himself and his rider than if his hinder parts lag either in leaping over an object or in springing up or down.
tgt_text.3854: To make him go down steep places, we must begin to train him on soft ground;
tgt_text.3855: and at length, when be is accus­ tomed to this, he will run much more readily down a slope than up it.
tgt_text.3856: As to what some people fear, that horses will dislocate their shoulders in being ridden down steep places, let them be under no apprehension, when they are told that the Persians and the Odrysæ all ride as fast as they can down steep hills, and yet have horses not less sound than those of the Greeks.
tgt_text.3858: Nor will we omit to mention how the rider must accom­ modate himself to each of these particular circumstances;
tgt_text.3859: for he ought, when his horse suddenly raises himself for a leap,.
tgt_text.3860: to lean forward (since by that means the horse will feel less pressure on his hinder parts, I and will be less likely to shake the rider), and, as he pulls in the reins when the horse alights, he must throw himself back, for he will thus be less jolted.
tgt_text.3862: As the horse is leaping over a ditch, or stretching up an ascent, it is well for the rider to take hold of the mane,2 that the horse may not be oppressed by the difficulty of the ground and by the bit at the same time;
tgt_text.3863: but in going down a declivity,, he should hold himself back, and support the horse with the bridle, that himself and his horse may not be carried headlong down the slope.
tgt_text.3865: It is right, also, to exercise the horse sometimes in one place and sometimes in another, sometimes for a longer and sometimes for a shorter period;
tgt_text.3866: for this will be less disagree­ able to the horse than to be always exercised in the same place and for the same length of time.
tgt_text.3868: Since it is necessary, too, for him who rides his horse at full speed over all sorts of ground to be able to sit firmly on him, and to know how to use his arms on horseback dex­ terously, the practice of horsemanship in hunting is to be­ commended, where the country is favourable, and wild beasts to be found;
tgt_text.3869: but where these conveniences do not offer them­ selves, it is a good sort of exercise for two horsemen to make such an arrangement as this:
tgt_text.3870: that the one is to retreat over ground of a varied character, and, as he flees, is to turn about from time to time and present his spear, while the other is to pursue, carrying javelins blunted with balls, and a spear pre­ pared in the same manner ;
tgt_text.3871: and whenever the pursuer comes within a javelin's throw of the pursued, he is to discharge his blunted javelins at him, and, whenever he gets within the stroke of a spear, to strike him as he is overtaken.
tgt_text.3873: It is well for a horseman, also, if he close with an ene­ my, to pull his enemy towards him, and then suddenly push him away;
tgt_text.3874: for this treatment is likely to unhorse him.
tgt_text.3875: On the other hand, it is well for him who is thus dragged to urge his horse forward ;
tgt_text.3876: for by this means he is more likely to throw off his antagonist than to fall off himself.
tgt_text.3877: 12. If, on any occasion, when two camps are pitched opposite,, the cavalry ride out against one another, and one party pur­ sue their adversaries close up to their main body, and then retreat to their own, it is good for a rider to know that in such circumstances, as long as he is near his friends, it is right and safe to wheel about among the foremost, and charge the enemy at full speed 1;
tgt_text.3878: but he must take care, as he comes close upon them, to have his horse under control;
tgt_text.3879: for, by act­ ing with such caution, he will be in the best condition, as is probable, to injure the enemy and to escape injury from them.
tgt_text.3881: The gods have enabled men to teach other men by speech what they ought to do.
tgt_text.3882: As for a horse, it is certain that you can teach him nothing by speech;
tgt_text.3883: but if, when he does what you wish, you gratify him in some way in return, and, when he is disobedient, make him feel punishment, be will thus effectually learn to obey you in what is required of him.
tgt_text.3884: 14. This we may express, indeed, in a few words, but it should influence us throughout all our treatment of horses;
tgt_text.3885: for a horse will more readily take the bit, if, when he has taken it, something pleasant results to himself;
tgt_text.3886: and he will leap across ditches, and jump over obstacles, and comply with our wishes in all other respects, if he looks forward.
tgt_text.3887: when he has done what is required of him, to some in­ dulgence.
tgt_text.3888: 1. THE directions which I have given show how a person may best avoid being deceived in purchasing a colt or a full- grown horse;
tgt_text.3889: how he is least likely to spoil him in putting him to use, more especially if he would produce a horse having all the qualities that a horseman requires for war.
tgt_text.3890: But per­ haps it is now proper to state how a rider, if he ever happen to have a horse excessively fiery, or excessively sluggish, may treat either of them with the most success.a.
tgt_text.3891: In the first place, then, he ought to know that spirit in a horse is what anger is in a man ;
tgt_text.3892: and as a person who should neither say nor do anything annoying to a man would be least likely to anger him, so the rider that does nothing to vex a high-spirited horse will be least likely to provoke him.
tgt_text.3893: 3. Accordingly he must be careful, even from the very time that he mounts such a horse, not to discompose him as he takes his seat;
tgt_text.3894: and when he is fairly seated, he should allow him to stand quiet for a longer time than a horse of ordinary spirit,1 and then direct him to go forward with the gentlest possible intimations.
tgt_text.3895: Beginning to proceed, too, at the slow­ est pace, he should bring him into a quicker one, in such a manner, that the horse may be as little sensible as possible that he is accelerating his course.
tgt_text.3896: 4. But whatever a rider requires a spirited horse to do suddenly, the unexpected sights, or sounds, or sensations, consequent upon it, annoy him, as they would annoy a passionate man ;
tgt_text.3897: and it is necessary to bear in mind that everything sudden produces perplexity in a horse.
tgt_text.3898: 5. If therefore you wish to rein in a spirited horse when he is going faster than is necessary, you must not check him sud­ denly, but pull him in with the bridle gently, coaxing, and not forcing him, to slacken his pace.
tgt_text.3900: Long rides in a direct course, too, soothe horses more than frequent short turnings ;
tgt_text.3901: and long gentle rides also soft­ en and tame, and do not exasperate, the high-mettled horse.
tgt_text.3902: 7. But if any one imagines that if he rides at a hard pace for a long distance, he will render his horse gentle by fatiguing him, he supposes what is quite contrary to experience ;
tgt_text.3903: for a high- spirited horse, in such circumstances, uses his utmost en­ deavours to get the better by force and with anger, like an angry man, and often does irreparable mischief both to him­ self and to his rider.
tgt_text.3905: It is proper also to check a high-mettled horse from gal­ loping at full speed, and to abstain altogether from matching him with other horses ;
tgt_text.3906: for horses that grow fond of contending against others become also the most refractory.
tgt_text.3908: Smooth bits are more eligible for such a horse than rough.
tgt_text.3909: If a rough bit be used, we ought to assimilate it tc a smooth one by keeping it slack.
tgt_text.3911: It is well, too, for the rider to accustom himself to sit quiet on a fiery-spirited horse, and to touch him as little as possible with anything else2 be­ sides those parts of the body with which we necessarily touch him in order to sit secure.
tgt_text.3913: A rider should know, also, that it is a rule to moderate a horse's pace with a sort of whistle, and to urge him forward with a clucking sound;
tgt_text.3914: yet that if a person should from the first move him to gentle exertions with a clucking sound, and to more difficult efforts with a whistle, he would learn to quicken his pace at the whistle, and to moderate it at the cluck.
tgt_text.3916: Likewise, when a shout is raised, or a trumpet sounded, a person should not appear to a horse to be at all disturbed, or approach him with anything that may alarm him, but should, under such circumstances, use his utmost efforts to pacify him, and, if convenient, should bring him his morning or evening feed.
tgt_text.3918: It is a very judicious piece of advice, too, not to pur­ chase a very high-mettled horse for service in war.
tgt_text.3919: As to a sluggish horse, it appears to me sufficient to observe, that a rider must treat him in a manner quite contrary to that in which we recommend him to treat a horse of high spirit.
tgt_text.3921: BUT whoever would desire to have a horse serviceable for war, and at the same time of a stately and striking figure to ride, must abstain from pulling his mouth with the bit, and from spurring and whipping him ;
tgt_text.3922: practices which some people adopt in the notion that they are setting their horses off;
tgt_text.3923: but they produce a quite contrary effect from that which they intend.
tgt_text.3924: 2. For by drawing the mouths of their horses up, they blind them when they ought to see clearly before them, and they frighten them so much by spurring and strik­ ing them, that they are confused and run headlong into danger ;
tgt_text.3925: acts which distinguish such horses as are most averse to being ridden, and as conduct themselves improperly and unbecomingly.
tgt_text.3926: 3. But if a rider teach his horse to go with the bridle loose, to carry his neck high, and to arch it from the head onwards, he would thus lead him to do everything in which the animal himself takes pleasure and pride.
tgt_text.3928: That he does take pleasure in such actions, we see suf­ ficient proof;
tgt_text.3929: for whenever he approaches other horses, and especially when he comes to mares, he rears his neck aloft, bends his head gallantly, throws out his legs with nimbleness, and carries his tail erect.
tgt_text.3930: 5. When a rider, therefore, can prompt him to assume that figure which he himself assumes when he wishes to set off his beauty, he will thus exhibit his steed as taking pride in being ridden, and having a magnificent, noble, and distinguished appearance.
tgt_text.3931: By what means we consider that such results maybe attained, we will now endeavour to show.
tgt_text.3932: 6. First of all, then, it is necessary for a rider to have not less than two bits ;
tgt_text.3933: and of these let one be smooth, and have rings of a moderate size;
tgt_text.3934: 1 and let the other have rings that are heavy, and hang lower down, with sharp points;
tgt_text.3935: 2 in order that, when the horse takes the latter into his mouth, he may be offended with its roughness, and consequently let it go, but when he finds it exchanged for the other, he may be pleased with its smoothness ;
tgt_text.3936: and that what­ ever he has been trained to do with the rough bit, he may do also with the smooth.
tgt_text.3937: 7. But if, from making light of it for its smoothness, he press upon it frequently with his teethe we in that case add large rings to the smooth bit, that, being compelled by them to open his mouth, he may let go the bit.
tgt_text.3938: But it is possible to vary the rough bit in every way, by re­ laxing or tightening it.
tgt_text.3940: But whatever sorts of bits are used, let them all be yield­ ing ;
tgt_text.3941: for as to a stiff bit, wherever a horse seizes it, he has the whole of it fast between his teeth, as a person, when he takes up a spit, wherever he lays hold of it, raises up the whole.
tgt_text.3942: 9. But the other sort of bit is similar to a chain ;
tgt_text.3943: for of whatever part of it a person takes hold, that part alone re­ mains unbent, but the rest hangs down.
tgt_text.3944: But as the horse is always catching at the part which escapes him in his mouth, he drops the bit out of his jaws;
tgt_text.3945: and to remedy this incon­ venience rings2 are suspended by the middle from the two parts of the bit,3 that while he catches at these with his tongue and his teeth, he may omit to seize the bit between his jaws.
tgt_text.3947: In case any one should be ignorant what flexibility, and rigidity, in a bit are, we will explain the terms ;
tgt_text.3948: for a bit is flexible when the two parts of it have broad and smooth joints, so as to be easily bent;
tgt_text.3949: and everything that is applied about these two parts, if it fit loosely, and not with a close grasp, conduces to flexibility;
tgt_text.3950: but if every part of the bit opens and closes with difficulty, it is to be called hard.
tgt_text.3951: 11. But whatever sort of bit is used, the rider must do everything with it in the manner which I have stated, if he wishes to make his horse such as has been described.
tgt_text.3952: 12. He must pull up the mouth of the horse neither too severely, so as to provoke him to shake himself free from it, nor too gently, so that he may be insensible to it.
tgt_text.3953: But when, on pulling him up, he raises his neck, the rider must immediately give him the bridle.
tgt_text.3954: In other respects, too, as we do not cease to repeat,.
tgt_text.3955: he must, whenever the horse has acquitted himself well, show him some indulgence.
tgt_text.3957: When he perceives that the horse is pleased with carrying his head aloft, and with the looseness of the rein, he should then put him to nothing disagreeable,.
tgt_text.3958: as if he would force him to exert himself, but should coax him, as if he wished him to be at ease;
tgt_text.3959: for thus he will feel greatly encouraged, and will advance of his own accord at a swift pace.
tgt_text.3960: 14. That a horse delights in going fast, there is sufficient proof;
tgt_text.3961: for no horse, on getting loose, goes off at a slow pace, but runs.
tgt_text.3962: With this speed he is naturally delighted, provided we do not compel him to run longer than is reasonable;
tgt_text.3963: for nothing whatever, immoderately protracted, is agreeable to either horse or man.
tgt_text.3965: When the horse was brought to perform his exercise with grace, he was trained by us,1 we know, in the early part of his practice, to advance at full speed after sundry turns.
tgt_text.3966: But if any rider, when his horse has learned to do this, should rein him in, and give him at the same time a signal to hasten forward, the horse, being at once checked by the bridle, and incited to speed by the signal, will advance his chest, and lift his legs higher in anger, but not with ease-;
tgt_text.3967: for horses, when they are annoyed, will assuredly not use their legs with greater agility and grace.
tgt_text.3968: 16. But if when he is thus ani­ mated, the rider gives him the bridle, he will then, from de­ light at supposing himself, on account of the looseness of the bit, freed from its restraint, bound forward with exultation, in a noble attitude, and with an easy motion of his limbs, and expressing in every gesture the grace with which he approaches other horses.
tgt_text.3969: 17. Persons who view such a horse pronounce him noble-spirited, prompt for action, fit for military exercise,, high-mettled, superb, and at once pleasing and formidable to contemplate.
tgt_text.3970: If any one desires such qualities in a horse, let what we have so far written serve as instructions for him.
tgt_text.3971: I. BUT if a person wishes to possess a horse that is fit for processions, and of lofty and magnificent bearing, such qualities are not to be found in every horse, for he must be one that is of a noble spirit and strong frame.
tgt_text.3973: But what some suppose, that a horse which has supple­ ness of leg will also be able to rear his body high, is not the case;
tgt_text.3974: the truth rather is, that it must be a horse which has flexible, short, and strong loins (we do not mean the part by the tail, but that which is between the ribs and the haunches, at the belly), for such a horse will be able to extend his hind­ er legs far forward under him.
tgt_text.3975: 3. If a rider, then, when the horse has his hind legs thus under him, should pull him up with the bridle, he rests his hinder parts on his heels, and rears up the fore part of his body, so that his belly is seen by those in front of him.
tgt_text.3976: But when he does this, it is proper to give him the bridle, that he may assume of his own accord the attitudes most graceful in a horse, and appear to the spectators to do so.
tgt_text.3978: There are people who teach horses thus to rise, some by striking them on the fetlocks with a stick, some by directing a man, who runs at the side for that purpose, to hit them on the upper part of the legs.
tgt_text.3979: 1 5. We however consider it the best mode of instruction, as we are perpetually saying, that when ever a horse acts agreeably to the wishes of his rider, it should follow that he receive some indulgence from him.
tgt_text.3980: 6. For what a horse does under compulsion, as Simo also observes, he does without understanding, and with no more grace than a dancer would display if a person should whip and spur him during his performance;
tgt_text.3981: since both horse and man, When suffering such treatment, would exhibit more ungraceful than graceful gestures.
tgt_text.3982: But the rider ought to teach a horse by signs to assume of his own accord all his most beautiful and showy attitudes.
tgt_text.3983: 7. If, then, when he is exercised, he be ridden till he is quite in a perspiration, and the rider, as soon as he raises himself gracefully, dismounts and unbridles him, he may feel assured that the horse will always be ready to rear himself of his own accord.
tgt_text.3985: It is upon horses of this kind that gods and heroes are painted riding, and men who are able to manage them skil­ fully are regarded as deserving of admiration.
tgt_text.3986: 9. So extremely beautiful, and admirable, and noble a sight is a horse that bears himself superbly, that he fixes the gaze of all who see him, both young and old;
tgt_text.3987: no one, indeed, leaves him, or is tired of con­ templating him, as long as he continues to display his magni­ ficent attitudes.
tgt_text.3989: If it should ever happen to the possessor of such a horse to be a phylarch2 or hipparch,2 he ought not to make it his study that he alone may enjoy distinction, but rather that all the cavalry under his command may be de­ serving of admiration, 11.
tgt_text.3990: Should such a horse precede the rest, [as people esteem such horses most,] 3 one that, as he advances, rears himself very high and very frequently, it is plain that the other horses would follow him at a slow pace;
tgt_text.3991: but what striking attraction could there be in such a specta­ cle ?
tgt_text.3992: 12. If, however, while you animate your steed, you lead neither with too great quickness nor with too great slowness, but just as horses appear most lively and formidable, and best adapted for exertion, if, I say, you precede the other horses in this manner, the march of the whole troop will be uniform, and even the very neighing and snorting of the horses will be in concert, so that not only the commander himself, but the whole troop, will present an admirable spectacle.
tgt_text.3994: If a person be fortunate in purchasing horses, and bring them up to be able to endure fatigue, and train them properly, not only in exercises for war, but in manoeuvres for parade, and in service in the field, what can prevent him, unless some god be adverse to his endeavours, from rendering his horses of far greater value than they were when be took them under his care, or from having not only estimable horses, but being himself greatly admired for his skill in the art of horseman­ ship ?1.
tgt_text.3995: WE wish also to show how he should be armed who pre­ pares to encounter danger on horseback.
tgt_text.3996: In the first place, then, we say that his coat of mail should be made to suit his body;
tgt_text.3997: because the whole of the body sup­ ports one that fits well, but the shoulders only support one that is too loose;
tgt_text.3998: and one that is too tight is a prison, and not a coat of defence.
tgt_text.3999: 2. Since the neck, too, is one of the vital parts, we think that a covering should be made for it of the same shape with the neck, rising from the coat of mail;
tgt_text.4000: for it will not only be an ornament, but, if it be made as it ought to be, will cover the face of the rider, if he wishes, up to the nose.
tgt_text.4002: As for the helmet, we consider that which is of Boeotian manufacture to be the best;
tgt_text.4003: for it protects most effectually all the parts above the corslet, and yet does not prevent the wearer from seeing.
tgt_text.4004: The coat of mail, again, should be made in such a way that it may not prevent the horseman from sitting or stooping.
tgt_text.4005: 4. About the abdomen, too, and the parts below and around, there should be skirts of such a description and size as to pro­ tect the limbs.
tgt_text.4007: Since, also, if the left hand should be hurt, it disables the rider, we recommend the armour which has been invented for it, and which is called the hand;
tgt_text.4008: for it protects the shoulder, the upper part of the arm, the elbow, and the portion of the arm next to the bridle, and can be either expanded or con­ tracted ;
tgt_text.4009: and it also covers the part under the arm which is left unguarded by the coat of mail.
tgt_text.4011: The right hand a rider must raise, when he wishes either to hurl a weapon or to strike a blow.
tgt_text.4012: Whatever portion of the coat of mail, therefore, would obstruct it, must be removed ;
tgt_text.4013: and if in its place a sort of flaps with joints be put, they will, when the arm is raised, unfold at the same time, and, when it is let down, will close.
tgt_text.4015: As to the right arm, that sort of defence which is put on it like greaves on the leg appears to us to be better adapted for protecting it than that which is attached to the coat of mail;
tgt_text.4016: and the part of the arm which is exposed when the right hand is lifted up must be defended near the coat of mail, with a covering made of calf's skin or of brass;
tgt_text.4017: other­ wise it will be left unguarded in a most dangerous place.
tgt_text.4019: Since, too, if the horse is disabled, the rider will be in extreme peril, it is necessary to arm the horse also with de­ fences for his head, his breast, and his shoulders;
tgt_text.4020: for these assist likewise in guarding the rider's thighs.
tgt_text.4021: But of all parts of the horse we take most care to protect his belly, for it is at once a most vital and a most defenceless part;
tgt_text.4022: but it is pos­ sible to protect it by something connected with the housings.)9.
tgt_text.4023: It is necessary, too, that that which covers the horse's back should be put together in such a way that the rider may have a firmer seat,'2 and that the back of the horse may not be galled.
tgt_text.4024: As to other parts, also, both horse and horseman should be armed with the same precaution.
tgt_text.4026: The legs and feet will naturally hang down below the covering of the thighs;
tgt_text.4027: but these parts may be sufficiently protected, if a sort of boots be constructed for them of the leather of which sandals are made ;
tgt_text.4028: for such boots may be at once armour for the legs and shoes for the feet.
tgt_text.4029: 11. Such is the armour that may prove, if the gods be pro­ pitious, a defence against harm.
tgt_text.4030: But to inflict injury on an enemy, we recommend the short curved sword rather than the long straight one;
tgt_text.4031: for from a horseman, seated aloft, a blow from a scymitar will be more effective than one from a straight sword.
tgt_text.4032: 12. Instead of a reed-like spear, as it is weak and inconvenient to carry, we rather approve of two javelins of corneil wood;
tgt_text.4033: for a skilful thrower may hurl one of these, and use the other against assailants either in front, or flank, or rear.
tgt_text.4035: They are at once stronger than a spear, and more easily carried.
tgt_text.4036: 13. We approve of the hurling of a javelin from a great distance;
tgt_text.4037: for by that means more time is allowed for throw­ ing it2 and for taking another weapon.
tgt_text.4038: We shall intimate in a few words how the javelin may be hurled with the greatest effect.
tgt_text.4039: If the rider advance his left side, at the same time drawing back his right, and rising on his thighs, and launch his weapon with its point directed a little upwards, he will thus send it with the greatest force and to the greatest dis­ tance ;
tgt_text.4040: and be will send it with the truest aim, if the point, as it is discharged, is directed steadily to the mark.
tgt_text.4042: Let these admonitions, and instructions, and exercises be considered sufficient to be prescribed for a private individual.
tgt_text.4043: What it is proper for a commander of cavalry to know and to do, is set forth in another treatise.
tgt_text.4044: THE object of this treatise is to show how a commander of the Athenian cavalry may maintain them at the proper number;
tgt_text.4045: how they may be suitably equipped;
tgt_text.4046: and how he may employ them with the greatest efficiency.
tgt_text.4047: It is addressed to some one person.
tgt_text.4048: Camerarius supposes that it was written for the instruction of Xenophon's son Gryllus, who afterwards served in the Athenian cavalry, and whom, he thinks, his father wished to qualify for a commander.
tgt_text.4049: Weiske is inclined to favour Camerarius's opinion.
tgt_text.4050: There were two hipparchs, or chief commanders of the cavalry at Athens.1.
tgt_text.4051: FIRST of all, it is incumbent on you to offer sacrifice, and to entreat the gods to grant you to think, and say, and do those things by which you may exercise your command most agreeably to them, and with the greatest pleasure, and honour, and benefit to yourself, your friends, and your country.
tgt_text.4053: When the gods are propitiated, you must prepare your cavalry, 1 taking care that the number2 prescribed by law may be completed, and that the force previously enrolled may not be diminished ;
tgt_text.4054: for, unless new horsemen are added, the number will constantly grow less, as some must retire from old age, and some must fail from other causes.
tgt_text.4056: After the complement is made up, you must take care that the horses may be fed in such a way as to be able to en­ dure exertion;
tgt_text.4057: for horses that are too weak for their work will be unable either to overtake an enemy or to retreat.
tgt_text.4058: You must make it an object of your attention, too, that they may be fit for service;
tgt_text.4059: for such as are unmanageable are an aid to the enemy rather than to their friends.
tgt_text.4060: 4. Such as kick when they are mounted, also, must be set aside ;
tgt_text.4061: for they often inflict more mischief on their own side than the enemy inflicts
tgt_text.4062: You must pay attention to their feet also, that they may be in a condition to be ridden even on rough ground, knowing that when they suffer from being ridden they become useless.
tgt_text.4064: When you have your horses in proper condition, you must next exercise your men ;
tgt_text.4065: in the first place, that they may be well able to vault on their horses, for by that means safety has been secured by many ;
tgt_text.4066: and in the second, that they may be qualified to ride over every kind of ground, as the enemy will be at different times in different places.
tgt_text.4067: 6. When they are able to sit firm, you must see that they exercise themselves, as much as possible, in throwing javelins on horse­ back, and that they qualify themselves to do everything that cavalry ought to do.
tgt_text.4068: After this, you must arm both your horses and their riders in such a manner that they may be least likely to be wounded, and may be able to do the greatest, possible harm to the enemy.
tgt_text.4070: In the next place, you must make it your care that your men may be obedient;
tgt_text.4071: for without obedience there will be no profit either in good horses, or in firm-seated riders, or in fine arms.
tgt_text.4072: In regard to all these things, then, it is right that a com­ mander of cavalry should give authoritative directions, in order that they may be properly done.
tgt_text.4074: But since the state, thinking it difficult for the corn­ mander of the cavalry to accomplish all these objects with­ out assistance, appoints him the phylarchs1 as coadjutors, and enjoins the senate to support him by giving their attention to the cavalry, it appears to me of great importance that you should prepare the phylarchs to study what is for the advan­ tage of the cavalry as well as yourself, and that you should secure able speakers in the senate, who may, by their remarks, keep the cavalry in awe (for under the influence of fear they will attend to their duties better), and who may pacify the senate, should they show any unreasonable displeasure.
tgt_text.4076: These are suggestions as to the duties to which you must attend.
tgt_text.4077: How each of them may be best discharged I will now endeavour to show.
tgt_text.4078: Into the cavalry, then, it is evident that you must bring, according to the law, such of the citizens as are in the best condition as to pecuniary means and as to bodily strength, either by calling them before the judges or by persuading them.
tgt_text.4079: 10. Before the judges I think that you must summon those, whom if you were not to summon, you would be thought to abstain from doing so from regard to your interest;
tgt_text.4080: for those of inferior meaDS would at once have a ground of excuse, if you should forbear to coerce the most able first of all.
tgt_text.4081: 11. As for the young, you seem likely, in my opinion, to animate them with a desire for cavalry service, if you enlarge to them on the opportunities for distinction in the cavalry ;
tgt_text.4082: and you will be likely to find less opposition from those 2 who have authority over them, if you represent to them that they will be obliged, if not by you, at least by some one else,3 to main­ tain a horse on account of their fortune ;
tgt_text.4084: but that, if their sons engage in the cavalry under you, you will restrain them from expensive and unreasonable purchasing of horses, and will make it your care that they shall soon become able horse­ men ;
tgt_text.4085: and while you say this, you must study to do it.is.
tgt_text.4086: As for those who are in the cavalry service at present, it appears to me that the senate, if they were to give notice that the equestrian exercise will in future be doubled, and that they will reject the horses that cannot keep up with the others, would excite them to feed their horses better, and to pay them more attention.
tgt_text.4087: 14. It seems to me very proper, also, that an announcement should be made that all unruly horses will be rejected ;
