tgt_text.4088: for a threat of that kind would stimulate the owners of such horses to sell them, and purchase others with greater judgment.
tgt_text.4089: 15. It would be well, too, for notice to be given that horses apt to kick during exercise will be reject­ ed ;
tgt_text.4090: for it is impossible to range horses of that description in proper order, and, whenever an advance is to be made upon the enemy, they will of necessity follow in the rear;
tgt_text.4091: so that the rider may be rendered useless by the inefficiency of his horse.
tgt_text.4093: For keeping the feet of the horses in the best condition, if any one has an easier and cheaper method than mine, let it be adopted ;
tgt_text.4094: if not, I recommend, from experience, that the horseman should scatter over the ground stones gathered from the road, of about a pound weight, more or less, and that he should keep the horse standing on such stones while he grooms him, and let him walk upon them whenever he goes out of the stable ;
tgt_text.4095: for thus the horse will be constantly moving his feet on the stones, as well when he is rubbed down as when he is annoyed by flies.
tgt_text.4096: He that makes trial of this suggestion will give credit to others which I shall offer, and will see the feet of his horse become firm.217.
tgt_text.4097: I shall next show how, when the horses are brought into the condition in which they ought to be, the riders may be best trained.
tgt_text.4098: The younger of them I should advise to learn to vault upon their horses ;
tgt_text.4099: and if you assign them a person to teach them, you will justly gain praise for doing so.
tgt_text.4100: The older you may accustom to be mounted with the aid of others, after the Persian manner,3 and may thus be of great service to them.
tgt_text.4101: 18. To lead out the cavalry frequently, however, in order that they may be qualified to keep their seats on every sort of ground, may perhaps appear, when there is no war, somewhat troublesome ;
tgt_text.4102: but it will be proper to call the horse men together, and to advise them to exercise themselves, and then ride out into the country, or anywhere else, to quit the beaten road, and to gallop their horses over ground of all sorts;
tgt_text.4103: for this will be of much the same use as to lead them out, and will cause them less annoyance.
tgt_text.4104: 19. It will be useful to remind them, too, that the state supports an expenditure of nearly forty talents a year for the cavalry, in order that, if war arise, they may not have to seek cavalry, but may make use.
tgt_text.4105: of that which they have at once, as being in proper con­ dition ;
tgt_text.4106: for it is natural that the soldiers, reflecting on this expense, should apply to their exercise with greater diligence, in order that, if war should break out, they may not have to contend, without due preparation, for their country, for glory, and for life.
tgt_text.4108: It will be well for you also to announce to the men, that you will take them out yourself on certain occasions, and will lead them over ground of every description.
tgt_text.4109: In exercises, too, for mock combats, it will be proper to lead them out to differ­ ent places at different times ;
tgt_text.4110: for such charges will be more beneficial both to the riders and to their horses.
tgt_text.4112: As for javelin-throwing on horseback, the greatest number seem to me likely to be induced to practise it;
tgt_text.4113: if you give notice to the phylarchs that they will be required to lead out the javelin-throwers of their several tribes to exercise them­ t'elves with the javelin ;
tgt_text.4114: for they will thus be induced by -ambition, as is probable, to produce respectively as many javelin-throwers as possible for the service of the state.
tgt_text.4115: 22. The phylarchs, too, appear to me likely to contribute most to the horsemen being well armed, if they be persuaded that it will be much more honourable, in the opinion of the state, that they should be adorned by the splendour of their several tribes than merely by their own equipments.
tgt_text.4116: 23. It is probable that they will not be difficult of persuasion as to such points, as they sought the command in their tribes from desire of distinction and honour ;
tgt_text.4117: and they will be able, too, to have their men armed according to law, without incurring any personal expense, by obliging them to equip themselves, as the law directs, out of their own pay.
tgt_text.4119: To render the men obedient, it is important to represent.
tgt_text.4120: in your addresses to them, how many advantages there are in submitting to orders;
tgt_text.4121: and it is of great effect to arrange things go in practice that the orderly may gain something by their good conduct, and the disorderly be in every respect the losers.
tgt_text.4123: But the strongest incitement to the phylarchs to be am­ bitious to bring the men of their several tribes well equipped into the field appears to me to be, that you should adorn your staff-officers 1 about you with arms in the highest degree splendid, and oblige them to exercise themselves in throwing the javelin as frequently as possible, leading them yourself to trials of skill at that weapon, having previously acquired suf­ ficient skill in throwing it yourself.
tgt_text.4124: 26. If any one could offer prizes, moreover, to the several tribes, for excellence in whatever is commonly practised by cavalry on public occasions, I think that such a proposal would have the greatest effect in excit.. ing the Athenians in general to emulation.
tgt_text.4125: It is seen in the case of the choruses how much labour is endured, and how much money expended, to obtain very small prizes.
tgt_text.4126: You should take care, however, to secure judges by whom the can­ didates will be best pleased to be pronounced conquerors.
tgt_text.4128: WHEN your cavalry are well exercised in all these par­ ticulars, they ought next to be taught a certain order, by observing which they may march in processions at the feast of the gods with the greatest precision, may perform their evolutions with the best effect, may fight, if it be necessary, with the greatest success, and may pursue their marches and make their way over obstacles with the utmost ease and the least possible confusion.
tgt_text.4129: What order they may adopt, so as to be likely to accomplish these objects most effectually, I shall now endeavour to show.
tgt_text.4131: Distinct tribes, then, are appointed by the state.
tgt_text.4132: Among these I think that you ought first of all to appoint, with the approbation of each of the phylarchs, captains of ten, selected from the citizens in the vigour of youth, and such as are most ambitious to do something honourable and obtain praise.
tgt_text.4133: These you ought to place in the first rank in each ten.
tgt_text.4134: 3. In the next place, you ought to choose an equal number of the oldest and wisest, who may hold the last rank in the ten ;
tgt_text.4135: for, if I may illustrate my meaning by a comparison, iron penetrates into iron best when the fore part of the cutting instrument is strong, and the hinder part urged with competent force.
tgt_text.4136: 4. As to those who are placed in the middle between the first and the last, if the captains of the tens choose those who are to stand next to them, and the others choose others in like man­ ner, it is likely that each will have a sufficiently trustworthy supporter.
tgt_text.4137: 5. For the leader of each tribe,1 you ought by all means to appoint an able man;
tgt_text.4138: for, if he is brave, he will, whenever he is to march against the enemy, inspire those in front with ardour by his exhortations;
tgt_text.4139: or, if circumstances re­ quire him to retreat, he will be more likely, by drawing off his troop judiciously, to preserve the men of his tribe.
tgt_text.4140: 6. If the captains of ten, again, are of an even number,2 they will afford facilities for dividing them into more equal parts than if they be of an odd number.
tgt_text.4141: This arrangement pleases me for these reasons, that, in the first place, all those in the first rank are officers, and men when they are in command think it more incumbent on them to do something honourable than when they are mere privates ;
tgt_text.4142: and, secondly, that when anything is to be done, an order has far more effect when it comes, not from privates, but from officers.
tgt_text.4144: When this order is established, then, as the place of the phylarchs, in which each of them is to ride, is appointed by the comnmander-in-chief, so the places for the captains of tens, where they are severally to march, must be appointed by the captains of tribes;
tgt_text.4145: for, when such appointments are made, things will be in far better order than if they run against one another, going wherever chance may lead them, like people coming out of a theatre.
tgt_text.4146: 8. Those in the first rank, too, will be more disposed to fight, if any opposition appear in front of them, when they know that the front is their proper place;
tgt_text.4147: and those in the rear, if an enemy appears behind them, will be more ready to exert themselves, as they know that it will be a disgrace to them to leave their post.
tgt_text.4148: 9. But if they are without any regular order, they throw one another into confusion in defiles and passages of rivers, and no one of his own accord takes a post in face of the enemy.
tgt_text.4149: All these particulars ought to be carefully studied by the cavalry universally, if they would be staunch supporters to their leader.
tgt_text.4151: THE following matters must be the business of the com­ mander-in-chief alone.
tgt_text.4153: First, that he may obtain favourable omens from the gods, on behalf of the cavalry, by offering sacrifices;
tgt_text.4154: next, that he may render the processions, on festal occasions, worthy of being seen;
tgt_text.4155: and, in addition, that he may exhibit whatever spectacles he has to produce for the public in the best possible manner, whether in the Academia, in the Lyceum, the Phaleron,2 or the Hippodrome.
tgt_text.4156: The latter will form subjects for particular admonitions.
tgt_text.4157: But how each of these general divisions may be best ordered, I shall here attempt to show.
tgt_text.4159: As to the processions, then, I think that they may be rendered most acceptable, as well to the gods as to the specie tors, if, whatever deities have temples and statues in the forum, the cavalry should march round to those statues and temples, beginning with those of Hermes, and circumambulating the forum in honour of those deities.
tgt_text.4160: At the festival of Bacchus, the choruses offer homage, by their dancing, to other gods besides the twelve.
tgt_text.4161: When they have ridden round, and have come to the statues of Hermes again, it seems to me that it will be well for them to ride their horses at a quick pace from thence, one tribe after another, to the temple of Eleusinian Ceres.3.
tgt_text.4162: Nor will I omit to mention how their lances may be car­ ried so as least to interfere one with another;
tgt_text.4163: for each mark should hold his lance between the ears of his horse, if the­ weapons are to look formidable and distinct, and at the same­ time to present the appearance of a multitude.
tgt_text.4165: When they have made an end of riding at a quick pace,, it will be proper for them to ride steadily back, at the other pace, 1 by the same route as before, to the temples again ;
tgt_text.4166: and thus whatever manoeuvres are performed on mounted horses.
tgt_text.4167: will have been fully displayed both to gods and men.5.
tgt_text.4168: That the cavalry are not accustomed to these perform­ ances I am well aware;
tgt_text.4169: but I think that they will be be­ coming and attractive, and afford pleasure to the spectators-
tgt_text.4170: I find also that the cavalry have executed other new evolu­ tions, when their commanders-in-chief were able to prevail on them to do what they wished.
tgt_text.4172: When they ride in the Lyceum, before they engage in throwing the javelin, it will be well for the tribes to ride­ five on each side with an extended front,2 as if prepared for battle, with the commander-in-chief and the captains of the­ tribes at their head, in such array as to cover the whole- breadth of the course.
tgt_text.4173: 7. But when they have passed the ex­ tremity3 of the theatre opposite to them,4 I think it will be a fine sight, if you show that the cavalry can ride at a quick pace down the steep, as many abreast as is suitable for the­ ground.
tgt_text.4174: 8. Nor am I ignorant that they will perform this duty with the greatest pleasure, if they but feel confident that they will be able to ride fast;
tgt_text.4175: but if they remain unexercised in this respect, you will have to take care lest the enemy may at some time force them to practise it.
tgt_text.4177: The order has now been stated1 in which, in the exercises for approval,2 the cavalry may ride with the best effect.
tgt_text.4179: fthe leader, provided that he have a strong horse, constantly rides round about3 on the outside rank, he will thus continu­ ally ride at a quick pace himself, and those who are on the outside with him will ride at a quick pace in their turn, so that the senate4 will always have before them the portion which is advancing rapidly, and the horses will not be wearied, as they will rest in succession.
tgt_text.4181: But when the exhibition is to be made in the hippo­ drome, it will be well to arrange the cavalry, at first, in such a manner that they may cover the hippodrome with the extent of their line, and clear all the people from the midst of it.
tgt_text.4182: 11. It will be proper, too, when the tribes in the mock com­ bats5 pursue and flee from one another at full speed, and when the officers are at the head of the five tribes,6 that the tribes on either side should ride through the spaces between the other tribes;
tgt_text.4183: for in such a spectacle, when they ride front to front against each other, there is something that produces awe, and something imposing when, after having ridden over the hippodrome, they assume a position facing one another;
tgt_text.4184: and it is a noble sight, when, at the next sound of the trum­ pet, they ride towards one another with increased speed.
tgt_text.4185: 12. When they have come to a stand again, they must rush a third time, at the sound of the trumpet, towards one another at their utmost speed;
tgt_text.4186: and, when they have ridden their course, they must, to bring the spectacle to a conclusion, form in one body, and, as is your custom, ride forwards towards the senate.
tgt_text.4187: 13. Such evolutions would appear to me to present something more warlike, and something more novel, than is usual ;
tgt_text.4188: but for a commander-in-chief to ride slower than the captains of tribes, or to manoeuvre exactly in the same manner as they, is unbecoming his office.
tgt_text.4189: 14. When you have to exhibit the cavalry in the Academia, however, on hard ground, 1 I would offer the following hints for your observation :
tgt_text.4190: that the men, to secure themselves from falling off their horses, should lean back as they ride, and that, to prevent the horses from falling, they should keep up their heads with the bridle whenever they wheel round.
tgt_text.4191: When they ride straight forward, however, they ought to ride at a quick pace, for thus the senate will have before them an exhibition free from danger and of great attraction.
tgt_text.4193: ON marches, the commander of cavalry ought constantly to consider how he may give rest to the backs of his horses, and afford relief to the riders as they proceed,2 whether by riding at a moderate pace, or by dismounting and walking at a moderate pace.
tgt_text.4194: In maintaining this moderate pace you will not fail, if you pay proper attention to the matter ;
tgt_text.4195: for every man can judge from himself, so as not to be unaware when others are over-fatigued.
tgt_text.4196: 2. When, however, you are march­ ing to any particular place, and it is uncertain whether you may fall in with the enemy, you must let the tribes rest only in turns, for it would be dangerous if the enemy should come upon you when all your men are dismounted.
tgt_text.4197: 3. If, again, you have to march through narrow passes, you must lead on your men, at the word of command, in single file ;
tgt_text.4198: if you come into broad roads, you must, at the word of command, extend the front of each tribe ;
tgt_text.4199: and when you come forth into open plains, you must form all the tribes in a solid body ;
tgt_text.4200: for it is well to execute these movements even for the sake of exercise, and it is more agreeable, as you pursue your route, to vary the modes of marching in the different companies.
tgt_text.4202: When you march out of the beaten road, and over diffi­ cult ground, it will be very proper, not only in a hostile but in a friendly country, that some of the inferior officers should ride on in advance of each tribe ;
tgt_text.4203: who, if they meet with im­ passable woods, may seek unobstructed ways, and point out to the rest of the cavalry where they must direct their march, so that whole companies may not stray from one another.
tgt_text.4204: 5. If you march in expectation of encountering dangers, it is the part of a prudent commander to see that extraordinary scouts go before the ordinary ones to ascertain the position of the enemy.
tgt_text.4205: It is proper, also, both with reference to attacking and for keeping on guard, that at the crossing of rivers the soldiers should wait for one another, that those who get over last may not fatigue their horses by hastening after their leader.
tgt_text.4206: Almost all officers know the propriety of this, but there are not many willing to take the trouble of constantly attending to it.
tgt_text.4208: It is the duty of a commander of cavalry in time of peace, also, to study to acquire an exact knowledge, as well of the enemy's country, as of his own ;
tgt_text.4209: and if he cannot obtain such knowledge personally, he may keep about him men that are well acquainted with the several parts of both countries ;
tgt_text.4210: for a leader who knows the roads is a totally different person from one who is ignorant of them ;
tgt_text.4211: and, in forming plans against the enemy, he who has a knowledge of the country has a vast advantage over him who is a stranger to it.
tgt_text.4212: 7. When you are procuring spies, too, before a war is actually begun, you ought to take care that they may be taken from towns friendly to both parties, and from merchants ;
tgt_text.4213: for all towns receive as friends those who bring anything with them;
tgt_text.4214: and such persons are sometimes useful as pretended deserters.
tgt_text.4215: 8. You ought never to trust to your spies, however, so far as to neglect to keep on your guard, but you should always be as well prepared as if the enemy were reported to be approaching;
tgt_text.4216: for however trust­ worthy the spies may be, it may be difficult for them to bring information in time, since many obstacles occur in war.9.
tgt_text.4217: The enemy will be least likely to observe the march of cavalry out of the camp, if it be conducted by notice commu­ nicated from man to man rather than by announcement made by a herald or by a written order.
tgt_text.4219: Besides leading out the troops, too, by notice from man to man, it will be proper to appoint captains of ten, and captains of five under the captains of ten, that each may have to give orders to as few as possible, and also that the captains of five may extend the front of the troop by bringing forward their men, as they may do without confusion, whenever there is occasion.
tgt_text.4221: Whenever it is necessary to guard against surprise, I always recommend watches to beset, and sentinels to be posted, with secrecy;
tgt_text.4222: for thus, while they are a security to their friends, they are rendered as it were an ambush for the enemy.
tgt_text.4223: 11. The watch themselves, too, when they are concealed, are less liable to surprise, and much more to be dreaded by the enemy ;
tgt_text.4224: for though the enemy may know that there are advanced guards somewhere, yet, if they know not where they are, or what is their number, their ignorance deprives them of all feeling of security, and compels them to regard every spot with suspicion ;
tgt_text.4225: while guards posted openly show them at once what they have to fear, and how far they may be free from apprehension.
tgt_text.4226: 12. He also that has parties on guard posted secretly, will be able, by sending out a small party openly in advance of those that are concealed, to endeavour to draw the enemy into an ambush.
tgt_text.4227: Another way of occasionally surprising the enemy, also, is to post parties that are visible behind those that are concealed;
tgt_text.4228: and this may be as effective in deceiving an antagonist as the method previously mentioned.
tgt_text.4229: 13. It is indeed the part of a prudent commander never to expose himself to danger, except when he has previously made it clear that he will have the ad­ vantage over his adversaries.
tgt_text.4230: But for him to offer favourable opportunities of which the enemy may take advantage,2 may be justly considered rather a betrayal of his party,J than a display of fortitude.
tgt_text.4231: 14. It is judicious, moreover, to make­ an attack on the enemy in the part where he is weakest, though that part may be at some distance;
tgt_text.4232: for to endure the fatigue of a long march is less dangerous than to contend against a superior force.
tgt_text.4233: 15. Should the enemy advance between two fortified places that are friendly to you, it will be well, even though they are far superior to you in number, to attack them on that wing on which you may approach them unobserved ;
tgt_text.4234: or it will be well even to attack them on both wings at once ;
tgt_text.4235: for, whenever one of your parties has to retire,2 the other,, riding up on the opposite side, may throw the enemy into confusion and assist in bringing off their friends.
tgt_text.4237: That it is proper to endeavour to learn the state of the enemy's affairs by means of scouts, has been long ago said ;
tgt_text.4238: 3 but I think it best of all for the general himself to watch the enemy, if he can, from some safe position, and observe whether they commit any error.
tgt_text.4239: 17. Whatever may be taken from them secretly, too, it is well to send a competent detachment to bring off;
tgt_text.4240: and whatever can be snatched from them openly,, it is proper to despatch troops openly to seize.
tgt_text.4241: If, again, when the enemy are on the march, any part of their force, weaker than your own, is detached from the main body, or strays from it through too great self-confidence, you must not fail to take advantage of such an opportunity ;
tgt_text.4242: but you must always take care to pursue such weaker body with a force stronger than itself, is.
tgt_text.4243: You may also, by giving your attention, profit by the following observations in regard to animals.
tgt_text.4244: Since birds and beasts of prey, which are inferior in intellect to man, as kites for instance, will seize on what­ ever is left unguarded, and retreat to a place of safety before they are captured, and wolves will hunt cattle that are with­ out protection, or steal such as are in places unwatched, and if a dog cornea in pursuit of one of them, he will, if the dog is weaker than himself, attack him, or, if he is stronger, will kill the animal that he is carrying, and make off;
tgt_text.4246: and since wolves, too, when they think themselves stronger3 than those who are keeping guard, appoint some of their number to drive off the guard, and others to carry away the cattle, and thus secure subsistence for themselves ;
tgt_text.4248: does it not become man, when beasts can carry off their prey with so much cunning, to show himself wiser than beasts, which are themselves caught by the art of man ?1.
tgt_text.4249: A MAN who has the charge of cavalry ought also to know in what distance a horse can overtake a person on foot, and at what distance slow horses may escape from such as are swifter.
tgt_text.4251: It becomes a commander of cavalry to understand, too, on what kinds of ground foot are preferable to horse, and when horse are preferable to foot.
tgt_text.4252: 2. He should be fertile also in contrivances, and know how to make a small body of cavalry appear large, and a large one appear but small;
tgt_text.4253: how to make the enemy imagine that he is absent when he is pre­ sent, and present when he is absent;
tgt_text.4254: and how, not only to conceal the state of things among the enemy from his own men, but, by concealing the movements of his own men from the enemy, to attack them unawares.
tgt_text.4255: It is an excellent arti­ fice, also, to contrive, when you are weaker than the enemy, to strike terror into them, that they may not attack you;
tgt_text.4256: and, when you are stronger, to create a false confidence in them, that they may come to a battle;
tgt_text.4257: for thus you yourself are least likely to suffer loss, and are in the best condition to take advantage of any error on the part of the enemy.
tgt_text.4259: That I may not be thought to prescribe what is impossi­ ble, I will explain how that which appears most difficult in such proceedings may be accomplished.
tgt_text.4260: 4. Security from failure, then, when attempting to pursue or retreat, a know­ ledge of the strength of his horses will give.
tgt_text.4261: But how can he obtain this knowledge ?
tgt_text.4262: By observing, in the mock fights during peace, how the horses hold out in pursuit and re­ treat.
tgt_text.4263: 5. When you wish your cavalry to appear numerous, let it be your first consideration whether there be a fair opportunity for doing so, that you may not attempt to deceive the enemy when you are close upon them;
tgt_text.4264: for it is safer to try such deceit at a distance, and it is more likely to be successful.
tgt_text.4265: You must then bear in mind that horses appear numerous when they are in a close body, on account of the size of the animal, but that, when they are scattered about, they are easily counted.
tgt_text.4266: 6. Your cavalry may also be made to appear more numerous than they are, if you station the grooms1 between the horsemen, holding spears, if possible, or, if not, something resembling spears, in their hands;
tgt_text.4267: and this you may do whether you exhibit the cavalry standing still, or whether you are leading it along, for the mass of a troop must thus always appear greater and denser.
tgt_text.4268: 7. Should you, on the other hand, wish a large number to seem small, it is plain that, if there be grounds at hand to admit of conceal­ ment, you may keep some of your men on the open parts, and place others out of sight, and thus disguise their number;
tgt_text.4269: but if the country is entirely open, you must range your men by tens in single file,2 and lead them on with an interval between the files, and you must make the men of each ten immediately in front of the enemy hold their lances erect, while the rest keep them down and out of sight.
tgt_text.4270: 8. To alarm the enemy you may adopt pretended ambuscades, may feign to send suc­ cour to this or that quarter, or may circulate false reports.
tgt_text.4271: The enemy, however, are always boldest when they hear that their adversaries have plenty of trouble or occupation.
tgt_text.4273: Having laid down these precepts, I shall add that a commander ought always to be on the alert to deceive the enemy, so as to take advantage of present circumstances ;
tgt_text.4274: for in reality nothing is more useful in war than deceit.
tgt_text.4275: 10. And when even children, as they play at guessing numbers,' are able to deceive by making pretences, so that, when they have but few, they may appear to have many, and, when they bring forward many, may appear to have but few, how can it be impossible for men, when they apply their minds to de­ ceive, to be able to contrive similar stratagems?
tgt_text.4276: 11. If a person reflects upon the various advantages that have been obtained in wars, he will find that the most and greatest have been obtained by stratagems.
tgt_text.4277: For which reason a man must either never attempt to be a commander, or he must suppli­ cate the gods that he may be able to unite this accomplish­ ment with others, and he himself must strive to excel in it.
tgt_text.4279: For commanders who have sea at hand, it is an excel­ lent mode of deceiving the enemy, to seem to be fitting out ships, and in the mean time to carry into execution some enterprise by land, or, while they pretend to be forming de­ signs by land, to make some attempt by sea.
tgt_text.4281: It is the duty of a commander of cavalry, too, to impress upon the state how weak cavalry is, when unsupported by infantry, against an enemy that has cavalry united with his infantry.
tgt_text.4282: It is the duty also of a commander of cavalry, when he has infantry given him, to use them with effect.
tgt_text.4283: He may conceal his infantry, too, not only among his cavalry, but behind them;
tgt_text.4284: for a horseman obstructs the view far more than a foot soldier.
tgt_text.4285: 14. But all such stratagems, and what­ ever others he may contrive in addition to them, when he wishes to get the advantage of the enemy either by force or by art, I recommend him to try only under the favour of the gods, so that, when the gods are propitious, fortune may be on his side.
tgt_text.4287: It is sometimes an effectual mode of deceit to make it appear that you are extremely cautious, and utterly averse to risk;
tgt_text.4288: for this often leads the enemy to be less on their guard, and to commit more mistakes.
tgt_text.4289: On the other hand, if a com­ mander appears on some occasions to be venturesome, he may, even while he continues quiet, yet feigns to be preparing for some enterprise, cause the enemy much anxiety.
tgt_text.4290: I. BUT no workman can fashion anything as he wishes unless the materials from which he has to fashion it be pre­ pared to his hand, so that they may obey his pleasure;
tgt_text.4291: nor can a commander do what he pleases with men, unless they be so disposed, with the help of the gods, as to have a friend­ ly feeling towards him, and a conviction that he has more skill than themselves in ordering battles with an enemy.
tgt_text.4292: 2. A friendly feeling it is likely that the troops will entertain to­ wards him, if he shows that he takes thought for them, that they may have provisions, may retire to a secure camp, and rest under a sufficient guard.
tgt_text.4293: 3. In the field 1 he must let it be seen that he pays attention to the fodder for the horses, the tents, the water, the posting of sentinels, and all other necessary matters, exercising his forethought, and even de­ priving himself of sleep, for the good of those under his com­ mand.
tgt_text.4294: When the commander has abundance of anything, it will be for his interest to share it with his men.
tgt_text.4295: 4. Contempt for a commander they will be very unlikely to feel, if, to say all in a few words, he appears to do whatever he orders them to do better than they.
tgt_text.4296: 5. Beginning, therefore, with the mounting of their horses, he ought to exercise them in every sort of equestrian accomplishment, that they may see that their leader is able to cross ditches on horseback with safety, to leap over walls, to jump down from heights, and to throw his javelin efficiently;
tgt_text.4297: for all such qualifications contribute to protect him from being undervalued.
tgt_text.4298: 6. If they feel assured, too, that he is skilful in directing affairs, and able to secure them advantages over the enemy ;
tgt_text.4299: if they are impressed also with the belief that he will not lead them against the enemy rashly, or without the approbation of the gods, or in oppo­ sition to the auspices;
tgt_text.4300: all such feelings will render troops more submissive to their commander.
tgt_text.4302: IT belongs, doubtless, to every commander to be pru­ dent;
tgt_text.4303: but the commander of the cavalry of the Athenians ought to be far superior to others, both in showing respect for the gods and in military qualifications, as he has enemies bordering on his country who have as many cavalry as him­ self, and a large force of heavy-armed infantry.
tgt_text.4304: 2. Should he then attempt to invade the enemy's country without the sup­ port of the other troops of the state, he would have to main­ tain a perilous contest against the enemy's cavalry and in­ fantry with his cavalry only.
tgt_text.4305: Should the enemy, on the other hand, invade the country of the Athenians, they would not come, in the first place, without other cavalry united with their own, and, in the second place, without such a number of infantry that they would consider all the Athenians together unable to oppose them in the field.
tgt_text.4306: 3. If, however, the whole people should go forth against such an enemy, with a resolution to defend their territory, favourable hopes might be entertained;
tgt_text.4307: for the cavalry, if their commander pays due attention to them, will be, with the help of the gods, superior to those of the enemy;
tgt_text.4308: the infantry will not be inferior to theirs in number, nor will they have the disadvantage in bodily strength, while in their minds they will be even more ambitious of distinction, if, un­ der the favour of the gods, they be properly exercised.
tgt_text.4309: On their ancestors, certainly, the Athenians pride themselves no less than the Bœotians.
tgt_text.4310: 4. But should the people turn their thoughts towards the sea, and think it sufficient to save merely their walls, as at the time when the Lacedæmonians invaded the country in conjunction with all the other Greeks,1 and should they appoint the cavalry to defend the parts outside the walls, and to hazard a contest, themselves alone, against all the in­ vaders, I think that in that case there would be need, above all, of powerful support from the gods, and that it will be proper, in addition, for the commander of the cavalry to be an extremely accomplished leader ;
tgt_text.4311: for he will require great judgment to act against an enemy far more numerous than his own troops, and great boldness to take advantage of an oppor­ tunity whenever one may present itself.
tgt_text.4313: It is necessary also, as it appears to me, that he should be able to sustain personal fatigue ;
tgt_text.4314: 2 for otherwise, having to contend at his peril with an army before him, to which not even the whole state would be willing to oppose itself, it is evident that he would have to submit to whatever those stronger than himself chose to impose upon him, and would be able to make not even a semblance of defence.
tgt_text.4315: 6. But if he should protect the grounds without the walls, with such a number of men as would suffice to watch the motions of the enemy, and be able to retreat into a place of safety after having observed whatever might be requisite,3 (and a small number may be not less able to reconnoitre than a larger one,) and those who are too timid to trust either to themselves or their horses may be as well qualified for going out to watch,, and returning to their friends, as others, (for fear appears to be a powerful incentive to keeping guard), and a commander might perhaps accordingly decide rightly in taking guards from these;
tgt_text.4316: but if, when he has with him those who are not wanted for the guard, he considers that he has an army, it will certainly appear to him but.
tgt_text.4317: a small one, for it will be alto­ gether too weak to make head against the enemy in the field.
tgt_text.4318: But if he employs them as flying parties, he may find their force, as it would appear, quite sufficient for that duty.
tgt_text.4319: It behoves him, however, as it seems to me, to keep his men 1 always ready for action, and to be on the watch for any secret movement of the enemy's army, in case that they should be guilty of any error.
tgt_text.4320: 9. The more numerous an army is, in­ deed, the more faults the men are accustomed to commit;
tgt_text.4321: for they either scatter themselves about for the purpose of getting provisions,2 or, marching with too little regard to order, some go before, and others fall behind, farther than is proper.
tgt_text.4323: Such negligences you should not suffer to be committed with impunity, (for if you do so, the whole country will be one camp,)3 taking good care, however, if you undertake any expe­ dition, to make a hasty retreat before the great bpdy of the enemy can come to the aid of their party.
tgt_text.4325: An army on the march often comes into roads in which a large number of men can do no more than a small one ;
tgt_text.4326: and at the crossings of the rivers it is possible for a commander who is on the alert, and who pursues with caution, to manage in such a manner that he may attack as many of his adver­ saries at once as he pleases.
tgt_text.4327: 12. Sometimes it is advantageous, too, to make attacks on the enemy when they are at their morning or evening meal, or when they are rising from their beds;
tgt_text.4328: for at all such times the troops are unarmed, the in­ fantry for a shorter, and the cavalry for a longer time.
tgt_text.4329: 13. On their sentinels and outposts you should never cease to make attempts ;
tgt_text.4330: for these are always few in number, and are sometimes stationed far away from the main body.
tgt_text.4331: 14. Should the enemy guard such posts well, it will not be amiss to pass them secretly, and penetrate into the enemy's ground, relying on the support of the gods, and after having first ascertained what force is at each station, and the exact spots where they are placed;
tgt_text.4332: for no prize is so honourable as the capture of an enemy's advanced guard.
tgt_text.4334: Guards, indeed, are very easily deceived;
tgt_text.4335: since they are ready to pursue whatever small force they see, imagining that this is a part of their duty.
tgt_text.4336: You must have a care, however, as to the direction of your retreat that it may not be on that side where the enemy will come to the succour of their party.
tgt_text.4337: I.1 THOSE, however, who would be able to annoy a much stronger army than their own, ought to have so much the ad­ vantage over their enemies in military skill, that they them­ selves may appear accomplished in all kinds of equestrian ex­ ercises, and their adversaries utterly unpractised in them.
tgt_text.4338: 2. The first requisite to this is, that those who are to engage in predatory excursions should be so inured to the fatigue of riding, that they may be prepared to endure every sort of military exertion;
tgt_text.4339: for horses and men that are unaccustomed to such duty would appear like women going to fight against men.
tgt_text.4340: 3. But those who are taught and accustomed to leap across ditches, to vault over walls, to spring up on eminences, to descend from them with safety, and to ride at full speed down steep grounds, will have as much advantage over those who are unpractised in such exercises as winged animals have over those that can only walk.
tgt_text.4341: Those, again, whose feet are hardened with exercise will be as superior on rough ground to those who are not habituated to it, as persons who are sound in their limbs are to those who are lame;
tgt_text.4342: and those who are acquainted with the face of a country will as much sur­ pass those who are unacquainted with it, in advancing and re­ treating, as those who have sight would surpass the blind.
tgt_text.4343: 4. A commander should understand, moreover, that horses in good Condition are such as are well fed, but at the same time exer­ cised so effectually that they will not lose their wind under fatigue.
tgt_text.4344: And as bits and housings for horses can be useful only when they are fitted with straps, a commander of cavalry should never be without straps;
tgt_text.4345: for he may at a small expense put those who are in want of them in an efficient con­ dition.
tgt_text.4347: Should any officer think that he shall have too much trouble if he must thus exercise his cavalry, let him reflect that those who exercise themselves in gymnastic games un­ dergo far greater labour and trouble than those who practise equestrian exercises to the utmost degree;
tgt_text.4348: for the greater part of gymnastic exercises are performed with extreme ex­ ertion, but most of those of an equestrian kind with pleasure.
tgt_text.4349: 6. Should a man pray, indeed, to become a winged animal, there is no human accomplishment that would bring him so near to the object of his wishes as horsemanship.
tgt_text.4350: 7. To gain a victory in the field of battle is far more glorious than to gain one in a pugilistic contest;
tgt_text.4351: for the state has a share in such honour,1 and it is through success in war that the gods, for the most part, crown communities with prosperity;
tgt_text.4352: so that I know not why it is proper to practise any kind of exercises more than those of a warlike nature.
tgt_text.4353: 8. We may consider, also, that it is only through being inured to toil that the pi­ rates are enabled to live on the property of those who are far stronger then themselves.
tgt_text.4354: On land, too, it is not the part of those who reap the fruit of their own grounds, but of those who are in want of sustenance, to commit depredations on others;
tgt_text.4355: for they must either cultivate the ground themselves, or live on the produce of the labour of others, since by no other means is it possible either to secure life or enjoy peace.
tgt_text.4357: You must likewise bear in mind that you must never, when you make an attack with cavalry on a superior force, leave any ground behind you which is difficult for the horses to cross;
tgt_text.4358: for to be unhorsed is far more perilous to him who is retreating than to him who is pursuing.10.
tgt_text.4359: I would wish to remind you, also, that you ought to be very cautious in the following respects;
tgt_text.4360: for there are some commanders who, when they are going against an enemy to whom they think themselves superior, set out with a very small force, so that they often suffer what they hoped to in­ dict ;
tgt_text.4361: and, when they proceed against an enemy to whom they are quite certain that they are inferior, they take with them all the troops that they can command.
tgt_text.4362: 11. But I am of opin­ ion that you ought to act in a quite contrary manner;
tgt_text.4363: when a commander leads out his troops in the expectation that he shall conquer, I think that he should not spare his force, whatever he has ;
tgt_text.4364: for to have obtained an overwhelming vic­ tory has never been a cause of repentance to any leader.
tgt_text.4365: 12. But when he makes an attempt upon an enemy far superior in number, and foresees that, after doing his utmost, he will still be obliged to retreat, I assert that, in such a case, it is much better for him to lead a few of his men, than the whole of them, to the charge, but that he should take the flower of his force, the best of his men, and the best of his horses;
tgt_text.4366: for, being of that description, they will be able to execute any enterprise, and secure a retreat, with most safety.
tgt_text.4367: 13. But when he leads all his force against a superior enemy, and wishes to retreat, it must happen that those who are on the slowest horses will be overtaken, while others will fall off from unskilfulness in riding, and others will be intercepted through the difficulties of the ground;
tgt_text.4368: for it is hard to find any large extent of ground exactly such as you would wish.
tgt_text.4369: 14. They may also, from being numerous, run against each other, impede one another's progress, and do much damage.
tgt_text.4370: But good horses and men will be able to escape from the hands of the enemy,l especially if the commander contrive to threaten the pursuers with that portion of his cavalry that has remained behind.
tgt_text.4372: For this purpose, pretended ambushes are ser­ viceable ;
tgt_text.4373: and it will be useful for him also to discover at what point some of his own party may show themselves with safety so as to retard the course of the pursuers.
tgt_text.4374: 16. It is manifest, too, that where exertion and expedition are required, a smaller number will have the advantage over a larger, rather than a larger over a smaller;
tgt_text.4375: not that I say that the smaller number will be more efficient and expeditious because it is smaller, but that it is easier to find a small number who will take care of themselves and their horses, and who will practise horse­ manship with skill, than a large one.
tgt_text.4377: If it even happen that a commander has to contend with a body of cavalry exactly equal in number to his own, I think that it will not be amiss for him to form two troops out of each tribe, of which the phylarch may command one, and the other whosoever appears best qualified.
tgt_text.4378: 18. The latter leader may follow with his troop, for a time, at the rear of the troop under the phylarch;
tgt_text.4379: and when the enemy come close up, he may, at the word of command, ride forward to attack them;
tgt_text.4380: for by this method I think that they will cause more alarm to the enemy, and will be more difficult to withstand.
tgt_text.4381: 19. Should both the leaders also have infantry with them, and should these be concealed behind the cavalry, and, discovering themselves suddenly, close with the enemy, they seem likely to contribute much more by that means to secure a victory;
tgt_text.4382: for I see that what is unexpected, if it be good, gives people much more pleasure, and, if it is something formidable, causes them much more alarm.
tgt_text.4383: 20. This any per­ son may very well understand, who reflects how much those are startled that fall into an ambuscade, even though they be much superior in numbers;
tgt_text.4384: and how much greater terror, when two armies are encamped opposite to one another, is felt during the first days after their meeting.
tgt_text.4385: 21. To order these matters, however, is not difficult;
tgt_text.4386: but to secure men who will act against the enemy with prudence, fidelity, zeal, and courage, requires great ability in a commander ;
tgt_text.4388: for he ought to be qualified to speak and to act in such a manner that those who are under his command may feel convinced that it is advantageous for them to obey him, to follow him as their leader, and to engage the enemy under his direction, and that they may feel a desire for praise, and a resolution to persevere in whatever course they adopt.
tgt_text.4390: If, on any occasion, when two camps lie face to face, or two fortresses belonging to the opposite parties, there occur returns to the charge,1 and pursuits, and retreats2 of the cavalry in the space between them, both parties are for the most part accustomed, in such cases, to advance slowly on re­ turning to a charge, and then to ride over the intermediate space at full speed.
tgt_text.4391: 24. But if any commander, letting it be supposed that he will act thus, nevertheless, on wheeling about, charges with speed and retires with speed, he may thus, as is apparent, do most damage to the enemy, and con­ sult best for his own safety, riding forward quickly while he is near the strength of his own side, and retreating quickly from before the strength of the enemy.
tgt_text.4392: 25. If he could con­ trive to leave unobserved,3 too, four or five of the best horses and men of each troop, they would be of great weight in charging the enemy as they are returning to the attack.
tgt_text.4394: As to reading these precepts, it will be sufficient for a commander to peruse them but a very few times;
tgt_text.4395: but, in action, he ought to be constantly ready to take advantage of whatever opportunity may occur, and, looking to that which offers itself, to work out that which is expedient.
tgt_text.4396: To com­ mit to writing everything that he ought to do is no more pos- sible than to know everything that will happen.
tgt_text.4397: 2. Of all ad­ monitions, however, the best seems to me to be, that whatever he discovers to be advantageous, he should take care that it be carried into execution;
tgt_text.4398: for neither in agriculture, nor in navigation, nor in military management, does accurate know­ ledge produce any effect, unless the possessor of it takes care that it be carried into practice.3.
tgt_text.4399: I give it as my opinion, however, that the whole body of cavalry may, with the assistance of the gods, be kept up to the number of a thousand1 with greater expedition, and with much more ease to the citizens, if they should admit two hundred foreign soldiers as mercenaries;
tgt_text.4400: as these, if united with the rest, seem likely to render the whole of the cavalry more obedient 2 and more emulous of one another in valour;
tgt_text.4401: for I know that the cavalry of the Lacedæmonians began to be distinguished when they admitted foreigners into it.
tgt_text.4402: 4. I see that in other states too, in all countries, foreign soldiers are held in much esteem;
tgt_text.4405: For purchasing horses I consider that the citizens may secure funds from those who are strongly averse to cavalry service, (for persons of that character, on whom that service falls, will be willing to pay the cavalry-tax that they may be exempt from it,) and from other persons that are rich, but too weak for bodily exertion ;
tgt_text.4406: and I think that contributions might be exacted from orphans4 that have estates able to pay.
tgt_text.4407: 6. I am of opinion also, that if some of the metœcs were re­ ceived into the cavalry, they would show a desire for distinc­ tion ;
tgt_text.4408: for I see that in regard to other honours, of which the citizens allow them a share, some of them are ready, from a love of praise, to do whatever is required of them.
tgt_text.4410: Infantry, too, in union with the cavalry, appears to me likely to be of great service, if it be composed of men de­ termined to act against the enemy.
tgt_text.4412: All these advantages may be secured with the aid of the gods.
tgt_text.4414: If any reader is surprised at my frequent repetition that we must proceed WITH THE AID OF THE GODS, let him be assured that he will feel less surprise at this admonition, if he fall often into danger, and if he reflect that in time of war enemies often form designs on one another, but seldom know the state of things among the party against whom their de­ signs are formed.
tgt_text.4415: 9. Such being the case, it is impossible to find to whom we may apply for counsel, except to the gods, who know all things, and who give intimations to whomsoever they please, by sacrifices, auguries, omens, and dreams.
tgt_text.4416: But it is probable that the gods will be more willing to afford counsel to those who not only ask them what they are to do when they need advice, but pay them honour, as far as they can, in time of success.
tgt_text.4417: IAT what period of his life Xenophon wrote this piece is uncer­ tain, except that we may suppose it to have been written some time after his return from Asia with the Ten Thousand.
tgt_text.4418: Valckenaer, De Aristobulo, p. 114, cited by Schneider, suspects that the catalogue of mythological and other personages in the first chapter, who are said to have profited so much by devotion to hunting, can scarcely be all genuine.
tgt_text.4419: To this suspicion Schneider was very ready to listen.
tgt_text.4420: But there is far more ground for believing that the thirteenth chapter, which consists chiefly of a series of weak and foolish assaults on the sophists, is spurious.
tgt_text.4421: Both the matter, and the manner in which it is expressed, are utterly unworthy of Xenophon.
tgt_text.4422: The rest of the work, though Schneider has some suspicion of the twelfth chapter, is probably genuine.
tgt_text.4423: The first part, as far as the end of the eighth chapter, treats mostly of hare-hunting, and with such a thorough acquaintance with the subject, that Blane, hitherto the only English translator of the work, who, being a sportsman, deserves attention, says, " I have been indeed astonished;
tgt_text.4424: in reading the Cynegeticos of Xenophon, to find the accurate knowledge that great man had of the nature of the hare, and the method of hunting her;
tgt_text.4425: and to observe one of the finest writers, the bravest soldiers, the ablest politicians, the wisest philosophers, and the most virtuous citizens of antiquity, so intimately acquainted with all the niceties and difficulties of pursuing this little animal, and describing them with a precision that would not disgrace the oldest sportsman of Great Britain, who never had any other idea interfere to perplex his researches.
tgt_text.4426: "The rest of the treatise speaks of the hunting of deer, boars, and other larger beasts.
tgt_text.4427: His description of a snare for entangling the feet of deer, in the ninth chapter, is to us of modern days very obscure.
tgt_text.4429: THE invention of the art is from the gods ;
tgt_text.4430: for hunting and dogs were the care of Apollo and Diana, who rewarded and honoured Chiron with a knowledge of them on account of his regard for justice.
tgt_text.4431: 2. He, having received the gift, was delighted with it, and had as disciples, in this and other honourable pursuits, Cephalus, AEsculapius, Melanion, Nestor, Amphiaraus, Peleus, Telamon, Meleager, Theseus, Hippoly­ tus, Palamedes, Ulysses, Menestheus, Diomede, Castor, Pollux, Machaon, Podalirius, Antilochus, Æneas, Achilles;
tgt_text.4432: each of whom, in his own day, received honour from the gods.
tgt_text.4434: Nor let any one wonder that most of them, though they pleased the deities, nevertheless died ;
tgt_text.4436: but their great praises have been perpetuated ;
tgt_text.4437: ) nor let any one feel surprised that their lives were not all of the same duration, since the life of Chiron was long enough for all of them.
tgt_text.4438: 1 4. Jupiter and Chiron were brothers, sons of the same father ;
tgt_text.4439: but Jupiter had Rhea for his mother, and Chiron a Naiad nymph ;
tgt_text.4440: so that he was born before all of them, but did not die till he had brought up Achilles.5.
tgt_text.4441: From their attention to dogs and hunting, and from their other accomplishments, they were admired as greatly excel­ ling in merit.
tgt_text.4442: 6. Cephalus was carried off by a goddess ;
tgt_text.4443: 2 .Esculapius obtained higher distinction, that of raising the dead and healing the sick ;
tgt_text.4444: and for these powers he receives immortal glory as a god among mortals.
tgt_text.4445: 7. Melanion attained such renown in bodily exercises, that he alone was deemed worthy of the high honour of a marriage with Atalanta, for which the most eminent men of that period were his rivals.
tgt_text.4446: The merit of Nestor has already pervaded the ears of the Greeks ;
tgt_text.4447: so that, if I were to speak of it, I should speak to those who are well acquainted with it.
tgt_text.4448: 8. Amphiaraus, when be proceeded against Thebes, obtained the greatest praise, and received from the gods the honour of living for ever.
tgt_text.4449: Peleus inspired the gods with the desire of giving him Thetis in marriage, and of celebrating the marriage at the dwelling of Chiron.
tgt_text.4450: 9. Telamon became so eminent that he married Peribœa, the daughter of Alcathous, a native of the greatest of cities,l whom he courted ;
tgt_text.4451: and when Hercules, the chief of the Greeks, distributed the prizes of valour after he had taken Troy, he assigned to him Hesione.
tgt_text.4452: 10. The honours which Meleager received are well known ;
tgt_text.4453: and that he fell into mis­ fortunes in his old age was not through his own fault, but through his father's forgetfulness of the goddess.
tgt_text.4455: Theseus alone overthrew the enemies of all Greece;
tgt_text.4456: and, having greatly increased the power of his country, is held in honour even in the present day.
tgt_text.4458: Hippolytus was honoured by Diana, and celebrated by general report, and died in happy estimation for his temperance and piety.
tgt_text.4459: Palamedes, as long as he lived, far surpassed the men of his age in wisdom ;
tgt_text.4460: and, after being put to death unjustly, obtained more honour from the gods than any other among mortals.
tgt_text.4461: But be was not put to death by those by whom some suppose that he was;
tgt_text.4462: for it could not have been one3 who was almost the best of men, and another4 who was of a character with the good ;
tgt_text.4463: but it was assuredly bad men that did the deed.
tgt_text.4465: Menestheus, from his devotion to hunting, so far sur­ passed other men in endurance of toil, that the first among the Greeks acknowledged themselves inferior to him in mili­ tary affairs, except Nestor alone ;
tgt_text.4466: and he indeed is not said to have excelled, but to have rivalled him.
tgt_text.4467: 13. Ulysses and Diomede were distinguished on particular occasions, and were on the whole the authors of the reduction of Troy.
tgt_text.4468: Castor and Pollux, through the esteem which they acquired from exhibiting in Greece such of the accomplishments as they learned from Chiron, are immortal.
tgt_text.4469: 14. Machaon and Poda­ lirius, who were instructed in all the same accomplishments, were excellent in arts, and eloquence, and war.
tgt_text.4470: Antilochus, by dying for his father,1 obtained such glory that he alone is called by the Greeks Philopator.
tgt_text.4472: AEneas, by preserving his paternal and maternal gods,2 and by saving also the life of his father, gained such renown for his filial piety, that the Greeks granted to him alone, of all that they took prisoners in Troy, exemption from being spoiled of his property.
tgt_text.4473: 16. Achilles, brought up in the same course of instruction, raised such illustrious and extraordinary memorials of himself, that no one is ever tired either of speaking or hearing con­ cerning him.
tgt_text.4475: All these men became such as they were from the instruc­ tion derived from Chiron ;
tgt_text.4476: men whom the good still love, and the bad envy.
tgt_text.4477: If misfortunes happened, indeed, to any city or ruler in Greece, they 3 became its deliverers;
tgt_text.4478: or if a quarrel or war arose between the whole of Greece and the barbarians,4 the Greeks secured the victory by means of these heroes ;
tgt_text.4479: so that they rendered Greece invincible.
tgt_text.4480: 18. I therefore exhort the young not to despise hunting, or any part of liberal edu­ cation ;
tgt_text.4481: for by such means men become excellent in military qualifications, and in other accomplishments by which they are necessarily led to think, act, and speak rightly.
tgt_text.4483: IN the first place, then, it is proper for one who has just passed the age of boyhood to devote himself to hunting, and, in the next place, to other accomplishments;
tgt_text.4484: I mean, one who has fortune ;
tgt_text.4485: but he must have regard to the extent of it;
tgt_text.4486: he who has a competency should pursue such exercises in proportion to the benefit which he may expect from them ;
tgt_text.4487: he who has not, should at least show a desire for them, and neglect no part of them that is within his means.
tgt_text.4489: With what preparations, and of what kind, he ought to come to the pursuit of hunting, I will mention, as well as what is necessary to be known in each particular matter, in order that he may not enter on the occupation without some previous instruction.
tgt_text.4490: Nor let any one imagine that the ad­ monitions which I offer are trifling;
tgt_text.4491: for without attention to them nothing could be done.
tgt_text.4493: It is necessary, then, that be who has the care of the nets should be fond of his employment, should speak the Greek language, be about twenty years of age, active and strong in body, and possessed of sufficient courage, in order that, surmounting toil by means of these qualifications, he may have pleasure in the occupation.
tgt_text.4494: 4. The small nets, those for stopping roads, and the larger ones,2 should all be made of fine flax from Phasis or Carthage.
tgt_text.4495: The nets should also be made of cord of nine threads;
tgt_text.4496: that is, of three strands, and each strand of three threads;
tgt_text.4497: they should be five spans3 in depth, and two palms1 at the running-nooses ;
tgt_text.4498: 2 and let the cords that run round them be inserted without knots, that they may slip with ease.
tgt_text.4499: 5. The road-nets should be made of cord of twelve threads, and the large nets of cor4 of six­ teen ;
tgt_text.4500: as to size, the road-nets should be two, or four, or five fathoms in length;
tgt_text.4501: the large nets should be ten, or twenty, or thirty fathoms ;
tgt_text.4502: if they be larger, they will be difficult to manage;
tgt_text.4503: both of them must have thirty knots,3 and the size of the meshes must be the same as that of the meshes in the smaller nets.
tgt_text.4504: Let the road-nets have round knots at the upper extremities, and the larger nets rings;
tgt_text.4505: and the ropes4 that run round them made of twisted cord.

tgt_text.4507: (let such of them as are of unequal length be used on sloping grounds, that they may keep the tops of the nets straight, while those of equal length may be used on level ground;
tgt_text.4508: ) they must allow the nets to be easily put off and on, and must accordingly be smooth at the tips.
tgt_text.4509: Let those for the road-nets be of twice that length, and those for the large nets five spans in length, having small forks, with notches by no means deep ;
tgt_text.4510: 6 let them all be easy to fix, and the thickness of them not disproportionate to the length.
tgt_text.4511: As to the number of props for the large nets, we may use either fewer or more;
tgt_text.4512: fewer, if they are much stretched in their position ;
tgt_text.4515: Let there also be sacks2 made of calves'-skin, in which the smaller and larger nets may be put, a sack for each ;
tgt_text.4516: and bill-hooks may also be put into them, that the hunter may cut down a portion of the wood, and stop up any part that may be necessary.
tgt_text.4518: OF dogs there are two kinds ;
tgt_text.4519: the one called Castorian, the other of the fox breed.
tgt_text.4521: The Castorian have this appellation, because Castor, who delighted in the amusement of hunting, had most regard for them;
tgt_text.4522: those of the fox breed were so termed because they are bred from a dog and a fox, and through length of time the natures of the two animals are completely amalgamated.
tgt_text.4524: The inferior animals of these two species,4 which are also the more numerous, are of the following sorts:
tgt_text.4525: such as are small, or have turned-up noses, are blue-eyed, near-sighted, in-shaped, stiff, weak, have thin hair, are long-legged, not well proportioned, deficient in spirit or power of scent, or have bad feet.
tgt_text.4526: 3. The small, from their diminutiveness, often find their efforts in the chase fruitless;
tgt_text.4527: those that have turned-up noses are weak in the mouth, and are unable, for this reason, to hold the hare;
tgt_text.4528: the near-sighted and blue-eyed are imper­ fect in sight, as well as ill-shaped and unpleasing to the eye;
tgt_text.4529: such as are stiff in the frame come off ill1 in the pursuit;
tgt_text.4530: such as are weak, and have thin hair, are unfit to endure fatigue;
tgt_text.4531: such as are long-legged, and ill-proportioned, have incompact frames, and run heavily;
tgt_text.4532: such as are deficient in spirit quit their work, shrink away from the heat of the sun into the shade and lie down;
tgt_text.4533: such as are wanting in scent hardly ever find the hare;
tgt_text.4534: and such as have bad feet are unable, even if they are ever so spirited, to endure the exer­ tion, but faint away from pain in the feet.
tgt_text.4536: Of tracking the hare there are many different modes among the same dogs;
tgt_text.4537: for some, when they have found the track, proceed onwards without giving any indication, so that it is not known that they are on the track;
tgt_text.4538: others merely move their ears, and keep their tail perfectly still;
tgt_text.4539: other keep their ears unmoved, but make a motion with the end of their tail.
tgt_text.4540: 5. Some, again, contract their ears, and, looking solemnly down on the track, pursue their way along it with their tails lowered and drawn between their legs;
tgt_text.4541: 2 many do none of these things, but run madly about the track when they have fallen upon it, barking and trampling out the scent in the most senseless manner.
tgt_text.4542: 6. Others, after making many turnings and windings, and getting an inkling of the scent in advance of the hare, leave her behind;
tgt_text.4543: whenever they run upon the track, they are never certain;
tgt_text.4544: and, when they see the hare before them, they give signs of fear, and do not advance upon her until they see her start.
tgt_text.4545: 7. Whatever dogs, again, in tracking and pursuing, run forward and watch fre­ quently, at the same time, for what other dogs discover, have no confidence in themselves.
tgt_text.4546: Some, on the other hand, are so rash that they do not allow the experienced dogs of the pack to precede them, but keep them back with a disturbing noise.
tgt_text.4547: Others pounce on false scents, and, exulting in what­ ever they find, take the lead at once, though conscious that they are deceiving the rest;
tgt_text.4548: others do the same without being conscious of it.
tgt_text.4549: Such dogs are worthless, too, as never leave beaten tracks, and do not know the tracks proper to be fol­ lowed.
tgt_text.4550: 8. Such dogs also as do not know the footsteps that lead to the hare's resting-place, and such as pass hastily over those which she makes in running, are not of a good breed.
tgt_text.4551: Some start in pursuit of the hare with great speed, but re­ lax for want of spirit;
tgt_text.4552: some run on,1 and then miss the scent;
tgt_text.4553: others run senselessly into the public roads, and so lose it, and show the utmost reluctance to be recalled.
tgt_text.4554: Many, abandoning the pursuit, turn back through dislike of the hare ;
tgt_text.4555: many, from longing for the society of their master.
tgt_text.4556: Some try to draw the other dogs from the track by yelping, making a false scent appear to be the true.
tgt_text.4558: There are some also, which, though they do not act thus, yet if, while they are running on, they hear a noise on any side, quit their own course, and start off foolishly towards it;
tgt_text.4559: for some run after anything in uncer­ tainty, others fancying strongly that they are getting on a track, others imagining they have found one ;
tgt_text.4560: some making a feint, while others maliciously quit the scent, though they are continually straying about close to it.
tgt_text.4562: Dogs that have such faults, most of them perhaps from nature, but some from having been unskilfully trained, are of little service.
tgt_text.4563: Such dogs, indeed, may disgust people with hunting who have a strong turn for it.
tgt_text.4564: But of what descrip­ tion dogs of this species3 ought to be, as to their shapes and other qualities, I will now proceed to show.
tgt_text.4566: IN the first place, then, they ought to be large ;
tgt_text.4567: and, in the next, they should have their heads light, short, and sinewy;
tgt_text.4569: the eyes up-raised,1 black, and bright;
tgt_text.4571: the line dividing the eyes deep;
tgt_text.4572: the ears small, thin, and without hair on the back ;
tgt_text.4573: the neck long, flexible, and round ;
tgt_text.4574: the breast broad and not without flesh ;
tgt_text.4575: the shoulder-blades standing out a little apart from the shoulders;
tgt_text.4576: 2 the fore-legs small, straight, round, wiry;
tgt_text.4578: 3 the sides should not hang down very deep, but run along obliquely;
tgt_text.4579: 4 the loins should be fleshy [their size a medium between long and short], and not too soft or too hard ;
tgt_text.4580: the upper flanks something between large and small;
tgt_text.4581: the hips should be round, fleshy towards the hinder part, not drawn together at the upper,5 but closely joined within ;
tgt_text.4582: 6 the part below the flank, and the lower flank7 itself, should be loose;
tgt_text.4585: the lower part of the thighs8 long, full, compact;
tgt_text.4586: the hinder legs much longer than those in front, and some.
tgt_text.4589: 12. If the dogs be shaped thus, they will be strong, agile, symmetrical, swift;
tgt_text.4590: will have pleasing looks and good mouths.
tgt_text.4591: 3. They must, as they seek for scent, be easily called off from beaten tracks, sloping their heads down to the ground, looking cheerfully as they come upon the track, hanging down their ears, glancing quickly about with their eyes, and wagging their tails;
tgt_text.4592: and thus let them proceed, with many windings, along the track of the hare to the place where she lies.
tgt_text.4593: 4. When they come near the hare, let them make the fact mani­ fest to the huntsman by moving about more quickly, signify­ ing it also by increased ardour, by the motion of their heads, by their glances, by the change in their movements, by look­ ing up, and looking onward to the seat of the hare, by jumping forward, and backward, and sideways, and by showing that they are really elated in their hearts, and rejoiced that they are close upon the hare.
tgt_text.4594: 5. They should pursue vigorously, and never relax, with great noise and barking, and turning in every direction with the hare,2 land should follow swiftly and unmis­ takeably, frequently winding about, and yelping only for good reason ;
tgt_text.4595: ]3 and they should never leave the track to return to the huntsman.
tgt_text.4597: With this shape, and this action, they should be spirit­ ed, sound in the feet, keen-scented, and have good hair.
tgt_text.4598: They will be spirited, if they do not shrink from the chase even when the heat prevails;
tgt_text.4599: they will be keen-scented, if they smell the hare in bare, arid, sunny4 places, when the sun 5 is hich up in the sky;
tgt_text.4600: they will be sound in the feet, if their leet are not injured as they run over the mountains in the same season of the year;
tgt_text.4601: and they will have good hair, if they have it fine, and thick, and soft.
tgt_text.4603: As to the colour of dogs, it should not be altogether red, or black, or white ;
tgt_text.4604: for such colours are not the signs of a good breed, but of a common and wild sort.
tgt_text.4605: 8. Such as are red or black should have white hair, and such as are white, red hair, growing about the face.
tgt_text.4606: On the upper part of the thighs they should have hair growing straight and long, as well as on the loins and at the extremity of the tail;
tgt_text.4607: at the upper part of the tail they should have but a moderate quan­ tity of hair.
tgt_text.4609: It will be proper to take out the dogs frequently over hilly grounds, and but seldom over cultivated fields;
tgt_text.4610: for on the hills they may track and pursue the hare without obstruc­ tion ;
tgt_text.4611: but on cultivated lands they can do neither, on account of the paths.
tgt_text.4612: 1 10. It is well, too, to take the dogs, even when they do not find the hare, over rough ground ;
tgt_text.4613: for they thus strengthen their feet, and are also benefited by exercising their bodies over such land.
tgt_text.4614: 11. In summer they should be taken out till noon ;
tgt_text.4615: in winter, through the whole day;
tgt_text.4618: for these are the times when the temperature is moderate.
tgt_text.4620: THE tracks of the hare are long in winter, on account of the length of the njghts;
tgt_text.4621: 2 in summer they are short, for the contrary reason.
tgt_text.4622: In winter, too, there is no scent from them in the morning, whenever there is hoar frost or ice;
tgt_text.4623: 3 for the hoar frost, by its influence, draws the heat into it and retains it, while the ice congeals it.
tgt_text.4624: 2. Those dogs, according­ ly, which have dull noses, are unable to scent the track when there is such weather, until the sun, or the advance of the day, relaxes the frost and ice;
tgt_text.4625: and then the dogs can smelt and the track itself, while it sends up a vapour, gives forth also a scent.
tgt_text.4626: 3. Much dew, too, dulls the scent by keeping it down ;
tgt_text.4627: 1 and rains, which fall after long intervals, raise odours from the ground, and render the track of the hare difficult to scent, until they are dried up.
tgt_text.4629: Southerly winds also make the scent fainter, for they spread moisture through the air;
tgt_text.4630: but northerly winds fix the scent, if it has not previously been dispelled,3 and preserve it.
tgt_text.4631: 4. Rains, in general, and dews drown it;
tgt_text.4632: and the moon dulls it by her warmth,4 especially when it is full.
tgt_text.4633: Scent, indeed, is then most scarce;
tgt_text.4634: for the hares, pleased with the light, and jump­ ing up, as they sport with one another, place their steps at long intervals.
tgt_text.4635: Scent is perplexed, also, when foxes have crossed the ground previously.
tgt_text.4637: The spring, from the temperature of the weather, renders the scent exceedingly clear, unless perchance the ground, where it is covered with flowers, may inconvenience the dogs, by mingling the odour of the flowers with that of the hare.
tgt_text.4638: In summer it is weak and uncertain;
tgt_text.4639: for the ground, being warm, absorbs the warmth which the scent has, and which is but slight;
tgt_text.4640: while the dogs have at that time less power of smelling, because their bodies are relaxed, In the autumn the scent is clear;
tgt_text.4641: for of the productions which the earth yields, those which are cultivated have been then gathered in, and the wild have withered away;
tgt_text.4642: so that the odours of the plants do not trouble the scent by mingling with it.
tgt_text.4643: 6. The tracks, also, in winter and summer, as well as in autumn, are mostly straight;
tgt_text.4644: but in spring they are perplexed;
tgt_text.4645: for the animals, which are indeed perpetually coupling, couple most at this season, and hence, by straying about with one another hither and hither, they necessarily produce this inconvenience.
tgt_text.4647: From the steps which a hare takes in going to her resting-place there arises a stronger scent than from those which she takes in running away from it;
tgt_text.4648: for those which she takes in going thither are made at a slower and irregular pace,1 those which she takes in running from it, at a quicker;
tgt_text.4649: the ground is accordingly saturated with the scent of the one, but is not even filled with that of the other.
tgt_text.4650: The scent is stronger, likewise, on woody than on bare ground;
tgt_text.4651: for the hare, as she runs about, and occasionally rests, touches many objects.
tgt_text.4652: 8. Hares sink down on what­ ever the earth produces or has on it, under all kinds of things, or above them, or among them, or close by them, or at some distance, great or small, from them or within them;
tgt_text.4653: 2 some­ times springing, too, as far as they can, over the sea, or into water, if there be anything rising above it or growing on it.
tgt_text.4654: 9. The hare, when it wishes to settle, makes its nest, for the most part, in warm spots, when it is cold;
tgt_text.4655: when it is hot, in shady ones;
tgt_text.4656: in spring and autumn, in places exposed to the sun :
tgt_text.4657: those that are unsettled may act otherwise, from being scared by dogs.
tgt_text.4658: 10. As it reclines, it draws the inner part of the thighs3 under its flanks, putting the fore-legs together, for the most part, and stretching them out, resting the chin on the tips of the feet, and spreading the ears over the shoulder-blades;
tgt_text.4659: by which means it covers the soft parts of the neck;
tgt_text.4660: 4 and it has also its hair as a protection, being thick and soft.
tgt_text.4661: 11. When it is awake, it winks with its eyelids;
tgt_text.4662: but when it is asleep, the eyelids are raised and fixed, and the eyes continue unmoved;
tgt_text.4663: also, while asleep, it moves its nostrils frequently, but when not asleep, less often.
tgt_text.4665: When the ground is giving forth herbage, the cultivated plains attract the hare more than the hills.
tgt_text.4666: It stops, when it is tracked, in any place whatever, unless it be excessively frightened at night;
tgt_text.4667: when it is thus affected, it hastens off to other parts.
tgt_text.4668: 13. It is so prolific an animal, that when the female has brought forth, she is ready to bring forth again, and is at the same time conceiving a third broody
tgt_text.4669: From the young hares there is more scent than from the full-grown;
tgt_text.4671: their limbs are weak, they drag them all along upon the ground.
tgt_text.4672: 14. The very young ones the huntsmen let go, from respect to the goddess.
tgt_text.4674: Those that are a year old run their first heat with great speed;
tgt_text.4675: the others not so swiftly, for, though they are nimble, they are not strong.
tgt_text.4677: To find the track of the hare, it is necessary to take the dogs by the parts above the cultivated grounds;
tgt_text.4678: 3 (such of the hares as do not come into cultivated lands betake them­ selves to meadows, glades, banks of streams, rocks, or woods;
tgt_text.4679: ) and if the hare move, we must take care not to cry out, lest the dogs should be startled,4 and find a difficulty in following the track.
tgt_text.4680: 16. When they are discovered by the dogs, and pursued, they sometimes cross over brooks, and double, and slink away into clefts and tortuous hiding-places;
tgt_text.4681: for they fear not only dogs, but also eagles, since, as they pass over flat slopes and open places, they are frequently carried off by them, whilst they are under a year old.
tgt_text.4682: The older ones the dogs pursue and carry off.
tgt_text.4683: 17. Those that frequent the hills are the swiftest, those in the plains are less so, and those that are about marshy grounds are the slowest.
tgt_text.4684: Those that wander over all sorts of ground are more difficult to pursue, for they know the short cuts;
tgt_text.4685: and they run chiefly up slopes or along level spots;
tgt_text.4686: over unequal ground they run irregularly, and least of all down­ hill.
tgt_text.4688: When they are pursued, they are seen best on land that is turned up, if they have a little redness of colour ;
tgt_text.4689: 5 and they are also seen well on stubble, by the light reflected on them ;
tgt_text.4690: 6 they appear very plain, too, along paths and roads, at least such as are level ;
