tgt_text.4691: for the bright hue of their hair strikes the eye;
tgt_text.4692: but when they run away among stones, and hills, and rocky and woody ground, they are not easily perceived, on account of the similarity of the colour.
tgt_text.4694: When they are in advance of the dogs, they will stop and squat down, and then raise themselves up to listen whether any barking or noise of dogs is near them ;
tgt_text.4695: and, on whatever quarter they hear any, they turn away from it.
tgt_text.4696: 20. Sometimes, also, when they hear none, but fancy or are persuaded in themselves that they hear some, they run re­ peatedly by and over the same ground, varying their steps, and making track upon track.
tgt_text.4697: 21. Those make the longest runs which are found on open grounds, from the view being unobstructed ;
tgt_text.4698: those run the shortest distance which are started from woody places, as the obscurity is a hindrance to them.
tgt_text.4699: 22. There are two sorts of hares ;
tgt_text.4700: for some are large and blackish, and have a great deal of white in the face ;
tgt_text.4701: while others are smaller and somewhat yellow, and have but little white.
tgt_text.4702: 23. Some have the tail varied with rings of different colours ;
tgt_text.4705: Some have the eyes grey­ ish, others somewhat blue.
tgt_text.4706: In some the black at the tips of the ears spreads over a large space ;
tgt_text.4707: in others, over but a small one.
tgt_text.4708: 24. The lesser sort most of the islands contain, as well the desert as the inhabited ;
tgt_text.4709: and they are more numer­ ous in the islands than on continents, for there are in most of them neither foxes, which attack and destroy both them and their young ones, nor eagles, which large mountains rather than small produce, and the mountains in islands are generally of the less elevated sort.
tgt_text.4710: 25. Hunters, too, come but seldom into desert islands;
tgt_text.4711: and on those which are inhabited there are but few people, and comparatively few of them given to hunting;
tgt_text.4712: while into the sacred islands it is not lawful even to transport dogs.
tgt_text.4713: Since, therefore, the inhabitants hunt but few of those which exist, and which are constantly multiplying, there must be a great number of them.
tgt_text.4715: The hare has not a keen sight, for many reasons ;
tgt_text.4716: for it has its eyes prominent, and the eye-lids small, affording no protection for the eye-balls ;
tgt_text.4717: and their sight is on this account dim and dispersed.
tgt_text.4718: 1 27. In addition to this, the animal, being much given to sleep, is by that means not improved in its sight.
tgt_text.4720: The swiftness with which it runs, too, tends greatly to trouble its vision ;
tgt_text.4721: for it turns off its eyes from objects be­ fore it can perceive what they are.
tgt_text.4722: The terror from the dogs, likewise, following upon it with them when it is chased, deprives it of all power of foresight;
tgt_text.4723: and hence it runs against many objects, and falls into nets, before it is aware.
tgt_text.4724: 29. If it ran, however, straight onwards, it would but seldom meet with such mishaps ;
tgt_text.4725: but, as it winds about, and feels an attraction towards the place in which it was born and bred, it is consequently captured.
tgt_text.4726: Yet it is not often captured by the dogs by speed of foot;
tgt_text.4727: but such as are caught are caught in spite of their natural conformation, and under the influence of chance;
tgt_text.4728: for of all animals that exist, no one of the same size is equal to the hare in swiftness ;
tgt_text.4729: such is the nature of the parts of which its body is composed.
tgt_text.4731: It has a head light, small, looking downwards, and nar­ row in the forepart;
tgt_text.4732: a neck slender, round, not stiff, and of a proper length ;
tgt_text.4733: shoulder-blades straight, and not contracted at the top ;
tgt_text.4734: 3 the legs joined to them, light and well attached ;
tgt_text.4735: 4 the breast not heavy with flesh ;
tgt_text.4739: the flanks yielding and sufficiently loose ;
tgt_text.4740: the hips round, full everywhere, and separ­ ated above by a proper interval;
tgt_text.4741: the thighs long, of due thickness, tense on the outside, and not turgid within ;
tgt_text.4742: the hind legs long and firm ;
tgt_text.4743: the fore feet extremely flexible, narrow, and straight the hind ones firm and broad;
tgt_text.4744: all the feet caring nothing for rough ground ;
tgt_text.4745: the hind legs much thicker than the fore ones, and bending a little outwards ;
tgt_text.4747: 31. Accordingly it is impossible that an animal composed of such parts should not be strong, agile, and extremely nimble.
tgt_text.4748: That it is nimble we have sufficient proof;
tgt_text.4749: for when it goes along quietly, it proceeds by leaps ;
tgt_text.4750: no man has ever seen it, or ever will see it, walking ;
tgt_text.4751: but, putting the hind feet in advance of the fore feet, and on the outside of them, it springs forward.
tgt_text.4752: This is plainly seen by the marks which it makes on the snow.
tgt_text.4753: 32.' It has a tail, however, not very conducive to speed ;
tgt_text.4754: for it cannot steer the body on account of its short­ ness ;
tgt_text.4755: but the animal produces this effect by the alternate ac­ tion of the ears, continuing it, even when it is on the very point of being caught by the dogs;
tgt_text.4756: for, lowering one ear, and turning it obliquely on the side on which it is threatened with annoyance, it first sways itself in that direction,' and then turns off suddenly in the other, and leaves its pursuers behind in a moment.
tgt_text.4758: It is so pleasing an animal, that no one who sees it, whether when it is tracked and discovered, or when it is pur­ sued or caught, would not forget whatever other object he ad­ mired.
tgt_text.4760: In hunting on cultivated grounds, the huntsman must abstain from injuring the fruits of the season, and must leave springs and streams 3 undisturbed ;
tgt_text.4761: for to interfere with these is contrary to propriety and morality, and it is to be feared that those who see such proceedings may set the law at defiance.
tgt_text.4763: When it is not a time for hunting,1 it will be proper to re­ move all the hunting implements.
tgt_text.4765: THE equipments for dogs are collars,3 leashes, and girths.
tgt_text.4767: Let the collars be soft as well as broad, that they may not wear off the dog's hair.
tgt_text.4768: Let the leashes have loops for the hand attached to them, but nothing else;
tgt_text.4769: for those who form the collars out of the leashes5 do not manage well for their dogs.
tgt_text.4770: Let the girths have broad bands, that they may not gall their flanks;
tgt_text.4771: and let there be iron points stitched into them, that they may protect the breeds.
tgt_text.4772: 62. But it is improper to take dogs out to hunt, whenever they do not readily take the food that is put before them, as this is a sufficient indication that they are out of health ;
tgt_text.4773: or whenever the wind blows very strong, as the wind scatters the scent, and the dogs are unable to catch it, nor will the nets, either small or large, stand.
tgt_text.4774: 3. When neither of these obstacles presents itself, however, we should take them out every third day.
tgt_text.4775: Foxes we should not accustom the dogs to hunt, for it is a great means of spoiling them, and they lose their readiness to follow where you required4.
tgt_text.4776: You should take them to hunt on different grounds at different times, in order that they may experience varieties in the chase, and that you yourself may become acquainted with the country.
tgt_text.4777: You should go out with them in the morning, that they may not fail of finding the track;
tgt_text.4778: for those who go out late deprive the dogs of all chance of find­ ing the hare, and themselves of all profit from their efforts$ for the consistence of the scent, which is very subtle, does.
tgt_text.4779: not remain the same throughout all the hours of the day.
tgt_text.4780: 25. Let the attendant that has charge of the nets go out to hunt in a dress that is not at all heavy;
tgt_text.4781: and let him fix the nets about passages 3 that are rough, sloping, open, or dark, and about brooks, glades, or waterfalls that are constantly running down ravines (for it is in such places that the hare mostly seeks refuge;
tgt_text.4782: to how many others she may flee it would be endless to specify);
tgt_text.4783: 6. and let him set them at tracks that run along by these or across them, whether they be plainly marked or scarcely perceptible, placing them at.
tgt_text.4784: dawn and not earlier, lest, if the part where they are fixed be near the hunting-grounds, the animal may be frightened at hearing the noise.
tgt_text.4785: Should the two places, however, be at a considerable distance from each other, that circumstance will put less restraint on those who clear the place for fixing the nets, that nothing may interfere with them.
tgt_text.4786: 47. He who has the management of the nets should fix the props sloping forward,1 that when they are pulled they may offer resistance.
tgt_text.4788: Let him put the loops uniformly on the tops, and fix the props regularly, putting the higher ones to­ wards the centre of the hollow part of the net.
tgt_text.4789: 8. To the end of the rope that runs round the net let him attach a long large stone, in order that the net, when it has caught the hare, may not be pulled in the contrary direction.
tgt_text.4790: Let him carry his nets in a long range, as well as have them high, that the hare may not leap over.
tgt_text.4791: In tracking the hare, he should make no delay ;
tgt_text.4792: 4 for it is sportsman-like, as well as a proof of fondness for exertion, to use every means to capture the animal speedily.
tgt_text.4794: The larger nets let him fix on level spots, and road-nets at the roads, stretching them from the roads in proper direc­ tions,5 attaching the ropes that run round the nets to the ground, bringing the extremities together,6 fixing the stakes between the edges,7 putting the ropes running at the top of the net on the points of them, and stopping up the inter­ vals.
tgt_text.4795: 8 10. Let him then walk round and keep watch ;
tgt_text.4796: if any stake or net give way, let him put it up;
tgt_text.4797: if the hare is pur­ sued towards the nets, let him allow her to go straight for­ ward, and then run after and shout;
tgt_text.4798: and when the hare has fallen into the nets, let him check the impetuosity of the dogs, not by touching them, but by calling to them;
tgt_text.4799: and let him signify to the huntsman, by crying out, that the hare is taken, or that it has gone by on this or that side, or that he has not seen it, or where he saw it.
tgt_text.4801: The huntsman should go out to the chase in a plain light, dress, with shoes of a similar description, and with a thick staff in his hand;
tgt_text.4802: the man who manages the nets should fol­ low him ;
tgt_text.4803: and they should proceed to the hunting-ground in silence, lest the hare, if she happen to be near, should run off on hearing their voices.
tgt_text.4804: 12. Having tied the dogs to trees, each separately, that they may be easily unfastened, let them fix the smaller and larger nets, as has been said;
tgt_text.4805: and then let the net-keeper continue on the watch, while the huntsman takes the dogs and proceeds to bring the prey towards the met.
tgt_text.4806: 13. Next vowing to Apollo and to Diana the Huntress to offer them a share of what is captured, let him loose that one of his dogs which is most skilful in tracking;
tgt_text.4807: and let this be done, if it is winter, at sunrise;
tgt_text.4809: and at other seasons between the two.
tgt_text.4810: 14. When the dog, out of all the tracks that intersect one another, has found the right one, let the hunter set loose another dog, and when this one has gained the track, let him loose the others one by one at no long intervals, and follow them, not urging them, but calling each by name, yet not frequently, lest they should be excited before the proper time.
tgt_text.4811: 15. The dogs will hasten forward with joy and spirit, discovering two or three tracks, as the case may be, proceeding along and over them, as they intersect, form circles, run straight or winding, are strong or weak, recognised or unrecognised;
tgt_text.4812: the animals passing by one another, waving their tails about incessantly, banging down their ears, and casting bright gleams from their eyes.
tgt_text.4813: 16. When they are near the hare, they will make it known to the huntsman by shaking not only their tails but their whole bodies, advancing as it were with hostile ardour, hastening emulously past each other, running resolutely in concert, coming quickly together, separating, and again ad­ vancing, till at last they will hit upon the hare's hiding-place, and rush towards her.
tgt_text.4814: 17. She, starting up suddenly, will raise behind her, as she flees, a loud barking and clamour from the dogs;
tgt_text.4815: and then let the men call after her, as she is pursued, " Forward, dogs, forward I Right, dogs !
tgt_text.4816: Well done, dogs !" and then let the huntsman, wrapping his cloak round his hand,1 and taking his staff, run along the track of the dogs toward the hare, taking care not to come in the teeth of them, for that would perplex them.
tgt_text.4818: The hare, retreating and soon getting out of sight, will in general come round again to the place from which she was started.
tgt_text.4819: The huntsman must cry, " Upon her, boy, upon her !
tgt_text.4820: Now boy, now boy !" and the boy must intimate whether she is caught or not.
tgt_text.4821: If she is caught in the first run, he must call in the dogs, and seek for another;
tgt_text.4822: if not, he must still run on with the dogs with all possible speed, not relaxing, but hurrying forward with the utmost exertion.
tgt_text.4823: 19. If the dogs, as they pursue, fall in with her again, he must shout, " Well done, well done, dogs !
tgt_text.4824: Follow, dogs!" and if the dogs get far before him, and he is unable, pursuing their track, to come up with them, but misses the way which they have taken, or cannot see them, though they are straying about somewhere near, or yelping, or keep­ ing on the scent, he may, as he runs on, call out to any one that he meets, and ask, " Have you seen my dogs anywhere ? " 20. When he has discovered where they are, he may, if they are on the track, go up to them and encourage them, repeat­ ing, as often as he can, the name of each dog, and varying the tones of his voice, making it sharp or grave, or gentle or strong.
tgt_text.4825: In addition to other exhortations, he may, if the pursuit is on a hill, call out thus, " Well done, dogs!
tgt_text.4826: Well done!" but if they are not on the track, but have gone be­ yond it, he must call to them, " Come back, come back, dogs l" 21.
tgt_text.4827: After they have come upon the track, he must lead them round,' making many and frequent windings;
tgt_text.4828: and wherever the scent is obscure, he ought to take a stake as a mark for himself,4 and draw the dogs round by this, cheering and sooth­ ing them, until they plainly recognise the track.
tgt_text.4829: 12. They, as soon as the track is clear, will throw themselves forward, and leap from side to side, will seem to have a com­ mon feeling, and to be forming conjectures, making signs to one another, and fixing as it were recognised bounds for themselves,1 and will start forward quickly in pursuit;
tgt_text.4830: but while they thus run hither and thither over the track, you must not urge them or run on with them, lest through eager­ ness they should go beyond it.
tgt_text.4831: 13. But when they are close upon the hare, and make it plain to the huntsman that they are so, he must take care lest through fear of the dogs she dart off in advance.
tgt_text.4832: The dogs themselves, whisking about their tails, running against and frequently leaping over one another, yelping, tossing up their heads, looking towards the huntsman, and intimating that these are the true tracks of the hare, will rouse her of themselves,2 and spring upon her with loud cries.
tgt_text.4833: 14. Should she run into the nets, or flee past them, whether on the outside or the inside, let the net-keeper, who is stationed at each of these parts, call out that such is the case.
tgt_text.4834: Should the hare be captured, the huntsman may proceed to seek another;
tgt_text.4835: if not, he may still continue to pur­ sue her, using the same incitements to the dogs as before.
tgt_text.4837: When the dogs are tired with running, and it is late in the day, the hunter may still continue to seek a for the hare, which will also be tired, leaving nothing unexamined of all that the earth produces or has upon it, making frequent turn­ ings about, that the animal may not escape him (for it lies in a small space, and sometimes shrinks from leaving it through weariness and terror), leading forward the dogs, animating them, cheering such as are docile with many words of en­ couragement, such as are intractable with but few, and such as are of an intermediate character with a moderate number, until he either kill the hare by tracking it, or drive it into the nets.
tgt_text.4838: 16. When this is done, let him take up his nets, small and large, and, after having rubbed down the dogs, quit the hunting-field, stopping occasionally, if it be noontide in summer, that the dogs' feet may not become sore on the way.
tgt_text.4840: IN the winter it is proper to let the females rest from labour, and to attend to breeding, that, from enjoying repose, they may produce a stout offspring towards the spring;
tgt_text.4841: for that season is particularly favourable for the growth of dogs.
tgt_text.4842: During fourteen days the want of the male1 affects them.
tgt_text.4843: 2. It is proper to take them to vigorous dogs after their ar­ dour is somewhat remitted,2 that they may conceive the sooner, and, while they are pregnant, not to take them out to hunt constantly, but only at intervals, lest they should mis­ carry from too much exertion.
tgt_text.4844: They go with young sixty days.
tgt_text.4846: When the puppies are born, we must leave them with the mother, and not put them to another dog ;
tgt_text.4847: for the nurture of strange dogs does not sufficiently contribute to growth ;
tgt_text.4848: but the milk and breath of their mothers is good for them, and their caresses pleasing.
tgt_text.4850: After the puppies are able to run about, we must give them milk for a year, with those sorts of food on which they are to live always, and nothing else;
tgt_text.4851: for much over-feeding of puppies distorts their legs, and produces diseases in their bodies;
tgt_text.4852: and their interior parts are thus rendered unsound.
tgt_text.4854: We should give them short names, that it may be easy to call them.
tgt_text.4855: They ought to be such as these:
tgt_text.4856: Psyche, 1 Thymus, Porpax,3 Styrax,4 Lonche,5 Lochos,6 Phrura,7 Phy­ lax, 8 Taxis, 9 Xiphon, 10 Phonax, 11Phlegon,12 Alce 13 Teuchon,14 Hyleus,15 Medas,16 Porthon,17 Sperchon,18 Orge,19 Bremon,20 Hybris,21 Thalion,22 Rhome,23 Antheus,24 Hebe,25 Getheus,26 Chara, Leusson, 28 Augo,29 Polys, 30 Bia,31 Stichon,32 Speude,33 Bryas,34 CEnas,35 Sterrhos,36 Crauge,37 Cænon,38 Tyrbas, 39 Sthenon, 40 Æther, 41 Actis, Æchme, 43 Noes,44 Gnome,45 Stibon,46 Horme.476.
tgt_text.4857: We must not take the female puppies out to hunt till they are eight months old, or the male till they are ten.
tgt_text.4858: The huntsman must not set them loose on the track to the hare'a form, but, keeping them tied with long straps, must let them follow the dogs that are scenting the hare, allowing them to run along the track.
tgt_text.4859: 7. When the hare is found, if they be well qualified by nature for running, he must not let them loose at once, but must wait till the hare has got in advance, so that they can no longer see her, and then let them go.
tgt_text.4860: 8. For if he lets loose immediately dogs that are well qualified by nature, and full of spirit, for running, they will, as soon as they see the hare, use such exertion as to injure themselves, as their frames are not yet strong ;
tgt_text.4861: and against such mishaps the huntsman must be on his guard.
tgt_text.4862: 9. If, on the contrary, they be but poorly qualified for running, there is nothing to hinder him from letting them go at once ;
tgt_text.4863: for, as they will be hopeless at first of overtaking the hare, they will do themselves no such mischief.
tgt_text.4864: The tracks which the hare leaves as she runs, be may allow the young Jogs to follow until they overtake her;
tgt_text.4865: and when she is caught, he may give her to them to tear to pieces.
tgt_text.4867: When they are no longer willing to stay by the nets, but scatter themselves about, he must call them in until they are trained to find the hare by running after her, lest, from perpetually going in quest of her without regard to order, they become at last untrainable ;
tgt_text.4868: 1 a result of the worst kind.
tgt_text.4869: 11. It is proper accordingly to give them their food at the nets, as long as they are young, when the nets are taken up, that if they should stray away in the hunting-field for want of knowing what they are about, they may be recovered through return­ ing to that spot.
tgt_text.4871: They will no longer require this care when they begin to have a hostile feeling towards the beast that they hunt, and are prompted to think more of their prey than of their ordinary food.
tgt_text.4873: It will be well for the huntsman, in general, to give the dogs their food himself;
tgt_text.4874: for though, when they are in want, they do not know who is the cause of it, they conceive an affection for him, who, when they are eager to receive it, gives it them.1.
tgt_text.4875: IT is proper that hares should be tracked, when snow has fallen in such a quantity that the ground is hidden;
tgt_text.4876: for if black spots appear on the surface, the animal will be diffi­ cult to trace.
tgt_text.4877: When there has been snow, and the north wind blows, the tracks are visible for a long time ;
tgt_text.4878: 3 but if the wind be southerly, and the sun also shines, they are to be seen but a short time, as they soon melt away.
tgt_text.4879: While snow continues to fall, it is of no use to attempt to track the animal, for the snow covers the traces;
tgt_text.4880: nor is it of any use if the wind be strong, for it effaces them by throwing up the snow.
tgt_text.4882: We must never go out to hunt with dogs, therefore, un­ der such circumstances;
tgt_text.4883: for the snow parches the noses and feet of the dogs, and carries off the scent of the hare from ex­ cessive cold.
tgt_text.4884: But the hunter may take his nets and go out with a com­ rade to the hills, at a distance from the cultivated grounds, and, when he has found traces of the hare, may follow them.
tgt_text.4885: 3. If they should be perplexed, he must go back on the same track, and still keep along it, making circuits so as to go round the whole of it seeking whither it finally leads;
tgt_text.4886: for the hare frequently wanders hither and thither, hesitating where it shall settle itself;
tgt_text.4887: and it is accustomed also to be very artful in going about, from being constantly pursued by its footsteps.
tgt_text.4888: 4. When the track shows itself plainly, the hunter may proceed straight forwards;
tgt_text.4889: and it will lead him either to a shady or to a steep place, because the wind carries the snow over such spots.
tgt_text.4890: The hare therefore leaves many places in which she might sit, and seeks for one of this kind.
tgt_text.4891: When the footsteps lead to such places, he must not approach too near, lest the hare should start, but make a circuit round about;
tgt_text.4892: for it is to be expected that a hare is there;
tgt_text.4893: and it will presently become certain, since there will be no track from such spots leading out in any other direction.
tgt_text.4894: When it is clear that the hare is there, he may let her alone (for she will not move), and seek for another, before the footsteps are obliterated, having regard to the time of day, in order that, if be find others, there may be time enough left for putting round the nets.
tgt_text.4895: 5. If such is the case, he must stretch the nets round each of the hares in the same way as on the dark soil, so that he may catch whatever hare they are near within them ;
tgt_text.4896: and when they are fixed, he must go and rouse the hare.
tgt_text.4897: If she escapes from the net, he must run after her on her track ;
tgt_text.4898: and she will betake herself to other similar spots, un­ less she chance to bury herself in the snow.
tgt_text.4899: He must ac­ cordingly ascertain where she is, and place the nets round her.
tgt_text.4900: Should she make no stay in any place, he must continue the pursuit;
tgt_text.4901: since she will be captured even without the as­ sistance of the nets;
tgt_text.4902: for she soon grows weary from the depth of the snow, and the great quantity of it which attaches itself to her feet, which are hairy underneath.i.
tgt_text.4903: FOR hunting fawns and stags Indian dogs1 should be used ;
tgt_text.4904: for they are strong, large, swift, and not deficient in courage;
tgt_text.4905: and, having these qualities, are able to endure fatigue.
tgt_text.4906: The very young fawns 2 we should hunt in the spring, for it is in that season that they are born.
tgt_text.4907: 2. The hunts­ man should first go into the grassy glades, where the deer are most numerous, and survey the ground;
tgt_text.4908: and, wherever they are seen, he should come to that spot with his dogs and spears before daybreak, and should tie the dogs to the trees at some distance off, lest, if they should see the deer, they should be­ gin to bark;
tgt_text.4909: and he himself should keep on the watch.
tgt_text.4910: 3. At dawn he will see the hinds bringing each her young one to the place where she is going to have its bed.
tgt_text.4911: Having lain down, and given their young ones suck, looking round, at the same time, lest they should be seen by any one, they will go off severally to the parts opposite their young, still keeping watch over them.
tgt_text.4912: 4. The huntsman, on seeing them in this condition, must go and let loose his dogs, and, taking his spears in his hand, must advance towards the first of the fawns, at least to the part where he has seen it lying, taking careful note of the ground;
tgt_text.4913: for places often assume a different appearance as a person draws near them from that which they presented when he was at a distance.
tgt_text.4914: 5. When he has caught sight of the fawn, he must go close to it;
tgt_text.4915: for it will remain quiet, crouching 1 as it were down upon the ground, and will let the huntsman take it up, making at the same time a loud noise, unless it be wet with rain ;
tgt_text.4916: since, if such be the case, it will not lie still, as the moisture which it has in it, being con­ densed by the cold, will soon make it move off 2 6.
tgt_text.4917: But it will be caught by the dogs, which will pursue it with vigour;
tgt_text.4918: and when the huntsman has got possession of it, he must give it to the net-keeper;
tgt_text.4919: it will utter a cry, and the hind, seeing and hearing what is going on, will rush upon the man that holds it, and endeavour to take it from him.
tgt_text.4920: 7. At this june­ tion the huntsman must cheer on the dogs, and use his spears;
tgt_text.4921: and when he has captured this animal, he may proceed to take others, adopting the same means for getting possession of them.
tgt_text.4923: The very young fawns may be taken thus;
tgt_text.4924: but those that are well grown give some trouble;
tgt_text.4925: for they feed with their dams and other deer, and run off, when they are pursued, in the midst of the herd, or sometimes in advance of it, but very rarely in the rear.
tgt_text.4926: 9. The hinds, acting in de­ fence of them, trample down the dogs, so that they are not easily taken, unless the hunter rushes straight in among the herd, and separates them from one another, when one of the young may be left behind by himself.
tgt_text.4928: When the herd is thus violently scattered, the dogs will be left behind at the first run after the fawn;
tgt_text.4929: for the desertion of the other deer will render it excessively timid, and the swiftness of fawns of that age is beyond all other swiftness;
tgt_text.4930: but at the second or third run they are soon taken, as their bodies, from being still tender, are unable to bear up under fatigue.
tgt_text.4932: Snares are also set for deer on hills, or about meadows and streams, as well as in woods and paths and in cultivated grounds, wherever they are in the habit of going.
tgt_text.4933: 12. These snares should be made of twigs of yew twisted, with the bark not taken off,1 lest they should grow rotten;
tgt_text.4934: and should have the crowns2 circular, and the studs made of iron and wood alternately, inserted in the circle, the iron ones being the larger, that the wooden ones may yield to the feet, and the others press it.
tgt_text.4935: 13. Such a snare should have the noose of the rope which is to be fixed on the crown made of twisted hemp, as well as the rope itself;
tgt_text.4936: for this material is least likely to be­ come rotten;
tgt_text.4937: and let the noose, as well as the rope, be strong.
tgt_text.4938: Let the piece of wood which is suspended to it be of common or scarlet oak, with the bark on, three spans3 in length, and one palm 3 in thickness.
tgt_text.4939: 14. The hunter must fix these snares by opening the ground to the depth of five palms;
tgt_text.4940: and this opening must be round, and even at the edge with the crowns of the snares, and growing gradually narrower below ;
tgt_text.4941: 4 he must also open a portion of the ground for the rope and the wood, as deep as it is necessary for both to be buried.
tgt_text.4942: 15. When he has done this, he must put the snare over the open­ ing, sinking it to a depth equal with the surface, and put the noose of the rope round the crown, letting down the rope itself and the wood each into its own place;
tgt_text.4943: he must put twigs of thorn over the crown, not sticking out above the surface, and upon the twigs some dry leaves, such as the season may af­ ford.
tgt_text.4944: 16. After this he must strew upon the leaves a portion of the earth taken from the surface 1 of the parts that have been dug, and upon this some solid earth brought from a dis­ tance, in order that the position of the snare may be concealed as much as possible from the deer;
tgt_text.4945: and what remains of the earth he should carry off to a distance from the snare, for if the animal finds by the smell that it has been recently dis­ turbed (and this it soon does), it becomes suspicious.
tgt_text.4947: The huntsman must then keep watch with his dogs by the snares that are placed2 on the hills, especially in the morning;
tgt_text.4948: and he may do so during the rest of the day ;
tgt_text.4949: on cultivated grounds he should be on the look-out before day­ break ;
tgt_text.4950: for on the hills the deer are caught not only during the night, but also in the day, because such places are unfre­ quented by man;
tgt_text.4951: but in cultivated grounds they are caught during the night, as they are afraid of men there during the day.
tgt_text.4953: When he finds the snare turned up, he must let loose his dogs, and pursue, cheering them on, along the track of the wooden clog, observing carefully whither it leads.
tgt_text.4954: In general it will not be difficult to trace, for the stones will be up, and the scratches of the clog will be very plain on culti­ vated ground ;
tgt_text.4955: if the animal however runs through rough places, the rocky parts will have portions of the bark stripped from the clog adhering to them, and thus the pursuit will be rendered easier.
tgt_text.4956: 19. Should the deer have been caught by the fore-foot, it will be very soon secured;
tgt_text.4957: for the clog, as the animal runs, will strike against its whole body and face;
tgt_text.4958: 3 but if it be caught by the hind-foot, the clog, as it is dragged along, will impede the motion of its whole body.
tgt_text.4959: Sometimes the clog, too, will catch itself in forked branches of the wood, and the deer, unless it break the rope, will be caught there.
tgt_text.4960: 20. Should the huntsman capture it in this way, or by overcoming it with fatigue, he must not, if it be a male, approach near it, for it will strike out with its horns and feet, but must spear it from a distance.
tgt_text.4961: They may be caught, if pursued in summer-time, even without a snare;
tgt_text.4962: for they become so excessively exhausted that they stand still, and may then be killed with spears.
tgt_text.4963: If they are hard pressed, and reduced to extremity, they will throw themselves into the sea, or any other water;
tgt_text.4964: and some­ times they fall down through want of breath.
tgt_text.4966: FOR the wild boar it is necessary to have Indian, Cretan, Locrian, and Spartan dogs ;
tgt_text.4967: with nets, javelins, spears, and snares.
tgt_text.4968: As to the dogs of this sort, they must not be ordinary ones, that they may be fit to contend with the wild beast.
tgt_text.4969: 2. The nets must be of the same cord as those for hares ;
tgt_text.4970: but let the cords consist of forty-five threads in three strands, each strand being made of fifteen threads.
tgt_text.4971: Let there be ten meshes I in depth from the edge, and the depth of the nooses* a pygon.
tgt_text.4973: Let the ropes that run round the net be half as thick again as the cords of the nets ;
tgt_text.4974: let the nets have rings at the extremities ;
tgt_text.4975: and let the ropes be inserted under the nooses, and the ends of them come out through the rings.
tgt_text.4978: As to the javelins, let them be of all kinds, having the points of considerable breadth, and sharp as a razor, and the handles strong.
tgt_text.4979: The spears should have heads of the length of five palms, and in the middle, where the iron is inserted into the wood, guards jutting out, formed of the metal, very stout;
tgt_text.4980: and let them have handles of corneil wood, of the thick­ ness of an ordinary spear.
tgt_text.4981: The snares should be similar to those for deer.
tgt_text.4982: But let the hunters go in company ;
tgt_text.4983: for the animal is not to be captured without difficulty, and the assist­ ance of many hands.
tgt_text.4984: How it is necessary to use each of these implements in hunting, I will show.4.
tgt_text.4985: In the first place, then, when the hunters have come to the place where they suppose that there is a boar, they must bring up the dogs quietly, letting one of the Spartan dogs loose, and keeping the others tied, and go round about the place with the loose dog.
tgt_text.4986: 5. When this dog has found traces of the boar, they must continue their course along the track, which is to guide the whole train.
tgt_text.4988: There will also be many indications of the boar to guide the huntsmen ;
tgt_text.4989: marks of his footsteps on soft ground;
tgt_text.4990: pieces of the shrubs broken off in the woody parts ;
tgt_text.4991: and where there are large trees, scratches of his tusks upon them.
tgt_text.4992: 6. The doc, pursuing the track, will generally come to some woody spot;
tgt_text.4993: for the animal commonly lies in such places, as they are warm in winter, and cool in summer.
tgt_text.4994: 7. When it comes to the beast's lair, it begins to bark ;
tgt_text.4995: yet the boar will seldom rise on that account.
tgt_text.4996: It will be necessary, therefore, to take the dog and tie him up with the others at some distance from the lair, and stretch the nets at the entrance to the thicket, hanging the meshes upon the forked branches 2 of the wood ;
tgt_text.4997: and it will be proper, at the same time, to spread the net in a circuit extending out­ wards to some distance, placing branches of trees as supports on each side within, in order that the rays of light may pene­ trate through the meshes as much as possible into that circuit, and that the part within it may be as clear as possible for the animal when he rushes toward the nets.
tgt_text.4998: The rope that runs round the nets they ought to attach to a strong tree, and not to bushes;
tgt_text.4999: for bushes give way3 on open ground.
tgt_text.5000: About 1 each net they must stop up even the less open pas­ sages 2 through the thicket, that the boar may rush straight into the nets, without turning aside from them.
tgt_text.5002: When the nets are fixed, let them return to the dogs and set them all loose, and, taking their javelins and spears, go forward themselves.
tgt_text.5003: One of the most experienced of the hunters should cheer on the dogs;
tgt_text.5004: and the rest should follow in order, but at some considerable distance one from another, that a passage of sufficient breadth between them may be left for the boar;
tgt_text.5005: for if, as he makes his retreat, he should rush in among a number of them, there is danger that they may be wounded;
tgt_text.5006: since against whomsoever he runs, upon him he vents his rage.
tgt_text.5007: 9. When the dogs come near the beast's lair, they will make a start forward;
tgt_text.5008: the boar, being disturbed, will spring up, and whichever of the dogs happens to meet him face to face, he will toss him into the air, and, running forwards, will fall into the nets;
tgt_text.5009: or, if he does not, the hunters must pursue him.
tgt_text.5010: Should the ground, on which the net catches him, be sloping, 3 he will soon rise;
tgt_text.5011: should it be level, he will keep himself on his feet, intent on saving himself.
tgt_text.5012: 10. At this juncture the dogs will press forward;
tgt_text.5013: and the hunters, keeping on their guard against him, must throw their javelins at him, and pelt him with stones, gather­ ing round behind him, and at a considerable distance, until, by pushing himself forward, he pulls down the rope that runs round the net to its utmost stretch;
tgt_text.5014: and then, whoever among the company is the most skilful and the most vigorous, must go up to him and spear him in the fore part of the body.
tgt_text.5015: 11. But if, notwithstanding he is struck with javelins and stones, he will not stretch the rope, but draws back, and makes a turn upon any one that comes near him, one of the hunters must in that case take his spear and go up to him, holding it with the left hand on the fore part, and the right on the hinder;
tgt_text.5016: for the left directs it, and the right impels it;
tgt_text.5017: and let his left foot be in advance corresponding with the left hand, while the right is behind in accordance with the other hand.
tgt_text.5018: 12. As he advances, he must present the spear, with his feet not much farther apart than in wrestling, turning the left side forward towards the left hand, looking straight into the very eye of the boar, and watching every movement of his head.
tgt_text.5019: As he holds out his spear, he must take care lest the boar, by turning his head aside, wrest it out of his hand;
tgt_text.5020: for he will follow up the charge after it is thus wrested.
tgt_text.5021: 13. Should he have this misfortune, he must throw himself flat upon his face, and cling to whatever substance is below him ;
tgt_text.5022: for, if the boar fall upon him in this position, he will be unable to seize his body on account of his tusks being turned up ;
tgt_text.5023: 1 but if he attack him standing erect, he must necessarily be wounded.
tgt_text.5024: The boar will accordingly endeavour to raise him up;
tgt_text.5025: and if he cannot do so, will trample upon him with his feet.
tgt_text.5026: 14. When he is in this perilous condition, there is but one mode of delivering him from it, which is, for one of his fellow-hunters to come up close to the animal with his spear, and irritate him by feigning to throw it;
tgt_text.5027: but he must not throw it, lest he should hit his companion who is on the ground.
tgt_text.5028: 15. When the boar sees him doing this, he will leave the man whom he has under him.
tgt_text.5029: and turn with rage and fury on the one who is provoking him.
tgt_text.5030: The other must then jump up, but take care to do so with his spear in his hand;
tgt_text.5031: for there is no honourable 2 way of saving himself but by overcoming the boar.
tgt_text.5032: 16. He must therefore present his spear in the same manner as before, and thrust it forwards within the shoulder-blade, where the throat3 is, and must hold it firm and press against it with all his might.
tgt_text.5033: The boar will advance upon him courageously, and, if the guards of the spear did not prevent him, would push along the handle of it until he reached the person holding it.
tgt_text.5034: 17. Such is his vigour that there is in him what no one would suppose;
tgt_text.5035: for so hot are his tusks when he is just dead, that if a person lays hairs upon them, the hairs shrivel up;
tgt_text.5036: and when he is alive, they are actually on fire whenever he is irritated;
tgt_text.5037: for otherwise he would not singe the tips of dogs' hair when he misses inflicting a wound on their bodies.
tgt_text.5039: The boar is caught after giving such, and often still more, trouble.
tgt_text.5040: But if it be a sow that falls into the net, the hunter must run forward and strike it, taking care however that he be not pushed down ;
tgt_text.5041: for, if he should have this mis­ fortune, he will necessarily be trampled upon and bitten.
tgt_text.5042: He must not therefore fall willingly ;
tgt_text.5043: but if he should happen to fall unwillingly, his mode of rising must be the same as in the case of the boar.
tgt_text.5045: They are caught also in the following manner.
tgt_text.5046: Nets are stretched for them in passages through the forests, in thick­ ets, winding valleys, and rough grounds, where there are out­ lets to grassy spots, and marshes, and waters.
tgt_text.5047: He that is appointed for this duty guards the nets with a spear in his hand.
tgt_text.5048: Others bring up the dogs, looking for the most eligible places;
tgt_text.5049: and, when the boar is found, he is at once pursued.
tgt_text.5051: Should he fall into the net, the net-keeper must take up his spear, and use it in the way which I have described ;
tgt_text.5052: if he does not run into the net, he must hasten after him.
tgt_text.5053: lie may be caught also, when it is hot weather, by being pursued by the dogs;
tgt_text.5054: for though he is an animal of vast strength, yet he soon becomes exhausted from shortness of breath.
tgt_text.5055: 21. Many dogs, however, are killed in such chases, and the hunt­ ers themselves are in peril.
tgt_text.5056: But when, in the pursuit, they are compelled to present their spears to the boar as he is in the water, or has retired to some steep place, or is in a thicket from which he is unwilling to come out, though, in such a case, there is neither net nor anything else to prevent him from rushing immediately on the person who approaches hiin, they must nevertheless advance upon him, and show that cour­ age by which they were induced to engage in such toils for the gratification of their propensity.
tgt_text.5057: 22. They must use their spears, and such bodily efforts as have been described ;
tgt_text.5058: 1 for then, if any one of them suffers any hurt, he will not suffer it for want of acting rightly.
tgt_text.5059: Snares are set for them just as for deer, in the same places;
tgt_text.5060: and the same modes of watching, pursuing, approaching them, and using the spear are adopted.
tgt_text.5061: 23. Whenever their young ones are taken, they do not allow themselves to be captured without difficulty ;
tgt_text.5062: for they do not stray about alone, as long as they are small;
tgt_text.5063: and when the dogs find them, or they fore­ see any danger, they soon disappear among the wood.
tgt_text.5064: Both the old ones also generally follow them, which are then very fierce, and fight more resolutely for them than for themselves.
tgt_text.5066: LIONS, leopards, lynxes, panthers, bears, and other wild beasts of that description, are caught in foreign parts;
tgt_text.5067: some about the mountains Pangæus and Cittus beyond Macedonia, others about Olympus in Mysia, others on Mount Pindus, others on Nysa beyond Syria, and upon other mountains which are suited for breeding such animals.
tgt_text.5068: 2. Some of these beasts, on account of the difficulty of approaching their abodes, are taken by means of the drug called aconite, which the hunters throw in their way about the banks of streams, and whatever other places they frequent, mixing it with what­ ever each of the animals likes to eat.
tgt_text.5070: 3. Some of them also are captured as they come down into the plains in the night, being intercepted by the aid of horses and armed men, but not without bringing those who take them into danger.
tgt_text.5071: 4. For some of them, again, they make pit-falls, round, large, and deep, leaving in the middle a pillar of earth, upon the top of which they put a goat, tied fast, towards night;
tgt_text.5072: they also hedge the pit-fall round with wood (leaving no passage through), in order that the animals may not see over2 into it.
tgt_text.5073: Hearing the bleating of the goat during the night, they run round about the hedge, and, when they find no inlet, leap over it and are caught.1.
tgt_text.5074: CONCERNING the modes of proceeding in the chase I have now spoken.
tgt_text.5075: Those who are fond of the pursuit will receive many benefits from it ;
tgt_text.5076: for they will secure health for their bodies, greater keenness of sight and hearing, 1 and a later old age.
tgt_text.5077: 2. It is also an excellent preparation for the toils of war ;
tgt_text.5078: for, in the first place, when hunters march under arms through difficult roads, they will not faint, but will endure the toil from being accustomed to such exertion in capturing wild beasts.
tgt_text.5079: They will likewise be able to sleep on hard couches, and will be excellent guardians of what is intrusted to them.
tgt_text.5080: 3. In marches against the enemy they will both be in a condition to pursue their course, and to do what they are ordered, because they are used to similar exertions in captur­ ing beasts of prey.
tgt_text.5081: If they are placed in the front of the army, they will not leave their posts, as they are well qualified for persistence.
tgt_text.5082: 4. In a rout of the enemy, they will pursue them straight onwards, and with safety, over every sort of ground, from being familiarized to such exercise.
tgt_text.5083: If their own army experience misfortune, they will be able, in places that are marshy, or precipitous, or otherwise difficult, to save themselves, as well as others, without dishonour ;
tgt_text.5084: for their practice in such exertions will supply them with greater knowledge than those around them.
tgt_text.5085: 5. Such men, even when a great number of their allies have been put to flight, have renewed the contest, and by their well-exercised strength and courage have repulsed the enemy, who were led into error by the difficulties of the ground ;
tgt_text.5086: for it belongs to those who have their bodies and minds in good condition to be always near to good fortune.
tgt_text.5087: 6. Our ancestors also, knowing that from such causes they had been successful against their adversaries, paid great attention to the exercises of the youth;
tgt_text.5088: for though they bad in early times no abundance of the fruits of the ground, yet they did not think proper to hinder the young men from hunting over anything that grows upon the earth.
tgt_text.5089: 7. In ad­ dition, they decreed that they should not hunt in the night within a great number of stadia from the city, lest those who were skilled in the art should take from them their prey ;
tgt_text.5090: for they saw that this one pleasure of youth was productive of many advantages to them, as it renders them prudent and just, from being brought up in real action ;
tgt_text.5092: while, if they wish to pursue other honourable occupations, it does not draw them away from them, as other pleasures, of a vicious kind, do ;
tgt_text.5093: pleasures in which they ought not to engage.
tgt_text.5095: From men thus exercised, therefore, are formed good soldiers and good leaders;
tgt_text.5096: for those from whose minds and bodies toil has eradicated unbecoming and licentious inclina­ tions, and infused into them a desire of virtue, are the most excellent of citizens, since they will neither allow their me­ tropolis to be wronged, nor the lands of their country to be laid waste.
tgt_text.5098: Yet some say that people ought not to cherish a love of hunting, lest they should neglect their domestic affairs ;
tgt_text.5099: but such persons do not know that all who benefit their country and their friends are most attentive to their domestic affairs;
tgt_text.5101: and if, accordingly, those who are fond of hunting prepare themselves to be useful, in the most important particulars, to their country, they will not be neglectful of that which con­ cerns themselves ;
tgt_text.5102: for whatever belongs to each individual citizen stands or falls with the state;
tgt_text.5103: so that citizens thus qualified preserve the property of other individuals as well as their own.
tgt_text.5104: 12. But many of those who make such observa­ tions would rather, from being rendered unreasonable through envy, perish in their own indolence, than be preserved by the honourable exertions of others ;
tgt_text.5105: for most pleasures have a pernicious influence, and, being overcome by them, they are incited to take the worse course, in their words and actions, instead of the better.
tgt_text.5106: 13. Hence they bring on themselves, from foolish words, enmities, and, from ill conduct, diseases and punishments, as well as death to themselves and their children and their friends, being insensible to the evil that they were incurring, but having a keener inclination for plea­ sures than other men ;
tgt_text.5107: and who can make indulgence in plea­ sure turn to the benefit of his country ?
tgt_text.5108: 14. From these evils, however, every one will be free, who loves what I recommend, since good training teaches men to observe the laws, and to speak as well as to hear, with a regard to what is just.
tgt_text.5109: 15. Those who make it their study, accordingly, to be continually labouring and learning something, choose toilsome pursuits and cares for themselves, but secure safety for their own com­ munities ;
tgt_text.5110: but those who decline to be taught anything, because it is laborious, and prefer to spend their lives in improper pleasures, are characters of the very worst nature.
tgt_text.5112: They obey neither the laws nor good admonitions;
tgt_text.5113: for as they shrink from every effort at improvement, they gain no conception what a man of virtue ought to be ;
tgt_text.5114: so that they can neither be pious nor wise, but, consigning themselves to ignorance, inveigh greatly against those who are learned.
tgt_text.5115: 17. By means of such men, therefore, nothing can be made to prosper, as everything advantageous to mankind is found out by better men than they ;
tgt_text.5116: and the better are those who are willing to exert themselves.
tgt_text.5117: 18. This has been demonstrated by strong proof;
tgt_text.5118: for, among the ancients, those who studied under Chiron, and whom I mentioned before, began their ex­ ercises when they were young, with hunting, and became masters of many noble qualifications, whence great honour was paid to them for their virtue, for which they are even to the present day held in admiration.
tgt_text.5119: That all men have a love for such virtue is evident, but, because it is possible to attain it only by labour, the greater part of mankind shrink from the pursuit of it;
tgt_text.5120: and the at­ tainment of it is indeed uncertain, while the exertions attend­ ant on the pursuit of it are manifest.
tgt_text.5121: 19. Perhaps, however, if Virtue could be seen bodily, men would be less neglectful of her;
tgt_text.5122: knowing that they would be seen by her as she would be seen by them;
tgt_text.5124: for every one, when he is in the sight of the object of his love, conducts himself better than at other times, and neither does nor says anything unbecoming or wrong, lest it should be seen by that object.
tgt_text.5125: 21. But men, thinking that they are not seen by Virtue, because they do not see her, commit many wicked and dishonourable acts without disguise1 yet she is in reality present everywhere, as she is immortal, and honours those who act rightly towards her, and casts dis­ honour on those who act wrong.
tgt_text.5126: Could they feel assured, then, that she sees them, they would devote themselves to those labours and studies by which she is, though with diffi­ culty, captivated, and would secure her favour.
tgt_text.5128: BUT I wonder at those men who are called sophists, be­ cause the most of them say that they lead mankind to virtue, while in reality they lead them in a contrary direction ;
tgt_text.5129: for we have nowhere seen any man whom the present race of sophists have rendered virtuous;
tgt_text.5130: nor do they offer any writ­ ings to the world by which people may be made virtuous.
tgt_text.5131: 2. But concerning frivolous subjects many treatises have been written by them, from which empty amusement for the young may be derived, but in which there are no precepts of virtue;
tgt_text.5132: treatises which cause useless consumption of time to those who vainly hope to learn something from them, detaining them from other more profitable occupations, and even teach­ ing them what is bad.
tgt_text.5133: 3. I blame them, then, for their more grave offences2 more severely;
tgt_text.5134: but as to what they write, I say that their words are studied with the utmost care, but that moral principles, by which youth may be formed to vir­ tue, are nowhere to be found in them.
tgt_text.5135: 4. I indeed am no extraordinary person, but I know that while it is best to be taught what is good by nature herself, it is next in desirable­ ness to be instructed by those who really know something of goodness rather than by such as understand merely the art of deceiving.
tgt_text.5136: 5. My words, perhaps, I may not use with the art of the sophists, for I make it not my object to do so;
tgt_text.5137: but the instructions which those need who are rightly trained to virtue I try to express with proper understanding of them ;
tgt_text.5138: for mere words cannot afford instruction, 1 but thoughts may, if they be of a right kind.
tgt_text.5140: Many others also blame the sophists of the present day (I do not say the philosophers), for showing their acuteness in words and not in thoughts.
tgt_text.5141: It does not escape my con­ sideration that it would be well for what I write to be ar­ ranged in proper order, for it will be easy for them to find fault with what is written hastily as not being written ele­ gantly ;
tgt_text.5143: it is written however in such a way that it may express what is right, and may make men, not sophistical, but wise and good;
tgt_text.5144: for I do not wish it merely to seem, but to be good, that it may remain irrefutable for ever.
tgt_text.5145: 8. The sophists, on the contrary, speak and write only to deceive, and for their own gain, and profit nobody in any way ;
tgt_text.5146: for no one of them has ever been, or is, wise;
tgt_text.5147: but each of them is content with being called a sophist, which is but a term of reproach among the right-thinking part of mankind.
tgt_text.5148: 9. Against the precepts of the sophists, therefore, I exhort the young to be on their guard, but not to undervalue the instructions of the philosophers ;
tgt_text.5149: for the sophists hunt for the rich and young ;
tgt_text.5150: but the philosophers are the common teachers and common friends of all.
tgt_text.5151: The fortunes of men they neither esteem nor contemn.10.
tgt_text.5152: I exhort the young, also, not to emulate those who hastily seek their own aggrandisement, whether in private or in public affairs, reflecting that while the best of them are known to their honour, and are industrious, the bad meet with ill fortune, and are distinguished to their disgrace;
tgt_text.5154: for, robbing individuals of their property, and embezzling the money of the public, they are less profitable to the common welfare than persons in a private station, while they have their bodies in the very worst and most disgraceful condition for war, being utterly incapable of any exertion.
tgt_text.5155: But hunt­ ers, on the contrary, present alike their bodies and their pro­ perty in excellent condition for promoting the common good of their countrymen.
tgt_text.5157: the other sort of people attack their friends.
tgt_text.5158: Those who act against their friends incur infamy among all men;
tgt_text.5159: hunters, from pursuing wild beasts, gain great honour;
tgt_text.5160: for, if they capture the beasts, they subdue enemies ;
tgt_text.5161: and, if they do not, they nevertheless receive praise, not only because they assail animals that meditate mischief to the whole community, but because they'proceed against them neither to the injury of any man nor for their own private gain.
tgt_text.5162: 13. Besides, by the exercise itself they are rendered better for many purposes, as well as wiser, by the causes which I shall specify.
tgt_text.5163: If, in the first place, they did not highly excel in activity, and contriv­ ances, and vigilance, in various ways, they would gain no booty ;
tgt_text.5165: for their adversaries, fighting for their lives, and in their own retreats, are in full force;
tgt_text.5166: so that the toil of the hunter would be in vain, if he did not subdue them with greater perseverance and with much intelligence.
tgt_text.5167: 15. Those who wish, then, to gain a superior station in the state, medi­ tate how to overcome their friends;
tgt_text.5168: the hunters, how to over­ throw common enemies.
tgt_text.5169: The exercise of the hunters makes them better men for other opponents;
tgt_text.5170: the practice of the other sort of people much worse men ;
tgt_text.5171: the prey of the one is gained in conjunction with wisdom, that of the other with disgrace­ ful audacity.
tgt_text.5172: 16. The one can despise mean practices and dis­ honourable gains, the other cannot;
tgt_text.5173: the one utter a voice expressive of good, the other, of turpitude;
tgt_text.5174: the one show themselves pious in the highest degree, the other feel nothing to restrain them from acting impiously towards all the di­ vinities.
tgt_text.5176: Tales of old times are in circulation, which say that the gods delight in the pursuit of hunting, both as actors and as spectators;
tgt_text.5177: so that the young, reflecting on this, may be both lovers of the gods and pious in their conduct, at least those who observe the admonitions which I give, and think that what they do is seen by some one of the deities ;
tgt_text.5178: and they will then be a benefit to their parents, their country in gener­ al, and everyone of their fellow-citizens and friends.
tgt_text.5180: Not only indeed have men who have been fond of the chace ob­ tained an honourable character, but also women to whom the goddess Diana has given excellence in the pursuit, as Ata. lanta, Precis, and some others.
tgt_text.5181: I. HERMOGENES, happening to meet me, told me some other things, and, as I asked him about you, what system of philosophy you followed, he replied, the same as Socrates.
tgt_text.5182: 2. But even when you were living at Athens, I admired your judgment;
tgt_text.5183: and as I began to admire you then, so also now I admire the unshaken firmness of your mind above any of those that have embraced the pursuit of wisdom;
tgt_text.5184: for it is, as I consider, the greatest proof of virtue, that you have been attracted by that man, if indeed people thought2 the life of Socrates that of a mortal man.3.
tgt_text.5185: That there are divine beings over us is manifest to every one;
tgt_text.5186: and it is enough for us to worship them for the superiority of their power;
tgt_text.5187: but of what nature they are, it is neither easy to find, nor dutiful to inquire;
tgt_text.5188: for it does not be­ long to slaves to understand the nature and conduct of their masters, as their sole business is to serve;
tgt_text.5189: 4. and, what is the most remarkable, the more admiration we must bestow on those who labour for the interests of mankind, the more blame is attached 3 to those who aim at getting reputation from improper and worthless objects.
tgt_text.5190: 5. For when, my dear Machines, did any one ever hear Socrates discoursing about the heavenly bodies, 1 or exhorting men to learn geometry in order to improve their morals ?
tgt_text.5191: As for music, we are aware that he knew nothing more of it than the pleasure of hearing it.
tgt_text.5192: But he was constantly discussing with his friends what propriety was, or fortitude, or justice, or other virtues.
tgt_text.5194: 6. These he called the important concerns of mankind;
tgt_text.5195: other things he said were impossible to be comprehended by man, or were akin to fables, trifling amusements for the mind, such as those on which the sophists so superciliously descant.
tgt_text.5196: Nor did he only say this, without observing it in his conduct;
tgt_text.5197: but to detail what he did to you who know it, though it would not be unpleasing, would take up time;
tgt_text.5198: and I have recorded it elsewhere.
tgt_text.5200: Let those, therefore, whom Socrates did not satisfy, be convinced and keep silence, or adopt just notions respecting him;
tgt_text.5201: a man to whose wisdom the god at Delphi testified, while those who put him to death could find no expiation by repentance.
tgt_text.5202: 4 8. But these illustrious philosophers 5 are in love with Egypt and the prodigious knowledge of Pythagoras, 6 their extravagant pursuit of which convicts them of incon­ stancy to Socrates, as does also their love of tyranny, and their preference of the immoderate luxury of a Sicilian table to a frugal diet.
tgt_text.5204: For be assured that Socrates often said to us, that those who are anxious about their children that they may have abundance of wealth, but have no care that they may become honourable and upright, act like those who breed horses, but train them to no military uses, though they supply them with abundance of food ;
tgt_text.5206: since they will thus have their horses fatter, but unqualified for what they ought to be able to do, as the merit of a horse consists, not in having abund­ ance of flesh, but in being courageous and well-exercised for the field of battle.
tgt_text.5207: The same fault, he said, was committed by those who acquire a great quantity of land for their children, but are regardless of their personal improvement;
tgt_text.5208: since what they possess will be thought of great value, but themselves of very little ;
tgt_text.5209: while, on the contrary, that which possesses ought to be more valuable than that which is possessed.
tgt_text.5210: 3. Accord­ ingly, he who renders his son deserving of high estimation has, though he bequeaths him but little, bestowed upon him much ;
tgt_text.5211: for it is from the condition of the mind 2 that our possessions appear greater or less, since to a well-ordered mind they seem sufficient, but to an ill-regulated and untaught mind too little.
tgt_text.5212: 4. You give your children nothing more than necessity requires :
tgt_text.5213: this, however, by the well-instructed, is considered not only sufficient for their wants, but absolute wealth ;
tgt_text.5214: but as for the ignorant, though it frees them from bodily uneasiness,3 it does not at all diminish their despondent views of the future.
tgt_text.5215: To me, Soteira, death appears nothing either repulsive or attractive, but merely an end of life, though not indeed the same for all, as inequality from birth, in regard to strength or weakness, brings inequality in number of years ;
tgt_text.5216: 5 and as different causes, sometimes disgraceful, and sometimes honour­ able and becoming, bring on death.
tgt_text.5217: But neither ought you to feel so much concern about death, knowing that we must regard birth as the beginning of man's course, and death as the end.
tgt_text.5218: He2 has died, as he who was even ever so reluctant would have died;
tgt_text.5219: but to die honourably is the part of one who is willing to die, and who has been taught what he ought to know.
tgt_text.5220: Happy therefore is Gryllus, and whoever chooses, not the greatest prolongation of life, but life distinguished by virtue ;
tgt_text.5221: though the gods granted him, indeed, but a short life....
tgt_text.5222: For you must first of all approve the excellent precept of Socrates, that "we must measure wealth ;
tgt_text.5223: "4 for Socrates used to say, that vast property was not wealth, but so much as is becoming for us to use ;
tgt_text.5224: and he admonished us besides not to err in our judgment about such matters, as those who use what they possess becomingly are justly to be called rich ;
tgt_text.5225: but others he pronounced poor, and declared that they were afflicted with poverty of an incurable kind, as it was want of understanding, and not of pecuniary means.
tgt_text.5227: No evil indeed originates with a man who makes prudence and temperance the foundations of wisdom.
tgt_text.5228: There are five Letters attributed to Xenophon in the Socratis et Socra­ ticorum Epistolæ, published by Leo Allatius, and placed by Weiske at the end of his edition of Xenophon ;
tgt_text.5229: but as they, with the rest of the let­ ters in Leo's volume, are now universally regarded as forgeries, it is not thought necessary to translate them.
